εr(py)\begin{document}$\varepsilon_{{r}}^{\left (\rm{py}\right)}$\end{document} and εf(py)\begin{document}$\varepsilon_{{f}}^{\left (\rm{py}\right)}$\end{document} are the proteome efficiencies for energy biogenesis using pyruvate in the respiration and fermentation pathways.
The corresponding variables of εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document} in the case of pyruvate utilization.

Ω`Gg\begin{document}$\mathrm{\Omega }^{\mathrm{'}}_{\mathrm{G}\mathrm{g}}$\end{document} is a composite parameter defined as ΩGg′≡(ηb+ηc)/κ8+ηa1/κ9\begin{document}$\mathrm{\Omega }^{\mathrm{'}}_{\mathrm{G}\mathrm{g}}\equiv \left (\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}\right) \big/\kappa _{8}+\eta _{a1}/\kappa _{9}$\end{document}.

ψpy\begin{document}${\psi _{\rm{py}}}$\end{document}, φpy\begin{document}$\varphi _\rm{py}$\end{document}, κpy(ST)\begin{document}$\kappa _{\rm{py}}^{\left ({\rm{ST}}\right)}$\end{document}, κpy(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{\rm{py}}^{\left ({\rm{C}}\right)}$\end{document} and λmax(py)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\mathrm{max}}^{\left ({\rm{py}}\right)}$\end{document} are the corresponding variables/parameters of ψ\begin{document}$\psi $\end{document}, φ\begin{document}$\varphi $\end{document}, κAmax\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\mathrm{m}\mathrm{a}\mathrm{x}}$\end{document}, κAC\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\left (C\right)}$\end{document} and λmax\begin{document}$\lambda _{\mathrm{m}\mathrm{a}\mathrm{x}}$\end{document} in the case of pyruvate utilization.

λC(py)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm{C}}^{\left ({\rm{py}}\right)}$\end{document}, μλC(py)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\rm{C}}^{\left ({\rm{py}}\right)}}$\end{document} and σλC(py)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\rm{C}}^{\left ({\rm{py}}\right)}}$\end{document} are the corresponding variables/parameters of λC\begin{document}$\lambda _\rm{C}$\end{document}, μλC\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _\rm{C}}$\end{document} and σλC\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{C}}$\end{document} in the case of pyruvate utilization.
The number of carbon atoms in a molecule of Pool i.
The value of NPicarbon\begin{document}$N_{{\rm{P}}_{i}}^\rm{carbon}$\end{document} is approximated by NEPicarbon\begin{document}$N_{{\rm{EP}}_{i}}^\rm{carbon}$\end{document} (Equation S107).
The substrate quality of the external supplied amino acids identical to those in Pool i.

Ω21AA\begin{document}$\mathrm{\Omega }_{21\mathrm{A}\mathrm{A}}$\end{document} is a composite parameter defined as Ω21AA≡1/κt+ηa1/κa1+∑ia2,b,c,dηi/κi(21AA)\begin{document}$\begin{array}{ll}\mathrm{\Omega }_{21\mathrm{A}\mathrm{A}}\equiv 1 \big/\kappa _{t}+\eta _{a1} \big/\kappa _{a1}\\+\sum \limits_{i}^{a2,b,c,d}\eta _{i} \big/\kappa _{i}^{\left (\rm{21AA}\right)}\end{array}$\end{document}.

ψ21AA\begin{document}$\psi _\rm{21AA}$\end{document}, φ21AA\begin{document}$\varphi _\rm{21AA}$\end{document}, λmax(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\mathrm{m}\mathrm{a}\mathrm{x}}^{\left (\rm{21AA}\right)}$\end{document}, λC(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm{C}}^{\left ({\rm{21AA}}\right)}$\end{document}, μλC(21AA)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\rm{C}}^{\left ({\rm{21AA}}\right)}}$\end{document} and σλC(21AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\rm{C}}^{\left ({\rm{21AA}}\right)}}$\end{document} are the corresponding variables/parameters of ψ\begin{document}$\psi $\end{document}, φ\begin{document}$\varphi $\end{document}, λmax\begin{document}$\lambda _{\mathrm{m}\mathrm{a}\mathrm{x}}$\end{document}, λC\begin{document}$\lambda _\rm{C}$\end{document}, μλC\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _\rm{C}}$\end{document} and σλC\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _\rm{C}}$\end{document} in the case of a Group A carbon source is mixed with 21 types of amino acids at saturated concentrations.

Ω7AA\begin{document}$\mathrm{\Omega }_{7\mathrm{A}\mathrm{A}}$\end{document}, φ7AA\begin{document}$\varphi _\rm{7AA}$\end{document}, μλC(7AA)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\rm{C}}^{\left ({\rm{7AA}}\right)}}$\end{document} and σλC(7AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\rm{C}}^{\left ({\rm{7AA}}\right)}}$\end{document} are the corresponding parameters of Ω\begin{document}$\mathrm{\Omega }$\end{document}, φ\begin{document}$\varphi $\end{document}, μλC\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _\rm{C}}$\end{document} and σλC\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _\rm{C}}$\end{document} in the case of a Group A carbon source is mixed with 7 types of amino acids.

Jin(N)\begin{document}$J_{\rm{in}}^{\left ({\rm{N}}\right)}$\end{document} is the normalized stoichiometric influx of a Group A carbon source (Equation S136). ϑ\begin{document}$\vartheta $\end{document} is a parameter defined as ϑ=ηa1+ηc+(ηa2+ηb+ηd)/2\begin{document}$\vartheta =\eta _{a1}+\eta _{c}+\left (\eta _{a2}+\eta _{b}+\eta _{d}\right) \big/2$\end{document} for the model shown in Figure 1B.

χext\begin{document}$\chi _\rm{ext}$\end{document}, χint\begin{document}$\chi _\rm{int}$\end{document} and χtot\begin{document}$\chi _\rm{tot}$\end{document} are the level of extrinsic noise, intrinsic noise and total noise in a system.

μkicat\begin{document}$\mu _{k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document} and σkicat\begin{document}$\sigma _{k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document} are the mean and standard deviation of kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^\rm{cat}$\end{document}. μ1/kicat\begin{document}$\mu _{1/k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document} (or μ1/kicat′\begin{document}$\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\rm{cat}}}^{\mathrm{'}}$\end{document}) and σ1/kicat\begin{document}$\sigma _{1/k_{i}^{\rm{cat}}}$\end{document} (or σ1/kicat′\begin{document}$\sigma^{\mathrm{'}} _{1/k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document}) are the mean and standard deviation of 1/kicat\begin{document}$1\big/k_{i}^{\rm{cat}}$\end{document}. See Appendix 8.1.

μkicat\begin{document}$\mu _{k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document} is approximated by the deterministic value of kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^\rm{cat}$\end{document}. The CV of kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^\rm{cat}$\end{document} is set to 25%. μ1/kicat\begin{document}$\mu _{1/k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document}≈1/μkicat\begin{document}$\mu _{k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document}; σ1/kicat\begin{document}$\sigma _{1/k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document}/μ1/kicat\begin{document}$\mu _{1/k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document}≈σkicat\begin{document}$\sigma _{k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document}/μkicat\begin{document}$\mu _{k_{i}^\rm{cat}}$\end{document}.
The inverse Gaussian (IG) distribution: variable x>0 with parameters μ\begin{document}$\mu $\end{document} and ζ\begin{document}$\zeta $\end{document}. See Equation S142.

The positive inverse of Gaussian (IOG) distribution: variable x>0 with parameters μ\begin{document}$\mu $\end{document} and ζ\begin{document}$\zeta $\end{document}. See Equation S140 and Appendix 8.1.
Distributional parameters of 1/kicat\begin{document}$1 \big/k_{i}^\rm{cat}$\end{document} corresponding to ζ\begin{document}$\zeta $\end{document} in an IG or IOG distribution.
The characteristic function of IG distribution. See Equation S147.

Xi\begin{document}$X_{i}$\end{document}, αi\begin{document}$\alpha _{i}$\end{document}, Θ\begin{document}$\Theta $\end{document} and Γi(t)\begin{document}$\Gamma _{i}\left (t\right)$\end{document} are variables and parameters used to calculate the first passage time TΘ\begin{document}$T_{\Theta }$\end{document} of a stochastic process that mimics the duration of an enzyme to finishing a catalytic job.

γi\begin{document}$\gamma _{i}$\end{document} is a real number; Ξ\begin{document}$\Xi $\end{document} is a variable defined as Ξ≡∑i=1nγi/kicat\begin{document}$\Xi \equiv \sum \limits_{i=1}^{n}\gamma _{i} \big/k_{i}^{\rm{cat}}$\end{document}; μΞ\begin{document}$\mu _{\Xi }$\end{document} and σΞ\begin{document}$\sigma _{\Xi }$\end{document} are the mean and standard deviation of Ξ\begin{document}$\Xi $\end{document}.

μκi\begin{document}$\mu _{\kappa _{i}}$\end{document} and σκi\begin{document}$\sigma _{\kappa _{i}}$\end{document} are the mean and standard deviation of κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document}; μ1/κi\begin{document}$\mu _{1/\kappa _{i}}$\end{document} and σ1/κi\begin{document}$\sigma _{1/\kappa _{i}}$\end{document} are the mean and standard deviation of 1/κi\begin{document}$1/\kappa _{i}$\end{document}.
See Equation S154 and Appendices 8.1 and 9.2.

λr\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{\lambda }_{\boldsymbol{r}}$\end{document}, λf\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{\lambda }_{\boldsymbol{f}}$\end{document}, μλr\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{\mu }_{\boldsymbol{\lambda }_{\boldsymbol{r}}}$\end{document}, σλr\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{\sigma }_{\boldsymbol{\lambda }_{\boldsymbol{r}}}$\end{document}, μλf\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{\mu }_{\boldsymbol{\lambda }_{\boldsymbol{f}}}$\end{document}, σλf\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{\sigma }_{\boldsymbol{\lambda }_{\boldsymbol{f}}}$\end{document}, ρrf\begin{document}$\boldsymbol{\rho }_{\boldsymbol{r}\boldsymbol{f}}$\end{document}

λr\begin{document}$\lambda _{r}$\end{document} and λf\begin{document}$\lambda _{f}$\end{document} are the growth rates when cells choose respiration or fermentation; μλr\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{r}}$\end{document}, μλf\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{f}}$\end{document} and σλr\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{r}}$\end{document}, σλf\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}$\end{document} are the means and standard deviations of λr\begin{document}$\lambda _{r}$\end{document} and λf\begin{document}$\lambda _{f}$\end{document}; ρrf\begin{document}$\rho _{rf}$\end{document} is the correlation of λr\begin{document}$\lambda _{r}$\end{document} and λf\begin{document}$\lambda _{f}$\end{document}.
See Equation S36 and Appendices 8.1 and 9.2.

λsuccinate(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm{succinate}}^{\left ({\rm{21AA}}\right)}$\end{document} and λacetate\begin{document}$\lambda _\rm{acetate}$\end{document} are the growth rates for succinate mixed with 21AA or acetate as the sole carbon source; μλsuccinate(21AA)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\rm{succinate}}^{\left (\rm{21AA}\right)}}$\end{document}, μλacetate\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _\rm{acetate}}$\end{document} and σλsuccinate(21AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\rm{succinate}}^{\left (\rm{21AA}\right)}}$\end{document}, σλacetate\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _\rm{acetate}}$\end{document} are the means and standard deviations of λsuccinate(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm{succinate}}^{\left (\rm{21AA}\right)}$\end{document} and λacetate\begin{document}$\lambda _\rm{acetate}$\end{document}.

ϕMT\begin{document}$\phi _\rm{MT}$\end{document} and κMT\begin{document}$\kappa _\rm{MT}$\end{document} are the proteomic mass fraction of the enzymes and the effective substrate quality of related metabolites in the mitochondria for yeast and mammalian cells, respectively.

The proportion of ATP generated from fermentation: Prf≡Jf(E)Jf(E)+Jr(E)\begin{document}$\mathrm{P}\mathrm{r}_{f}\equiv \frac{J_{f}^{\left ({\rm{E}}\right)}}{J_{f}^{\left ({\rm{E}}\right)}+J_{r}^{\left ({\rm{E}}\right)}}$\end{document}.
See Equations S180, S189 and Appendix 10.
The proteome efficiency difference between respiration and fermentation: Δ¯≡1/εr−1/εf.\begin{document}$\bar{\Delta }\equiv 1/\varepsilon _{r}-1/\varepsilon _{f}.$\end{document}
See Equations S181, S187 and Appendix 10.

μεr\begin{document}$\mu _{\varepsilon _{r}}$\end{document}, μεf\begin{document}$\mu _{\varepsilon _{f}}$\end{document}, μ1/εr\begin{document}$\mu _{1/\varepsilon _{r}}$\end{document} and μ1/εf\begin{document}$\mu _{1/\varepsilon _{f}}$\end{document} are the mean values of εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} , εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, 1/εr\begin{document}$1/\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and 1/εf\begin{document}$1/\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, respectively.

σεr\begin{document}$\sigma _{\varepsilon _{r}}$\end{document}, σεf\begin{document}$\sigma _{\varepsilon _{f}}$\end{document}, σ1/εr\begin{document}$\sigma _{1/\varepsilon _{r}}$\end{document}, and σ1/εf\begin{document}$\sigma _{1/\varepsilon _{f}}$\end{document} are the standard deviations of εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} , εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, 1/εr\begin{document}$1/\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and 1/εf\begin{document}$1/\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, respectively.
See Equations S182, S185 and Appendix 10.

χεr\begin{document}$\chi _{\varepsilon _{r}}$\end{document}, χεf\begin{document}$\chi _{\varepsilon _{f}}$\end{document}, χ1/εr\begin{document}$\chi _{1/\varepsilon _{r}}$\end{document}, and χ1/εf\begin{document}$\chi _{1/\varepsilon _{f}}$\end{document} are the coefficients of variation of εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} , εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, 1/εr\begin{document}$1/\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and 1/εf\begin{document}$1/\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, respectively.

μΔ¯\begin{document}$\mu _{\bar{\Delta }}$\end{document} and σΔ¯\begin{document}$\sigma _{\bar{\Delta }}$\end{document} are the mean and standard deviation of Δ¯\begin{document}$\bar{\Delta }$\end{document}, respectively.

εr\begin{document}$\left \langle \varepsilon _{r}\right \rangle $\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\left \langle \varepsilon _{f}\right \rangle $\end{document} are the population-averaged values of εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, respectively.
Measurable from experiments.See Equations S183-S184 and Appendix 10.

fn.p: Parameter settings for yeast and mammalian cells are specifically labeled as ‘eukaryotic cells.’
Extensive variables scale with the size of the cell population.
Intensive variables are scale-invariant with respect to the cell population.

caption.title: Central metabolic network and carbon utilization pathways of E. coli.
caption.p: (A) Energy biogenesis details in the central metabolic network. In E. coli, NADPH and NADH are interconvertible (Sauer et al., 2004), and all energy carriers can be converted to ATP through ADP phosphorylation. The conversion factors are: NADH = 2 ATP, NADPH = 2 ATP, FADH2=1 ATP (Neidhardt et al., 1990). (B) Relevant genes encoding enzymes in the central metabolic network of E. coli. (C–E) Three independent fates of glucose metabolism in E. coli. (C) For energy biogenesis through fermentation, a molecule of glucose generates 12 ATPs. (D) For energy biogenesis via respiration, a molecule of glucose generates 26 ATPs. (E) For biomass synthesis, glucose is converted into precursors of biomass. Note that biomass synthesis is accompanied by ATP production (see Appendix 3.1).

caption.title: Model and results for experimental comparison of E. coli.
caption.p: (A–C) Model analysis for carbon utilization in mixtures with amino acids. (A) Coarse-grained model for the case of a Group A carbon source mixed with extracellular amino acids. (B) Model predictions (Equations S157, S164-S165) and single-cell reference experimental results (Wallden et al., 2016) showing growth rate distributions for E. coli in three culturing conditions. (C) Comparison of the growth rate-fermentation flux relation for E. coli in Group A carbon sources between minimal media and enriched media (those with 7AA). (D–E) Influence of translation inhibition on overflow metabolism in E. coli. (D) A 3D plot illustrating the relations among fermentation flux, growth rate, and translation efficiency (Equations S79 and S160). (E) Growth rate dependence of acetate excretion rate as κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} varies, with each fixed dose of Cm. Translation efficiency is tuned by the dose of Cm, and the maintenance energy coefficient is set to 0 (i.e. w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document}). (F) Coarse-grained model for Group A carbon source utilization, which includes more details to compare with experiments. (G) Comparison of in vivo and in vitro catalytic rates for enzymes of E. coli within glycolysis and the TCA cycle (see Appendix 1—table 1 for details). (H) The proteome efficiencies for energy biogenesis in the respiration and fermentation pathways vary with growth rate as functions of the substrate quality of pyruvate (Equations S93 and S96)

caption.title: Relative protein expression of central metabolic enzymes in E. coli under various types of perturbations.
caption.p: (A–D) Relative protein expression under κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} perturbation. (A) Experimental data (Hui et al., 2015) for the catalytic enzymes at each step of glycolysis. (B) Experimental data (Hui et al., 2015) for the catalytic enzymes at each step of the TCA cycle. (C) Model predictions (Equation S118, with w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document}) and experimental data (Hui et al., 2015) for representative glycolytic genes. (D) Model predictions (Equation S118, with w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document}) and experimental data (Hui et al., 2015) for representative genes from the TCA cycle. (E–J) Relative protein expression under ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} perturbation. (E, F, I) Model predictions and experimental data (Basan et al., 2015) for representative glycolytic genes. (G, H, J) Model predictions and experimental data (Basan et al., 2015) for representative genes from the TCA cycle. (E–H) Results of ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} perturbation with w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document} (Equation S120). (I–J) Results of ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} perturbation with w0=2.5(h−1)\begin{document}$w_{0}=2.5 \,\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document} (Equation S121). (K–N) Relative protein expression upon energy dissipation. (K–L) Model fits (Equations S127 and S123) and experimental data (Basan et al., 2015) for representative glycolytic genes. (M–N) Model fits (Equations S127 and S123) and experimental data (Basan et al., 2015) for representative genes from the TCA cycle.

caption.title: Asymptotic distributions of inverse Gaussian distribution and the inverse of Gaussian distribution.
caption.p: (A) Comparison between the inverse of Gaussian distribution and the corresponding Gaussian distribution for various values of the coefficient of variation (CV) (Equations S140 and S145). (B) Comparison between the inverse Gaussian distribution and the corresponding Gaussian distribution for various values of CV (Equations S142 and S146). Both the inverse Gaussian distribution and the inverse of Gaussian distribution converge to Gaussian distributions when CV is small.

caption.title: Carbon utilization in yeast and mammalian cells.
caption.p: (A–D) Three independent fates of glucose metabolism in yeast and mammalian cells. (A–B) For energy biogenesis through fermentation, one molecule of glucose generates 2 ATPs. (C) For energy biogenesis through respiration, one molecule of glucose generates 32 ATPs. (D) For biomass synthesis, glucose is converted into biomass precursors, with ATP produced as a byproduct. In yeast and mammalian cells, the energy stored in NADH and FADH2 converts ADP into ATP in the mitochondria, with higher conversion factors than in E. coli: NADH = 2.5 ATP, FADH2=1.5 ATP (Nelson and Cox, 2008). (E) Coarse-grained model for Group A carbon source utilization in yeast. (F) Coarse-grained model for Group A carbon source utilization in mammalian cells.

sec.title: 2.1 Proteome partition
sec.p: Here, we adopt the proteome partition framework similar to that introduced by Scott et al., 2010. All proteins in a cell are classified into three classes: the fixed portion Q-class, the active ribosome-affiliated R-class, and the remaining catabolic/anabolic enzymes C-class. Each proteome class has a mass Mi(P)\begin{document}$M_{i}^{\left (\text{P}\right)}$\end{document} (i=Q,R,C\begin{document}$i=\text{Q},\text{R},\text{C}$\end{document}) and mass fraction ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document}, where ϕQ\begin{document}$\phi _\rm{Q}$\end{document} is a constant, and we define ϕmax≡1−ϕQ\begin{document}$\phi _{\rm{max}}\equiv 1- \phi _{\rm{Q}}$\end{document}. In the exponential growth phase, the ribosome allocation for protein synthesis of each class is fi\begin{document}$f_{i}$\end{document}, with fQ+fR+fC=1\begin{document}$f_{\text{Q}}+f_{\text{R}}+f_{\text{C}}=1$\end{document}.

To analyze cell growth optimization, we first consider the homogeneous case where all cells share identical biochemical parameters, simplifying the mass accumulation of the cell population into a ‘big cell.’ This simplification does not affect the value of growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document}. For bacteria, the protein turnover is negligible, so the mass accumulation of each class follows:(S1)dMi(P)/dt=fi⋅kT⋅NR⋅mAA(i=Q,R,C),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle dM_{i}^{\rm{(P)}}\big/dt=f_{i}\cdot k_{\rm{T}}\cdot N_{\rm{R}}\cdot m_{\rm{AA}}\qquad (i=\rm{{Q},{R},{C}}),$$\end{document}

where mAA\begin{document}$m_{\text{AA}}$\end{document} stands for the average molecular weight of amino acids, kT\begin{document}$k_{\text{T}}$\end{document} is the translation rate, NR=Mrp(P)/mR\begin{document}$N_{\text{R}}=M_{\text{rp}}^{\left (\text{P}\right)}\big/m_{\text{R}}$\end{document} is the number of ribosomes, mR\begin{document}$m_{\text{R}}$\end{document} is the protein mass of a single ribosome, and Mrp(P)\begin{document}$M_{\text{rp}}^{\left (\text{P}\right)}$\end{document} is the total protein mass of ribosomes, with MR(P)/Mrp(P)=ς≈1.67\begin{document}$M_{\text{R}}^{\left (\text{P}\right)}\big/M_{\text{rp}}^{\left (\text{P}\right)}=\varsigma \approx 1.67$\end{document} (Neidhardt, 1996; Scott et al., 2010). For a specific stable nutrient environment, fR\begin{document}$f_{\text{R}}$\end{document} and kT\begin{document}$k_{\text{T}}$\end{document} are temporal invariants. Thus,(S2)Mi(P)(t)=Mi(P)(0)+fi/fR⋅MR(P)(0)⋅[exp(λ⋅t)−1](i=Q,R,C),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle M_{i}^{\rm{(P)}}(t)=M_{i}^{\rm{(P)}}(0)+f_{i}\big/f_{\rm{R}}\cdot M_{\rm{R}}^{\rm{(P)}}(0)\cdot [{\rm{exp}}(\lambda\cdot t )-1]\qquad (i={\rm{Q, R, C}}),$$\end{document}

where λ=fR⋅kT⋅mAA/(ς⋅mR)\begin{document}$\lambda =f_{\text{R}}\cdot k_{\text{T}}\cdot m_{\text{AA}} \big/\left (\varsigma \cdot m_{\text{R}}\right)$\end{document}, and the total protein mass of the cell population Mprotein≡∑iQ,R,CMi(P)\begin{document}$M_{\text{protein}}\equiv \sum \limits_{i}^{\text{Q,R,C}}M_{i}^{\left (\text{P}\right)}$\end{document} follows:(S3)Mprotein(t)=Mprotein(0)+MR(0)⋅[exp(λ⋅t)−1]/fR\begin{document}$$M_{\text{protein}}\left (t\right)=M_{\text{protein}}\left (0\right)+M_{\text{R}}\left (0\right)\cdot \left [{\rm{exp}}\left (\lambda \cdot t\right)- 1\right ] \big/f_{\text{R}}$$\end{document}

Over a long period in the exponential growth phase (i.e. t→+∞\begin{document}$t\rightarrow +\infty $\end{document}), we have ϕi=fi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}=f_{i}$\end{document} (i=Q,R,C)\begin{document}$\left (i={\rm{Q, R, C}}\right)$\end{document}, and(S4)λ=ϕR⋅κt,\begin{document}$$\lambda =\phi _{\rm{R}}\cdot \kappa _{\rm{t}},$$\end{document}
where κt=kT⋅mAA/(ς⋅mR).\begin{document}$\kappa _{\text{t}}=k_{\text{T}}\cdot m_{\text{AA}} \big/\left (\varsigma \cdot m_{\text{R}}\right).$\end{document}

sec.title: 2.2 Precursor pools
sec.p: Based on the entry points of the metabolic network, we classify the precursors of biomass components into five pools (Figure 1A and B): a1 (entry point: G6P/F6P), a2 (entry point: GA3P/3PG/PEP), b (entry point: pyruvate/acetyl-CoA), c (entry point: α-ketoglutarate), and d (entry point: oxaloacetate). These five pools draw approximately ra1=24%\begin{document}$r_{\text{a1}}=24\% $\end{document}, ra2=24%\begin{document}$r_{\text{a2}}=24\% $\end{document}, rb=28%\begin{document}$r_{\text{b}}=28\% $\end{document}, rc=12%\begin{document}$r_{\text{c}}=12\% $\end{document}, and rd=12%\begin{document}$r_{\text{d}}=12\% $\end{document} of the carbon flux (Nelson and Cox, 2008; Wang et al., 2019). There are overlapping components between Pools a1 and a2 due to the joint synthesis of some precursors. Therefore, we use Pool a to represent both Pools a1 and a2 in the descriptions.

sec.title: 2.3 Stoichiometric flux
sec.p: We consider the following biochemical reaction between substrate Si\begin{document}$S_{i}$\end{document} and enzyme Ei\begin{document}$E_{i}$\end{document}:(S5)Ei+Si⇌diaiEi⋅Si→kicatEi+bi⋅Si+1+ci⋅CO2,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle E_{i}+S_{i} \xrightleftharpoons[{d_{i}}]{a_{i}}E_{i}\cdot S_{i}\xrightarrow[]{{k ^{\rm{cat}}_{i}}}E_{i}+b_{i}\cdot S_{i+1}+c_{i}\cdot \text{CO}_{\text{2}},$$\end{document}

where ai\begin{document}$a_{i}$\end{document}, di\begin{document}$d_{i}$\end{document} and kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} are the reaction parameters, Si+1\begin{document}$S_{i+1}$\end{document} is the product, bi\begin{document}$b_{i}$\end{document} and ci\begin{document}$c_{i}$\end{document} are the stoichiometric coefficients. For most of the reactions in the central metabolism, bi=1\begin{document}$b_{i}=1$\end{document} and ci=0\begin{document}$c_{i}=0$\end{document}. The reaction rate follows Michaelis–Menten kinetics (Nelson and Cox, 2008):(S6)vi=kicat⋅[Ei]⋅[Si][Si]+Ki,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle v_{i}=k_{i}^{\text{cat}}\cdot \left [E_{i}\right ]\cdot \frac{\left [S_{i}\right ]}{\left [S_{i}\right ]+K_{i}},$$\end{document}

where Ki≡(di+kicat)/ai\begin{document}$K_{i}\equiv \left (d_{i}\text{+}k_{i}^{\text{cat}}\right)\big/a_{i}$\end{document}, [Ei]\begin{document}$\left [E_{i}\right ]$\end{document} and [Si]\begin{document}$\left [S_{i}\right ]$\end{document} are the Michaelis constant, and the concentrations of enzyme Ei\begin{document}$E_{i}$\end{document} and substrate Si\begin{document}$S_{i}$\end{document}, respectively. For this reaction (Equation S5), d[Si+1]/dt=bi⋅vi\begin{document}$d\left [S_{i+1}\right] \big/dt=b_{i}\cdot v_{i}$\end{document} and d[Si]/dt=−vi\begin{document}$d\left [S_{i}\right] \big/dt=- v_{i}$\end{document}. In the cell population (the ‘big cell’), suppose that the cell volume is Vcell\begin{document}$V_{\text{cell}}$\end{document}, then the stoichiometric flux of the reaction is:(S7)Ji≡Vcell⋅vi.\begin{document}$$J_{i}\equiv V_{\text{cell}}\cdot v_{i}.$$\end{document}

The copy number of enzyme Ei\begin{document}$E_{i}$\end{document} is NEi=Vcell⋅[Ei]\begin{document}$N_{E_{i}}=V_{\text{cell}}\cdot \left [E_{i}\right]$\end{document} with a total weight of MEi=NEi⋅mEi\begin{document}$M_{E_{i}}=N_{E_{i}}\cdot m_{E_{i}}$\end{document}, where mEi\begin{document}$m_{E_{i}}$\end{document} is the molecular weight of Ei\begin{document}$E_{i}$\end{document}. By defining the enzyme cost of an Ei\begin{document}$E_{i}$\end{document} molecule as nEi≡mEi/m0\begin{document}$n_{E_{i}}\equiv m_{E_{i}}/m_{0}$\end{document}, where m0\begin{document}$m_{0}$\end{document} is a unit mass, then the cost of all Ei\begin{document}$E_{i}$\end{document} molecules is Φi≡NEi⋅nEi\begin{document}$\Phi _{i}\equiv N_{E_{i}}\cdot n_{E_{i}}$\end{document} (Wang et al., 2019). By further defining ξi≡kicatnEi⋅[Si][Si]+Ki\begin{document}$\xi _{i}\equiv \frac{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}{n_{E_{i}}}\cdot \frac{\left [S_{i}\right ]}{\left [S_{i}\right ]+K_{i}}$\end{document}, then:(S8)Ji=Φi⋅ξi.\begin{document}$$J_{i}=\Phi _{i}\cdot \xi _{i}.$$\end{document}

The mass fraction of enzyme Ei\begin{document}$E_{i}$\end{document} in the proteome is ϕi=MEi/Mprotein\begin{document}$\phi _{i}=M_{E_{i}} \big/M_{\text{protein}}$\end{document}, and thus:(S9)ϕi=Φi⋅m0Mprotein.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \phi _{i}=\Phi _{i}\cdot \frac{m_{0}}{M_{\text{protein}}}.$$\end{document}

sec.title: 2.4 Carbon flux and cell growth rate
sec.p: To clarify the relation between the stoichiometric flux Ji\begin{document}$J_{i}$\end{document} and growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document}, we consider the carbon flux in the biomass production. The carbon mass of the cell population (the ‘big cell’) is given by Mcarbon=Mprotein⋅rcarbon/rprotein\begin{document}$M_{\text{carbon}}=M_{\text{protein}}\cdot r_{\text{carbon}}{\big /}r_{\text{protein}}$\end{document} , where rcarbon\begin{document}$r_{\text{carbon}}$\end{document} and rprotein\begin{document}$r_{\text{protein}}$\end{document} represent the mass fraction of carbon and protein within a cell. In the exponential growth phase, the carbon flux of the biomass production is given by:(S10)JBM=1mcarbon⋅dMcarbondt=λ⋅Mcarbonmcarbon,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle J_{\text{BM}}=\frac{1}{m_{\text{carbon}}}\cdot \frac{dM_{\text{carbon}}}{dt}=\lambda \cdot \frac{M_{\text{carbon}}}{m_{\text{carbon}}},$$\end{document}

where mcarbon\begin{document}$m_{\text{carbon}}$\end{document} is the mass of a carbon atom. In fact, the carbon mass flux per stoichiometry varies depending on the entry point of the precursor pool. Taking Pool b as an example, there are three carbon atoms in a molecule of the entry point metabolite (i.e. pyruvate). Assuming that carbon atoms are conserved from pyruvate to Pool b, then the carbon flux of Pool b is given by Jbcarbon=Jb⋅Npycarbon\begin{document}$J_{b}^{\text{carbon}}=J_{b}\cdot N_{\text{py}}^{\text{carbon}}$\end{document}, where Jb\begin{document}$J_{b}$\end{document} is the stoichiometric flux from pyruvate to Pool b (Figure 1A and B) and Npycarbon\begin{document}$N_{\text{py}}^{\text{carbon}}$\end{document} stands for the carbon number of a pyruvate molecule. Combining with Equation S10 and noting that Jbcarbon=rb⋅JBM\begin{document}$J_{b}^{\text{carbon}}=r_{b}\cdot J_{\text{BM}}$\end{document}, we get Jb⋅Npycarbon⋅mcarbon=rb⋅λ⋅Mcarbon\begin{document}$J_{b}\cdot N_{\text{py}}^{\text{carbon}}\cdot m_{\text{carbon}}=r_{b}\cdot \lambda \cdot M_{\text{carbon}}$\end{document}. Similarly, for each precursor pool, we have:(S11)Ji⋅NEPicarbon⋅mcarbon=ri⋅λ⋅Mcarbon(i=a1,a2,b,c,d),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle J_i\cdot N_{{\text{EP}_{i}}}^{\rm carbon}\cdot m_{\text{carbon}}=r_{i}\cdot \lambda \cdot M_{\text{carbon}}\qquad (i=a1, a2, b, c, d),$$\end{document}

where the subscript ‘EPi\begin{document}$\mathrm{EP}_i$\end{document}’ represents the entry point of Pool i, and NEPi\begin{document}$N_{{\text{EP}_{i}}}$\end{document} is the number of carbon atoms in a molecule of the entry-point metabolite.

For each substrate in intermediate steps of the metabolic network, we define κi\begin{document}$\kappa _i$\end{document} as the substrate quality:(S12)κi≡ξi⋅rproteinrcarbon=rproteinrcarbon⋅kicatnEi⋅[Si][Si]+Ki,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \kappa _{i}\equiv \xi _{i}\cdot \frac{r_{\text{protein}}}{r_{\text{carbon}}}=\frac{r_{\text{protein}}}{r_{\text{carbon}}}\cdot \frac{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}{n_{E_{i}}}\cdot \frac{\left [S_{i}\right ]}{\left [S_{i}\right ]+K_{i}},$$\end{document}

and for each precursor pool, we define:(S13)ηi≡ri⋅m0/(NEPicarbon⋅mcarbon)(i=a1,a2,b,c,d).\begin{document}$$\eta _i\equiv {r_i\cdot m_0} \big/{(N_{\rm EP_{i}}^{\rm carbon}\cdot m_{\rm carbon})}\,\,\,\,\,\,(i=a1, a2, b,c, d).$$\end{document}
Combining Equations S8, S9 and S11, we have(S14)ϕ⋅κi=ηi⋅λ(i=a1,a2,b,c,d).\begin{document}$$\phi \cdot \kappa _{i}=\eta_{i} \cdot \lambda \qquad \left (i=a1, a2,b,c,d\right).$$\end{document}

Then, we define the normalized flux, which can be regarded as the flux per unit of biomass:(S15)Ji(N)≡ϕi⋅κi,\begin{document}$$J_{i}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\equiv \phi _{i}\cdot \kappa _{i},$$\end{document}

where the superscript ‘(N)’ stands for normalized. Combined with Equations S8, S9 and S12, we have:(S16)Ji(N)≡Ji⋅m0Mcarbon.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle J_{i}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\equiv J_{i}\cdot \frac{m_{\text{0}}}{M_{\text{carbon}}}.$$\end{document}

Since ∑ia1,a2,b,c,dri=1\begin{document}$\sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}r_{i}=1$\end{document}, by setting(S17)m0=[∑iri/NEPicarbon]−1⋅mcarbon,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle m_{0}=\left [\underset{i}{\sum }r_{i} \big/N_{\text{EP}_{i}}^{\text{carbon}}\right ]^{- 1}\cdot m_{\text{carbon}},$$\end{document}

we then obtain:(S18)ηi=riNEPicarbon⋅[∑ja1,a2,b,c,drjNEPjcarbon]−1(i=a1,a2,b,c,d),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \eta _i=\frac{r_{i}}{N^{\rm carbon}_{\text{EP}_{i}}}\cdot \left[\sum\limits_{j}^{a1, a2, b, c,d}{\frac{r_{j}}{N^{\rm carbon}_{\text{EP}_{j}}} } \right]^{-1} \qquad (i=a1, a2, b,c,d),$$\end{document}

and we have ∑ia1,a2,b,c,dηi=1\begin{document}$\sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}\eta _{i}=1$\end{document}, and(S19)∑ia1,a2,b,c,dϕi⋅κi=λ.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}\phi _{i}\cdot \kappa _{i}=\lambda.$$\end{document}

sec.title: 2.5 Intermediate nodes
sec.p: In a metabolic network, the metabolites between the carbon source and precursor pools are referred to as intermediate nodes. As specified by Wang et al., 2019, to optimize cell growth rate, the substrate of each intermediate node is nearly saturated, and thus:(S20)κi≈rproteinrcarbon⋅kicatnEi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \kappa _{i}\approx \frac{r_{\text{protein}}}{r_{\text{carbon}}}\cdot \frac{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}{n_{E_{i}}}$$\end{document}

Real cases could be more complicated due to other forms of metabolic regulations. Recent quantitative studies (Bennett et al., 2009; Park et al., 2016) have shown that, at least in E. coli, for most of the substrate-enzyme pairs, Ki\begin{document}$K_{i}$\end{document} is lower than the substrate concentration (i.e. [Si]>Ki\begin{document}$\left [S_{i}\right ] \gt K_{i}$\end{document}), which implies κi≈rproteinrcarbon⋅kicatnEi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}\approx \frac{r_{\text{protein}}}{r_{\text{carbon}}}\cdot \frac{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}{n_{E_{i}}}$\end{document}.

sec.title: 3.1 Coarse-grained model
sec.p: In the coarse-grained model shown in Figure 1B, node A represents an arbitrary carbon source of Group A (Wang et al., 2019), which joins at the upper part of glycolysis. Nodes M1, M2, M3, M4, and M5 stand for G6P, PEP, acetyl-CoA, α-ketoglutarate, and oxaloacetate, respectively. In the analysis of carbon supply into precursor pools, we lump sum G6P/F6P as M1, GA3P/3PG/PEP as M2, and pyruvate/acetyl-CoA as M3 for approximation. For the biochemical reactions, each follows Equation S5 with bi=1\begin{document}$b_{i}=1$\end{document} except for M1→2M2 and M3 +M5→M4. Basically, there are three independent possible fates for a Group A carbon source (e.g. glucose; see Appendix 1—figure 1C-E; Chen and Nielsen, 2019): energy biogenesis through fermentation; energy biogenesis via respiration (Appendix 1—figure 1C and D), or conversion into biomass components accompanied by energy biogenesis in the biomass pathway. Each fate involves a distinct fraction of the proteome, with no overlap between them (Appendix 1—figure 1).

By applying flux balance to the stoichiometric fluxes and combining with Equation S8, we have:(S21){ΦA⋅ξA=Φ1⋅ξ1+Φa1⋅ξa1,2Φ1⋅ξ1=Φ2⋅ξ2+Φ5⋅ξ5+Φa2⋅ξa2,Φ2⋅ξ2=Φ3⋅ξ3+Φ6⋅ξ6+Φb⋅ξb,Φ5⋅ξ5+Φ4⋅ξ4=Φ3⋅ξ3+Φd⋅ξd,Φ3⋅ξ3=Φ4⋅ξ4+Φc⋅ξc.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\Phi _A} \cdot {\xi _A} = {\Phi _1} \cdot {\xi _1} + {\Phi _{a1}} \cdot {\xi _{a1}},\\ 2{\Phi _1} \cdot {\xi _1} = {\Phi _2} \cdot {\xi _2} + {\Phi _5} \cdot {\xi _5} + {\Phi _{a2}} \cdot {\xi _{a2}},\\ {\Phi _2} \cdot {\xi _2} = {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} + {\Phi _6} \cdot {\xi _6} + {\Phi _b} \cdot {\xi _b},\\ {\Phi _5} \cdot {\xi _5} + {\Phi _4} \cdot {\xi _4} = {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} + {\Phi _d} \cdot {\xi _d},\\ {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} = {\Phi _4} \cdot {\xi _4} + {\Phi _c} \cdot {\xi _c}. \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

Obviously, the stoichiometric fluxes of respiration Jr\begin{document}$J_{r}$\end{document} and fermentation Jf\begin{document}$J_{f}$\end{document} (Appendix 1—figure 1C and D) are:(S22){Jr≡J4=Φ4⋅ξ4,Jf≡J6=Φ6⋅ξ6.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} {J_r} \equiv {J_4} = {\Phi _4} \cdot {\xi _4},\\ {J_f} \equiv {J_6} = {\Phi _6} \cdot {\xi _6}. \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

We further assume that the carbon atoms are conserved from each entry point metabolite to the precursor pool, and then,(S23)Φi⋅ξi⋅NEPicarbon=ri⋅JBM(i=a1,a2,b,c,d).\begin{document}$$\Phi _{i}\cdot \xi _{i}\cdot N_{\text {EP}_{i}}^\text{carbon}=r_{i}\cdot J_\text {BM}\,\,\,\,\,\,\left (i=a1,a2,b,c,d\right).$$\end{document}

In terms of energy biogenesis for the relevant reactions, for convenience, we convert all the energy currencies into ATPs, namely, NADH→2ATP (Neidhardt et al., 1990), NADPH→2ATP (Neidhardt et al., 1990; Sauer et al., 2004), FADH2→1ATP (Neidhardt et al., 1990). Then, we have(S24)β1⋅Φ1⋅ξ1+β2⋅Φ2⋅ξ2+β3⋅Φ3⋅ξ3+β4⋅Φ4⋅ξ4+β6⋅Φ6⋅ξ6+βa1⋅Φa1⋅ξa1=JE,\begin{document}$$\beta _{1}\cdot \Phi _{1}\cdot \xi _{1}+\beta _{2}\cdot \Phi _{2}\cdot \xi _{2}+\beta _{3}\cdot \Phi _{3}\cdot \xi _{3}+\beta _{4}\cdot \Phi _{4}\cdot \xi _{4}+\beta _{6}\cdot \Phi _{6}\cdot \xi _{6}+\beta _{a1}\cdot \Phi _{a1}\cdot \xi _{a1}=J_{\text{E}},$$\end{document}

where JE\begin{document}$J_{\text{E}}$\end{document} represents the energy demand for cell proliferation, expressed as the stoichiometric energy flux in ATP. βi\begin{document}$\beta _{i}$\end{document} is the stoichiometric coefficient with β1=4\begin{document}$\beta _{1}=4$\end{document}, β2=3\begin{document}$\beta _{2}=3$\end{document}, β3=2\begin{document}$\beta _{3}=2$\end{document}, β4=6\begin{document}$\beta _{4}=6$\end{document}, β6=1\begin{document}$\beta _{6}=1$\end{document}, and βa1=4\begin{document}$\beta _{a1}=4$\end{document} for E. coli (Neidhardt et al., 1990; Sauer et al., 2004). For bacteria, the energy demand is generally proportional to the carbon flux infused into biomass production, as the proportion of maintenance energy is roughly negligible (Locasale and Cantley, 2010). Thus,(S25)JE=rE⋅JBM,\begin{document}$$J_{\text{E}}=r_{\text{E}}\cdot J_{\text{BM}},$$\end{document}
where rE\begin{document}$r_{\text{E}}$\end{document} is the ratio and also a constant.

By applying the substitutions specified in Equations S9, S12, S14-S18, combined with Equations S4, S10, S21-S25, and the constraint of proteome resource allocation ϕR+ϕC=ϕmax\begin{document}$\phi _{\text{R}}+\phi _{\text{C}}=\phi _\rm{max}$\end{document}, we have:(S26){ϕA⋅κA=ϕ1⋅κ1+ϕa1⋅κa1,2ϕ1⋅κ1=ϕ2⋅κ2+ϕ5⋅κ5+ϕa2⋅κa2,ϕ2⋅κ2=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕ6⋅κ6+ϕb⋅κb,ϕ5⋅κ5+ϕ4⋅κ4=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕd⋅κd,ϕ3⋅κ3=ϕ4⋅κ4+ϕc⋅κc,ϕa1⋅κa1=ηa1⋅λ,ϕa2⋅κa2=ηa2⋅λ,ϕb⋅κb=ηb⋅λ,ϕc⋅κc=ηc⋅λ,ϕd⋅κd=ηd⋅λ,β1⋅ϕ1⋅κ1+β2⋅ϕ2⋅κ2+β3⋅ϕ3⋅κ3+β4⋅ϕ4⋅κ4+β6⋅ϕ6⋅κ6+βa1⋅ϕa1⋅κa1=JE(N),JE(N)=ηE⋅λ,λ=ϕR⋅κt,Jr(N)=ϕ4⋅κ4,Jf(N)=ϕ6⋅κ6,ϕR+ϕA+ϕ1+ϕ2+ϕ3+ϕ4+ϕ5+ϕ6+ϕa1+ϕa2+ϕb+ϕc+ϕd=ϕmax,\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}\phi _{A}\cdot \kappa _{A}=\phi _{1}\cdot \kappa _{1}+\phi _{a1}\cdot \kappa _{a1},\\2\phi _{1}\cdot \kappa _{1}=\phi _{2}\cdot \kappa _{2}+\phi _{5}\cdot \kappa _{5}+\phi _{a2}\cdot \kappa _{a2},\\\phi _{2}\cdot \kappa _{2}=\phi _{3}\cdot \kappa _{3}+\phi _{6}\cdot \kappa _{6}+\phi _{b}\cdot \kappa _{b},\\\phi _{5}\cdot \kappa _{5}+\phi _{4}\cdot \kappa _{4}=\phi _{3}\cdot \kappa _{3}+\phi _{d}\cdot \kappa _{d},\\\phi _{3}\cdot \kappa _{3}=\phi _{4}\cdot \kappa _{4}+\phi _{c}\cdot \kappa _{c},\\\phi _{a1}\cdot \kappa _{a1}=\eta _{a1}\cdot \lambda ,\phi _{a2}\cdot \kappa _{a2}=\eta _{a2}\cdot \lambda ,\phi _{b}\cdot \kappa _{b}=\eta _{b}\cdot \lambda ,\phi _{c}\cdot \kappa _{c}=\eta _{c}\cdot \lambda ,\phi _{d}\cdot \kappa _{d}=\eta _{d}\cdot \lambda ,\\\beta _{1}\cdot \phi _{1}\cdot \kappa _{1}+\beta _{2}\cdot \phi _{2}\cdot \kappa _{2}+\beta _{3}\cdot \phi _{3}\cdot \kappa _{3}+\beta _{4}\cdot \phi _{4}\cdot \kappa _{4}+\beta _{6}\cdot \phi _{6}\cdot \kappa _{6}+\beta _{a1}\cdot \phi _{a1}\cdot \kappa _{a1}=J_{\text{E}}^{\left (\text{N}\right)},\\J_{\text{E}}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}=\eta _{\text{E}}\cdot \lambda ,\lambda =\phi _{R}\cdot \kappa _{\rm t},J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}=\phi _{4}\cdot \kappa _{4},J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}=\phi _{6}\cdot \kappa _{6},\\\phi _{\text{R}}+\phi _{A}+\phi _{1}+\phi _{2}+\phi _{3}+\phi _{4}+\phi _{5}+\phi _{6}+\phi _{a1}+\phi _{a2}+\phi _{b}+\phi _{c}+\phi _{d}=\phi _{\rm max},\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

where JE(N)\begin{document}$J_{\text{E}}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} and ηE\begin{document}$\eta _{\text{E}}$\end{document} are defined as JE(N)≡JE⋅m0Mcarbon\begin{document}$J_{\text{E}}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\equiv J_{\text{E}}\cdot \frac{m_{\text{0}}}{M_{\text{carbon}}}$\end{document} and ηE≡rE⋅[∑iri/NEPicarbon]−1\begin{document}$\eta _{\text{E}}\equiv r_{\text{E}}\cdot \left [\underset{i}{\sum }r_{i} \big/N_{\text{EP}_{i}}^{\text{carbon}}\right]^{- 1}$\end{document}, respectively. Here, for each intermediate node, κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} follows Equation S20, which can be approximated as a constant. The substrate quality of the Group A carbon source κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} varies with the identity and concentration of the Group A carbon source:(S27)κA≡rproteinrcarbon⋅kAcatmEA⋅[A][A]+KA⋅m0,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \kappa _{A}\equiv \frac{r_{\text{protein}}}{r_{\text{carbon}}}\cdot \frac{k_{A}^{\text{cat}}}{m_{E_{A}}}\cdot \frac{\left [A\right ]}{\left [A\right ]+K_{A}}\cdot m_{0},$$\end{document}

which is determined externally by the culture condition. From Equation S26, all ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} and ϕR\begin{document}$\phi _{\text{R}}$\end{document} can be expressed in terms of Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, and λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document}:(S28){ϕA=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(2ηa1+ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)⋅λ]/(2⋅κA),ϕ1=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)⋅λ]/(2⋅κ1),ϕ2=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(ηb+ηc)⋅λ]/κ2,ϕ3=(Jr(N)+ηc⋅λ)/κ3,ϕ4=Jr(N)/κ4,ϕ5=(ηc+ηd)⋅λ/κ5,ϕ6=Jf(N)/κ6,ϕR=λ/κt,ϕi=ηi⋅λ/κi(i=a1,a2,b,c,d).\begin{document}$$\left\{\begin{aligned}\phi _{A} &=\left[J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+\left (2\eta _{a1}+\eta _{a2}+\eta _{b}+2\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}\right) \cdot \lambda \right]\big/\left (2\cdot \kappa _{A}\right),\\[1pt]\phi _{1} &=\left[J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+\left (\eta _{a2}+\eta _{b}+2\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}\right)\cdot \lambda \right] \big/\left (2\cdot \kappa _{1}\right),\\[1pt]\phi _{2} &=\left[J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+\left (\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}\right)\cdot \lambda \right] \big/\kappa _{2},\\[1pt]\phi _{3} &=\left (J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+\eta _{c}\cdot \lambda \right) \big/\kappa _{3},\phi _{4}=J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} \big/\kappa _{4},\\[1pt]\phi _{5} &=\left (\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}\right)\cdot \lambda \big/\kappa _{5},\phi _{6}=J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} \big/\kappa _{6},\phi _{R}=\lambda \big/\kappa _{\rm t},\\[1pt]\phi _{i} &=\eta _{i}\cdot \lambda \big/\kappa _{i}\quad \left (i=a1,\text a2,\text b,\text c,\text d\right).\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

In Equation S28, for each ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} or ϕR\begin{document}$\phi _{\text{R}}$\end{document}, the Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}- and Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}-related proteome fraction terms belong to the fractions of the proteome dedicated to respiration (denoted as ϕr\begin{document}$\phi _{r}$\end{document}) and fermentation (denoted as ϕf\begin{document}$\phi _{f}$\end{document}), respectively. The λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document}-related proteome fraction terms belong to those involved in the biomass synthesis pathway (denoted as ϕBM\begin{document}$\phi _{\text{BM}}$\end{document}). Thus, ϕr=Jr(N)⋅[1/(2⋅κA)\begin{document}$\phi _{r}=J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\cdot \big[1 \big/\left (2\cdot \kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document} +1/(2⋅κ1)\begin{document}$+1 \big/\left (2\cdot \kappa _{1}\right)$\end{document} +1/κ2\begin{document}$+1 \big/\kappa _{2}$\end{document} +1/κ3\begin{document}$+1 \big/\kappa _{3} $\end{document} +1/κ4]\begin{document}$+1 \big/\kappa _{4}\big]$\end{document}, ϕf=Jf(N)⋅\begin{document}$\phi _{f}=J_{f}^{(\text{N})}\cdot$\end{document} [1/(2⋅κA)\begin{document}$\big[1 \big/\left (2\cdot \kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document} +1/(2⋅κ1)\begin{document}$+1 \big/\left (2\cdot \kappa _{1}\right)$\end{document} +1/κ2\begin{document}$+1 \big/\kappa _{2}$\end{document} +1/κ6]\begin{document}$+1 \big/\kappa _{6}\big]$\end{document}, and ϕBM=λ⋅(1κt\begin{document}$\phi _{\text{BM}}=\lambda \cdot \bigg(\frac{1}{\kappa _{\rm{t}}}$\end{document} +1+ηa1+ηc2κA\begin{document}$+\frac{1+\eta _{a1}+\eta _{c}}{2\kappa _{A}}$\end{document} +1−ηa1+ηc2κ1\begin{document}$+\frac{1- \eta _{a1}+\eta _{c}}{2\kappa _{1}}$\end{document} +ηb+ηcκ2\begin{document}$+\frac{\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{2}}$\end{document} +ηcκ3\begin{document}$+\frac{\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{3}}$\end{document} +ηc+ηdκ5\begin{document}$+\frac{\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}}{\kappa _{5}}$\end{document} +∑ia1,a2,b,c,dηiκi)\begin{document}$+\sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}\frac{\eta _{i}}{\kappa _{i}}\bigg)$\end{document}. By substituting Equation S28 into Equation S26, we have:(S29){Jr(E)+Jf(E)=φ⋅λ,Jr(E)εr+Jf(E)εf=ϕmax−ψ⋅λ.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_r^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)} + J^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)}_f = \varphi \cdot \lambda ,\\[1pt] &\displaystyle \frac{{J_r^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)}}}{{{\varepsilon _r}}} + \frac{{J^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)}_f}}{{{\varepsilon _f}}} = {\phi _{\max }} - \psi \cdot \lambda . \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

Here, Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} and Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} stand for the normalized energy fluxes of respiration and fermentation, with(S30){Jr(E)=βr(A)⋅Jr(N)/2,Jf(E)=βf(A)⋅Jf(N)/2,\begin{document}$$\left\{\begin{array}{ll}J_{r}^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)} = \beta _r^{\left( A \right)} \cdot J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} \big/2,\\J_{f}^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)} = \beta _f^{\left( A \right)} \cdot J_f^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} \big/2, \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

where βr(A)=β1+2(β2+β3+β4)\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}=\beta _{1}+2\left (\beta _{2}+\beta _{3}+\beta _{4}\right)$\end{document} and βf(A)=β1+2(β2+β6)\begin{document}$\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}=\beta _{1}+2\left (\beta _{2}+\beta _{6}\right)$\end{document}, with βr(A)=26\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}=26$\end{document} and βf(A)=12\begin{document}$\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}=12$\end{document} for E. coli. εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document} represent the proteome efficiencies for energy biogenesis in the respiration and fermentation pathways (Appendix 1—figure 1C-D), defined as εr≡Jr(E)/ϕr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\equiv J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)} \big/\phi _{r}$\end{document} and εf≡Jf(E)/ϕf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}\equiv J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)} \big/\phi _{f}$\end{document}; that is, the normalized energy fluxes expressed in ATP generated per proteomic mass fraction dedicated to respiration and fermentation, respectively. Hence,(S31){εr=βr(A)1/κA+1/κ1+2/κ2+2/κ3+2/κ4,εf=βf(A)1/κA+1/κ1+2/κ2+2/κ6.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{ll}\varepsilon _{r} &= \displaystyle \frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}{1 \big/\kappa _{A}+1 \big/\kappa _{1}+2 \big/\kappa _{2}+2 \big/\kappa _{3}+2 \big/\kappa _{4}},\\[1pt ]\varepsilon_{f}&= \displaystyle \frac{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}{1 \big/\kappa _{A}+1 \big/\kappa _{1}+2 \big/\kappa _{2}+2 \big/\kappa _{6}}.\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

ψ−1\begin{document}$\psi ^{- 1}$\end{document} is the proteome efficiency for biomass generation in the biomass synthesis pathway (Appendix 1—figure 1E), defined as ψ−1≡λ/ϕBM=∑ia1,a2,b,c,dJi(N)/ϕBM\begin{document}$\psi ^{- 1}\equiv \lambda \big/\phi _{\text{BM}}=\sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}J_{i}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} \big/\phi _{\text{BM}}$\end{document} (see Equations S15 and S19); that is, the normalized flux (which differs from the normalized energy flux used to define εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}) generated per proteomic mass fraction dedicated to biomass synthesis. Hence(S32)ψ=1κt+1+ηa1+ηc2κA+ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd2κ1+ηb+ηcκ2+ηcκ3+ηc+ηdκ5+∑ia1,a2,b,c,dηiκi.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \psi =\frac{1}{\kappa _{\rm{t}}}+\frac{1+\eta _{a1}+\eta _{c}}{2\kappa _{A}}+\frac{\eta _{a2}+\eta _{b}+2\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}}{2\kappa _{1}}+\frac{\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{2}}+\frac{\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{3}}+\frac{\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}}{\kappa _{5}}+\sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}\frac{\eta _{i}}{\kappa _{i}}.$$\end{document}

φ\begin{document}$\varphi $\end{document} is an energy demand coefficient (a constant), with(S33)φ≡ηE−β1⋅(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)/2−β2⋅(ηb+ηc)−β3⋅ηc−βa1⋅ηa1,\begin{document}$$\varphi \equiv \eta _{\text{E}}- \beta _{1}\cdot \left (\eta _{a2}+\eta _{b}+2\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}\right) \big/2- \beta _{2}\cdot \left (\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}\right)- \beta _{3}\cdot \eta _{c}- \beta _{a1}\cdot \eta _{a1},$$\end{document}
and φ⋅λ\begin{document}$\varphi \cdot \lambda $\end{document} stands for the normalized flux of energy demand other than the accompanying energy biogenesis from the biomass synthesis pathway.

sec.title: 3.2 The reason for overflow metabolism
sec.p: Microbes optimize their growth rate to survive through the evolutionary process (Vander Heiden et al., 2009). The optimal growth principle also roughly holds for tumor cells, which proliferate while ignoring growth restriction signals and evading immune destruction by the host (Vander Heiden et al., 2009). First, we consider the optimal growth strategy for a single cell. The coarse-grained model for bacteria is summarized in Equation S26 and further simplified in Equation S29. Here, εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document}, εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document} and ψ\begin{document}$\psi $\end{document} are functions of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} (see Equations S31, S32), so we also denote them as εr(κA)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document}, εf(κA)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document}, ψ(κA)\begin{document}$\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document}. Evidently, the fluxes of both respiration and fermentation take non-negative values, i.e., Jr(E),Jf(E)≥0\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)},J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\geq 0$\end{document}, and all the coefficients are positive: εr(κA),εf(κA),ψ(κA),φ>0\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right),\varphi \gt 0$\end{document}.

Thus, if εr>εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r} \gt \varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, then (ψ+φ/εr)⋅λ=ϕmax−Jf(E)(1/εf−1/εr)≤ϕmax\begin{document}$\left (\psi +\varphi {\big /}\varepsilon _{r}\right)\cdot \lambda =\phi _{\rm{max}}- J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (1{\big /}\varepsilon _{f}- 1{\big /}\varepsilon _{r}\right)\leq \phi _{\rm{max}}$\end{document}. Obviously, the solution for optimal growth is:(S34){Jf(E)=0,Jr(E)=φ⋅λ.εr>εf.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} J_{f}^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)} = 0,\\ J_r^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)} = \varphi \cdot \lambda . \end{array} \right.\qquad{\varepsilon _r} > {\varepsilon _f}. $$\end{document}

Similarly, if εf>εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f} \gt \varepsilon _{r}$\end{document}, then the optimal growth solution is:(S35){Jf(E)=φ⋅λ,Jr(E)=0.εr<εf.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} J_{f}^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)} = \varphi \cdot \lambda ,\\ J_r^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)} = 0. \end{array} \right.\qquad {\varepsilon _r} < {\varepsilon _f}. $$\end{document}

In both cases, the growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} takes the maximum value for a given nutrient condition (i.e. given κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}):(S36)λ={λr=ϕmaxφ/εr(κA)+ψ(κA)εr(κA)>εf(κA),λf=ϕmaxφ/εf(κA)+ψ(κA)εr(κA)<εf(κA).\begin{document}$$\lambda =\left \{\begin{aligned}\lambda _{r} &= \displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\quad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\\[1pt]\lambda _{f} &= \displaystyle\frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\quad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right).\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

So, why do microbes use the seemingly wasteful fermentation pathway when the growth rate is large under aerobic conditions? Prevalent explanations (Basan et al., 2015; Chen and Nielsen, 2019) suggest that it originates from that the proteome efficiency in fermentation is consistently higher than in respiration (i.e. εf>εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f} \gt \varepsilon _{r}$\end{document}). If this is the case, why do microbes still use the normal respiration pathway when the growth rate is small? The answer lies in the fact that both εr(κA)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document} and εf(κA)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document} are not constants, but are dependent on nutrient conditions. In Equation S31, when κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} is small, consider the extreme case of κA→0\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0$\end{document}, and then(S37){εr(κA→0)≈βr(A)⋅κA,εf(κA→0)≈βf(A)⋅κA.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right)\approx \beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}\cdot \kappa _{A},\\\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right)\approx \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}\cdot \kappa _{A}.\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

Since βr(A)≫βf(A)\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}\gg \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}$\end{document}, clearly,(S38)εr(κA→0)>εf(κA→0).\begin{document}$$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right).$$\end{document}

Combined with Equation S36, thus cells would certainly use the respiration pathway when the growth rate is very small. Meanwhile, suppose that κAmax\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^\rm{max}$\end{document} is the maximum value of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} available across different Group A carbon sources, and if there exists a κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} (with κA≤κAmax\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}\leq \kappa _{A}^\rm{max}$\end{document}) satisfying εr(κA)<εf(κA)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document}, specifically,(S39)βr(A)−βf(A)κA<βf(A)(1κ1+2κ2+2κ3+2κ4)−βr(A)⋅(1κ1+2κ2+2κ6),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}- \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}{\kappa _{A}} \lt \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}\left (\frac{1}{\kappa _{1}}+\frac{2}{\kappa _{2}}+\frac{2}{\kappa _{3}}+\frac{2}{\kappa _{4}}\right)- \beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}\cdot \left (\frac{1}{\kappa _{1}}+\frac{2}{\kappa _{2}}+\frac{2}{\kappa _{6}}\right),$$\end{document}

then Δ(κA)≡εf(κA)/εr(κA)\begin{document}$\Delta \left (\kappa _{A}\right)\equiv \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document} is a monotonically increasing function of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}. Thus,(S40)εr(κAmax)<εf(κAmax),\begin{document}$$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right),$$\end{document}
and cells would use the fermentation pathway when the growth rate is large.

In practice, experimental studies using E. coli (Basan et al., 2015) have demonstrated that proteome efficiency in fermentation is higher than in respiration when the Group A carbon source is lactose at a saturated concentration, i.e., εr(κlactose(ST))<εf(κlactose(ST))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{\text{lactose}}^{(\text{ST})}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{\text{lactose}}^{(\text{ST})}\right)$\end{document}. Here, κlactose(ST)\begin{document}$\kappa _{\text{lactose}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}$\end{document} represents the substrate quality of lactose and the superscript ‘(ST)’ signifies saturated concentration. In fact, E. coli grows much faster in G6p than lactose (Basan et al., 2015), thus, κAmax>κlactose(ST)\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\rm max} \gt \kappa _{\text{lactose}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}$\end{document}, and hence, Equation S40 holds for E. coli. From a theoretical perspective, we can verify Equation S39 and consequently Equation S40 using Equation S20, combined with the in vivo/in vitro biochemical parameters obtained from experimental data (see Appendix 1—table 1; Appendix 1—table 2). For example, it is straightforward to confirm that εr(κglucose(ST))<εf(κglucose(ST))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{\text{glucose}}^{(\text{ST})}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{\text{glucose}}^{(\text{ST})}\right)$\end{document} using this method (see Appendix 9.2), further supporting the validity of Equations S39-S40 (see also Appendix 10).

Now that Equations S38-S40 are all valid, a critical value of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}, denoted as κA(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}$\end{document}, exists, satisfying Δ(κA(C))=1\begin{document}$\Delta \left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})}\right)=1$\end{document}. Thus,(S41){εf(κA)>εr(κA),κA>κA(C);εf(κA)=εr(κA),κA=κA(C);εf(κA)<εr(κA),κA<κA(C).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)\text{,}\,\,\,\,\,\,\kappa _{A} \gt \kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\text{;}\\\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)=\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)\text{,}\,\,\,\,\,\,\kappa _{A}=\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\text{;}\\\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)\text{,}\,\,\,\,\,\,\kappa _{A} \lt \kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\text{.}\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

Combined with Equation S31, we have:(S42)κA(C)=βr(A)−βf(A)βf(A)(1/κ1+2/κ2+2/κ3+2/κ4)−βr(A)(1/κ1+2/κ2+2/κ6).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}=\frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}- \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}\left (1 \big/\kappa _{1}+2 \big/\kappa _{2}+2 \big/\kappa _{3}+2 \big/\kappa _{4}\right)- \beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}\left (1 \big/\kappa _{1}+2 \big/\kappa _{2}+2 \big/\kappa _{6}\right)}.$$\end{document}

By substituting Equation S42 into Equations S31, S32 and S36, we obtain the expressions for εr(κA(C))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})}\right)$\end{document}, εf(κA(C))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})}\right)$\end{document} and the critical growth rate at the transition point (i.e. λC≡λ(κA(C))\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})}\right)$\end{document}):(S43){εr(κA(C))=εf(κA(C))=βr(A)−βf(A)2(1/κ3+1/κ4−1/κ6)=β3+β4−β61/κ3+1/κ4−1/κ6,λC=ϕmaxφ/εr/f(κA(C))+ψ(κA(C)),\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=\frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}- \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}{2\left (1 \big/\kappa _{3}+1 \big/\kappa _{4}- 1 \big/\kappa _{6}\right)}\text{=}\frac{\beta _{3}+\beta _{4}- \beta _{6}}{1 \big/\kappa _{3}+1 \big/\kappa _{4}- 1 \big/\kappa _{6}}\text{,}\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \lambda _{\text{C}}=\frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)}\text{,}\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

where εr/f\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r/f}$\end{document} represents either εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} or εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}. In Figure 1E, we show the dependencies of εr(κA)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document}, εf(κA)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document}, and λ(κA)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document} on κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} in a three-dimensional form, as κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} changes.

sec.title: 3.3 The relation between respiration/fermentation flux and growth rate
sec.p: We proceed to study the relation between the respiration/fermentation flux and the cell growth rate. From Equations S16 and S30, we see that the stoichiometric fluxes Jr\begin{document}$J_{r}$\end{document}, Jf\begin{document}$J_{f}$\end{document}, the normalized fluxes Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, and the normalized energy fluxes Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} , Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} are all interconvertible. For convenience, we first analyze the relations between Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} , Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document}, and λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} under growth rate optimization. In fact, all these terms are merely functions of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} (see Equations S34-S36), which is determined by the nutrient condition (Equation S27).

In the homogeneous case, where all microbes share identical biochemical parameters, as λ(κA)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document} increases with κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}, Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} appear abruptly and Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} vanish simultaneously as κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} exceeds κA(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}$\end{document} (Figure 1E; see also Equations S34-S35, S41). Combining Equations S34-S36 and S43, we obtain:(S44){Jf(E)=φ⋅λ⋅θ(λ−λC),Jr(E)=φ⋅λ⋅[1−θ(λ−λC)].\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} J_{f}^{(\text{E})} = \varphi \cdot \lambda \cdot \theta \left( \lambda - \lambda_{\text{C}} \right), \\ J_r^{(\text{E})} = \varphi \cdot \lambda \cdot \left[ 1 - \theta \left( \lambda - \lambda_{\text{C}} \right) \right]. \end{array} \right.$$\end{document}

where ‘θ\begin{document}$\theta $\end{document}’ stands for the Heaviside step function. Defining λmax=λ(κAmax)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}=\lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)$\end{document}, and then, [0,λmax]\begin{document}$\left [0,\lambda _{\rm max}\right]$\end{document} is the relevant range of the x-axis. In fact, the digital responses in Equation S44 are consistent with the numerical simulation results of Molenaar et al., 2009. However, these results are incompatible with the threshold-analog response in the standard picture of overflow metabolism (Basan et al., 2015; Holms, 1996).

In practice, the values of kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} can be greatly influenced by the concentrations of potassium and phosphate (García-Contreras et al., 2012), which vary from cell to cell. Consequently, there is a distribution of values for kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} among cell populations, commonly referred to as extrinsic noise (Elowitz et al., 2002). For convenience, we assume that each kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} (and thus κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document}) follows a Gaussian distribution with a coefficient of variation (CV) of 25%. Therefore, the distributions of proteome efficiencies that determine the choice between respiration and fermentation, εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, and the critical growth rate for the transition, λC\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}$\end{document}, can be approximated by Gaussian distributions for a cell population (see Appendix 8.1 for details). Specifically, λC\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}$\end{document} follows:(S45)λC∼N(μλC,σλC2),\begin{document}$$\lambda _{\text{C}}\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}},\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}^{2}\right),$$\end{document}

where μλC\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{{C}}}$\end{document} and σλC\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}$\end{document} represent the mean and standard deviation of λC\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}$\end{document}, with the CV σλC/μλC\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}} \big/\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}$\end{document} calculated to be 12% (see Appendix 9.2 for details). Note that λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} is κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} dependent, while λC\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}$\end{document} is independent of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}. Thus, given the growth rate of microbes in a culturing medium (e.g. in a chemostat), the normalized energy fluxes are:(S46){Jf(E)(λ)=12φ⋅λ⋅[erf(λ−μλC2σλC)+1],Jr(E)(λ)=12φ⋅λ⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC2σλC)],\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{1}{2}\varphi \cdot \lambda \cdot \left [\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}}\right)+1\right],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{1}{2}\varphi \cdot \lambda \cdot \left [1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}}\right)\right],\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

where ‘erf’ represents the error function. In practice, given a culturing medium, there is also a probability distribution for the growth rate (Appendix 1—figure 2B; see also Equation S157). For approximation, in plotting the growth rate-respiration/fermentation flux relations, we use the deterministic (noise-free) value of the growth rate as a proxy. To compare with experiments, we essentially compare the normalized fluxes, Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} and Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} (see Appendix 9.1 for details). Combining Equations S30 and S46, we obtain:(S47){Jf(N)(λ)=φβf(A)⋅λ⋅[erf(λ−μλC2σλC)+1],Jr(N)(λ)=φβr(A)⋅λ⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC2σλC)].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{\varphi }{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left [\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}}\right)+1\right ],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{\varphi }{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left [1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}}\right)\right].\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

In Figure 1C–D, we see that Equation S47 quantitatively illustrates the experimental data (Basan et al., 2015), where the model parameters were obtained using biochemical data for the catalytic enzymes (see Appendix 1—table 1 for details).

sec.title: 3.4 Dependence of the model on optimization principles
sec.p: In the derivation of the growth rate dependence of respiration/fermentation flux described above (Equation S44 for the single-cell level and Equation S47 for the population-averaged level), we applied the principles of optimal growth, incorporating both efficient protein allocation to enzymes and ribosomes (through ribosomal proteins). However, recent experimental studies show that the inactive portion of ribosomes (i.e. ribosomes not bound to mRNAs) may vary with culturing conditions (Dai et al., 2017; Li et al., 2018) and between individual cells within the same culture (Pavlou et al., 2025), despite an overall trend toward growth optimization. These findings (Dai et al., 2017; Li et al., 2018; Pavlou et al., 2025) suggest that ribosome allocation may be suboptimal under many culturing conditions, likely as a result of cells preparing for potential environmental changes (Li et al., 2018). Nevertheless, since our model’s predictions regarding the binary choice between respiration and fermentation rely solely on comparing proteome efficiency between these two pathways, which involves only efficient protein allocation to enzymes, and because the active portion of ribosomes and the translation elongation rate can be approximated as constants within the growth rate range of interest for cells exhibiting overflow metabolism (Dai et al., 2017), our model remains applicable to suboptimal growth conditions. This can be achieved by incorporating suboptimal ribosome allocation factors, lowering the parameter κt\begin{document}$\kappa _{\rm t}$\end{document} (which results in a larger ψ\begin{document}$\psi $\end{document} through Equation S32), to account for these influences. For convenience, we present results for optimal growth below, while all model results can be extended to cases of suboptimal ribosome allocation.

Regarding the mechanism by which cells sense and choose between respiration and fermentation, although the standard picture of overflow metabolism (Basan et al., 2015; Holms, 1996) presents a growth rate dependence of fermentation flux, it is the proteome efficiency of respiration and fermentation, rather than the growth rate, that a cell should sense directly. Due to stochasticity in gene expression and metabolic reactions, the cell growth rate may fluctuate within a cell cycle (Kiviet et al., 2014; Pavlou et al., 2025), and suboptimal factors related to ribosome allocation (Dai et al., 2017; Li et al., 2018) would further complicate the scheme if cells were sensing via growth rate. Essentially, to expedite cell growth and survive under evolutionary pressure, cells should adopt the optimal strategy by directly sensing and comparing proteome efficiencies between respiration and fermentation, choosing the pathway with higher efficiency. This is analogous to how microbes choose between two types of carbon sources in a mixture for nutrient uptake (Wang et al., 2019). Mechanistically, the cyclic AMP (cAMP)-cAMP receptor protein (CRP) system plays an important role in sensing proteome efficiency and executing the optimal strategy between respiration and fermentation (Basan et al., 2015; Towbin et al., 2017; Valgepea et al., 2010; Wehrens et al., 2023). However, the roles of additional unidentified regulators are required to fully elucidate this mechanism (Basan et al., 2015; Valgepea et al., 2010).

sec.title: 4.1 Overexpression of useless proteins
sec.p: Here, we consider the case of overexpression of the protein encoded by the lacZ gene (i.e. ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} perturbation) in E. coli. Effectively, this limits the proteome by altering ϕmax\begin{document}$\phi _{\rm max}$\end{document}:(S48)ϕmax→LacZ overexpressionϕmax−ϕZ,\begin{document}$$\phi _{\rm max} \xrightarrow[]{\text{LacZ overexpression}} \phi _{\rm max}- \phi _{Z},$$\end{document}

where ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} stands for the proteomic mass fraction of useless proteins, which is controllable in experiments. Then, the growth rate changes into a bivariate function of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} and ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document}:(S49)λ(κA,ϕZ)={ϕmax−ϕZφ/εr(κA)+ψ(κA)εr(κA)>εf(κA),ϕmax−ϕZφ/εf(κA)+ψ(κA)εr(κA)<εf(κA),\begin{document}$$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)=\left \{\begin{aligned} &\displaystyle\frac{\phi _{\rm max}- \phi _{\text{Z}}}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}- \phi _{\text{Z}}}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

and thus,(S50)λ(κA,ϕZ)=λ(κA,0)(1−ϕZ/ϕmax).\begin{document}$$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)=\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)\left (1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}\right).$$\end{document}

Obviously, κA(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}$\end{document} remains a constant (following Equation S42), while λC(ϕZ)≡λ(κA(C),ϕZ)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})},\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document} and λmax(ϕZ)≡λ(κAmax,ϕZ)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max},\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document} become functions of ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document}:(S51){λC(ϕZ)=λC(0)(1−ϕZ/ϕmax),λmax(ϕZ)=λmax(0)(1−ϕZ/ϕmax).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)=\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)\left (1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}\right),\\\lambda _{\rm max}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)=\lambda _{\rm max}\left (0\right)\left (1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}\right).\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

In the homogeneous case, Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} and Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} follow:(S52){Jf(E)(κA,ϕZ)=φ⋅λ(κA,ϕZ)⋅θ(λ(κA,ϕZ)−λC(ϕZ)),Jr(E)(κA,ϕZ)=φ⋅λ(κA,ϕZ)⋅[1−θ(λ(κA,ϕZ)−λC(ϕZ))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)=\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)\cdot \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)\right),\\J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)=\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)\cdot \left[1- \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)\right)\right]\text{.}\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

Combined with Equations S50-S51, we have:(S53){Jf(E)(κA,ϕZ)=φ⋅λ(κA,ϕZ)⋅θ(λ(κA,0)−λC(0)),Jr(E)(κA,ϕZ)=φ⋅λ(κA,ϕZ)⋅[1−θ(λ(κA,0)−λC(0))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)=\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)\cdot \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)\right),\\J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)=\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)\cdot \left[1- \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)\right)\right]\text{.}\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

To compare with experiments, we assume that each kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} and κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} follow the extrinsic noise with a CV of 25% specified in Appendix 3.3, and we neglect the noise on ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{\text{Z}}$\end{document} and ϕmax\begin{document}$\phi _{\rm max}$\end{document}. Combining Equations S45 and S51, λC(ϕZ)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document} approximately follows a Gaussian distribution:(S54)λC(ϕZ)∼N(μλC(ϕZ),σλC(ϕZ)2),\begin{document}$$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right),\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)^{2}\right),$$\end{document}

where μλC(ϕZ)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document} and σλC(ϕZ)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document} represent the mean and standard deviation of λC(ϕZ)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document}, with(S55){μλC(ϕZ)=μλC(0)(1−ϕZ/ϕmax),σλC(ϕZ)=σλC(0)(1−ϕZ/ϕmax).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)=\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left (1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}\right),\\\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)=\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left (1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}\right).\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

Here, μλC(0)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} , σλC(0)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)$\end{document}, λC(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} , λmax(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}\left (0\right)$\end{document}, and λ(κA,0)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)$\end{document} represent the parameters or variables free from ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} perturbation, just as those in Appendix 3.3. Since the noise on the multiplier term (i.e. 1−ϕZ/ϕmax\begin{document}$1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}$\end{document}) is negligible, the CV of λC(ϕZ)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document} (i.e. σλC(ϕZ)/μλC(ϕZ)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right) \big/\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document}) is unaffected by ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{\text{Z}}$\end{document}. By combining Equations S46 and S48, we obtain the relations between the normalized energy fluxes and growth rate:(S56){Jf(E)(λ(κA,ϕZ),ϕZ)=12φ⋅λ(κA,ϕZ)⋅[erf(λ(κA,ϕZ)−μλC(ϕZ)2σλC(ϕZ))+1],Jr(E)(λ(κA,ϕZ),ϕZ)=12φ⋅λ(κA,ϕZ)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,ϕZ)−μλC(ϕZ)2σλC(ϕZ))],\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} \displaystyle &J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right),\phi _{Z}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)\cdot \left [\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)- \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)}\right)+1\right ],\\[1pt] &\displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right),\phi _{Z}\right)=\frac{1}{2}\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)\cdot \left [1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)- \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)}\right)\right]\text{,}\end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

where λ(κA,ϕZ)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)$\end{document}, μλC(ϕZ)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document}, and σλC(ϕZ)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document} follow Equations S50 and S55 accordingly. For a given value of ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document}, i.e., ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} is fixed, then, λ(κA,ϕZ)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{Z}\right)$\end{document} changes monotonically with κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}.
