Combining Equations S55-S56 and S30, we obtain the relation between the normalized fluxes Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, and the growth rate (where ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} is a parameter):(S57){Jf(N)(λ,ϕZ)=φβf(A)⋅λ⋅[erf(λ−μλC(0)(1−ϕZ/ϕmax)2σλC(0)(1−ϕZ/ϕmax))+1],Jr(N)(λ,ϕZ)=φβr(A)⋅λ⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC(0)(1−ϕZ/ϕmax)2σλC(0)(1−ϕZ/ϕmax))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} &\displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda ,\phi _{Z}\right)=\frac{\varphi }{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left (1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}\right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left (1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}\right)}\right)+1\right ],\\[1pt] &\displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda ,\phi _{Z}\right)=\frac{\varphi }{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left (1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}\right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left (1- \phi _{\text{Z}} \big/\phi _{\rm max}\right)}\right)\right]\text{.}\end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}
In Figure 2C. we show that the model predictions (Equation S57) quantitatively agree with the experiments (Basan et al., 2015).

Meanwhile, we can also perturb the growth rate by tuning ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} in a stable culturing environment with fixed concentration of a Group A carbon source (i.e. given [A]). In fact, for this case there is a distribution of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} values due to the extrinsic noise in kAcat\begin{document}$k_{A}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document}, yet this distribution is fixed. For convenience of description, we still referred to it as fixed κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}. Then, combining Equations S30, S50, S55 and S56, we get:(S58){Jf(N)(λ,ϕZ)=φβf(A)⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1]⋅λ,Jr(N)(λ,ϕZ)=φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]⋅λ.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda ,\phi_{Z}\right)=\frac{\varphi }{\beta_{f}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)- \mu_{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)}\right)+1\right]\cdot \lambda ,\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda ,\phi _{Z}\right)=\frac{\varphi}{\beta_{r}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)- \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma_{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)}\right)\right]\cdot \lambda .\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

Here, λ(κA,0)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)$\end{document} remains unaltered as κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} is fixed. Therefore, in this case, Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} and Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} are proportional to λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document}, where the slopes are both functions of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}. More specifically, the slope of Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} is a monotonically increasing function of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}, while that of Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} is a monotonically decreasing function of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}. In Figure 2B, we see that the model predictions (Equation S58) agree quantitatively with the experiments (Basan et al., 2015).

In fact, the growth rate can be altered by tuning ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} and κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} simultaneously. Then, the relations among the energy fluxes, growth rate, and ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} still follow Equation S57 (where ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} is a variable). In a 3-D representation, these relations correspond to a surface. In Figure 2A, we show that the model predictions (Equation S57) match well with the experimental data (Basan et al., 2015).

sec.title: 4.2 Energy dissipation
sec.p: In practice, energy dissipation disrupts the proportional relationship between energy demand and biomass production. Thus, Equation S25 becomes:(S59)JE=rE⋅JBM+w⋅Mcarbonm0,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle J_{\text{E}}=r_{\text{E}}\cdot J_{\text{BM}}+w\cdot \frac{M_{\text{carbon}}}{m_{0}},$$\end{document}

where w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} represents the dissipation coefficient. In fact, maintenance energy contributes to energy dissipation, and we define the maintenance energy coefficient as w0\begin{document}$w_{0}$\end{document}. In bacteria, the impact of maintenance energy is roughly negligible, yet in tumor cells, it plays a much more significant role (Locasale and Cantley, 2010).

The introduction of energy dissipation leads to a modification of Equation S26: combining Equation S59 and Equation S16, we have:(S60)JE(N)=ηE⋅λ+w.\begin{document}$$J_{\text{E}}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}=\eta _{\text{E}}\cdot \lambda +w.$$\end{document}

Then, Equation S29 changes to:(S61){Jr(E)+Jf(E)=φ⋅λ+w,Jr(E)εr+Jf(E)εf=ϕmax−ψ⋅λ.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}+J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}=\varphi \cdot \lambda +w,\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \frac{J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}}{\varepsilon _{r}}+\frac{J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}}{\varepsilon _{f}}=\phi _{\rm max}- \psi \cdot \lambda .\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

Consequently, if εr>εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r} \gt \varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, the optimal growth strategy for the cell is:(S62){Jf(E)=0,Jr(E)=φ⋅λ+w,εr>εf,\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}=0,\\J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}=\varphi \cdot \lambda +w,\end{array}\qquad\varepsilon _{r} \gt \varepsilon _{f},\right.$$\end{document}

and if εf>εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f} \gt \varepsilon _{r}$\end{document}, the optimal growth strategy is:(S63){Jf(E)=φ⋅λ+w,Jr(E)=0.εr<εf.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}=\varphi \cdot \lambda +w,\\J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}=0.\end{array}\qquad\varepsilon _{r} \lt \varepsilon _{f}.\right.$$\end{document}

Then, the growth rate becomes a bivariate function of both κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} and w\begin{document}$w$\end{document}:(S64)λ(κA,w)={ϕmax−w/εr(κA)φ/εr(κA)+ψ(κA)εr(κA)>εf(κA),ϕmax−w/εf(κA)φ/εf(κA)+ψ(κA)εr(κA)<εf(κA).\begin{document}$$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)=\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}- w \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\\[1pt] &\displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}- w \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right).\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

Clearly, κA(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}$\end{document} is still a constant, while λC(w)≡λ(κA(C),w)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (w\right)\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})},w\right)$\end{document} and λmax(w)≡λ(κAmax,w)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}\left (w\right)\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max},w\right)$\end{document} become functions of w\begin{document}$w$\end{document}:(S65){λC(w)=λC(0){1−w/[εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]},λmax(w)=λmax(0){1−w/[εf(κAmax)ϕmax]}.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (w\right)=\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)\left \{1- w \big/\left[\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)\phi _{\rm max}\right ]\right \},\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \lambda _{\rm max}\left (w\right)=\lambda _{\rm max}\left (0\right)\left \{1- w \big/\left[\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)\phi _{\rm max}\right]\right \}.\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

For a cell population, in the homogeneous case, Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} and Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} follow:(S66){Jf(E)(κA,w)=[φ⋅λ(κA,w)+w]⋅θ(λ(κA,w)−λC(w)),Jr(E)(κA,w)=[φ⋅λ(κA,w)+w]⋅[1−θ(λ(κA,w)−λC(w))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},w\right)=\left[\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)+w\right]\cdot \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (w\right)\right),\\J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},w\right)=\left[\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)+w\right]\cdot \left[1- \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (w\right)\right)\right]\text{.}\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

To compare with experiments, we assume the same extent of extrinsic noise in kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} (and thus κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document}) as that specified in Appendix 3.3. Combining Equations S45 and S65, λC(w)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (w\right)$\end{document} approximately follows a Gaussian distribution:(S67)λC(w)∼N(μλC(w),σλC(w)2),\begin{document}$$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (w\right)\sim {\cal N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right),\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right)^{2}\right),$$\end{document}

where μλC(w)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right)$\end{document} and σλC(w)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right)$\end{document} represent the mean and standard deviation of λC(w)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (w\right)$\end{document}, and(S68){μλC(w)=μλC(0){1−w/[εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]},σλC(w)≈σλC(0){1−w/[εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]}.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right)=\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left \{1- w \big/\left[\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)\phi _{\rm max}\right]\right \},\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right)\approx \sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left \{1- w \big/\left[\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)\phi _{\rm max}\right]\right \}.\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

Here, μλC(0)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} , σλC(0)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)$\end{document}, λC(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} , λmax(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}\left (0\right)$\end{document}, and λ(κA,0)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)$\end{document} represent parameters or variables unaffected by energy dissipation. In fact, there is a distribution of values for εr/f(κA(C))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})}\right)$\end{document}. For approximation, we use the deterministic value of εr/f(κA(C))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})}\right)$\end{document} in Equation S68, and then the CV of λC(w)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (w\right)$\end{document} remains largely unperturbed by w\begin{document}$w$\end{document}. Combining Equations S46, S66 and S67, we have:(S69){Jf(E)(λ(κA,w),w)=12(φ⋅λ(κA,w)+w)⋅[erf(λ(κA,w)−μλC(w)2σλC(w))+1],Jr(E)(λ(κA,w),w)=12(φ⋅λ(κA,w)+w)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,w)−μλC(w)2σλC(w))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right),w\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left (\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)+w\right)\cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)- \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right)}\right)+1\right],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right),w\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left (\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)+w\right)\cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)- \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (w\right)}\right)\right]\text{.}\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

Since the dissipation coefficient w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is tunable in experiments, for a given value of w\begin{document}$w$\end{document}, λ(κA,w)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w\right)$\end{document} changes monotonically with κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}. Combining Equations S68-S69 and S30, we have (here w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is a parameter):(S70){Jf(N)(λ,w)=φ⋅λ+wβf(A)⋅[erf(λ−μλC(0){1−w/[εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]}2σλC(0){1−w/[εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]})+1],Jr(N)(λ,w)=φ⋅λ+wβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC(0){1−w/[εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]}2σλC(0){1−w/[εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]})].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left(\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda ,w\right)=\frac{\varphi \cdot \lambda +w}{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left \{1- w \big/\left[\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)\phi _{\rm max}\right]\right \}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left \{1- w \big/\left[\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)\phi _{\rm max}\right]\right\}}\right)+1\right],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda ,w\right)=\frac{\varphi \cdot \lambda +w}{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left \{1- w \big/\left [\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)\phi _{\rm max}\right]\right \}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\left \{1- w \big/\left[\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)\phi _{\rm max}\right]\right \}}\right)\right]\text{.}\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

The comparison between model predictions (Equation S70) and experimental results (Basan et al., 2015) is shown in Figure 3B, which shows quantitative agreement. Meanwhile, the growth rate can also be perturbed by changing κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} and w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} simultaneously. The relations among the energy fluxes, growth rate and w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} follow Equation S70 (here w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is a variable). In a 3D representation, these relations form a surface. As shown in Figure 3A, the model predictions (Equation S70) agree quantitatively with the experimental results (Basan et al., 2015).

sec.title: 4.3 Translation inhibition
sec.p: In E. coli, the translation rate can be modified by adding different concentrations of translation inhibitors, e.g., chloramphenicol (Cm). The net effect of this perturbation is represented as:(S71)κt→Translationinhibitionκt/(ι+1),\begin{document}$$\kappa _{\rm t}\xrightarrow{\rm Translation\, inhibition} \kappa _{\rm t} \big/\left (\iota +1\right),$$\end{document}

where ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} stands for the inhibition coefficient with ι>0\begin{document}$\iota \gt 0$\end{document}, and (1+ι)−1\begin{document}$\left (1+\iota \right)^{- 1}$\end{document} represents the translation efficiency. Thus, Equation S32 changes to:(S72)ψ(κA,ι)=ι+1κt+1+ηa1+ηc2κA+ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd2κ1+ηb+ηcκ2+ηcκ3+ηc+ηdκ5+∑ia1,a2,b,c,dηiκi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \psi \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)=\frac{\iota +1}{\kappa _{\rm t}}+\frac{1+\eta _{a1}+\eta _{c}}{2\kappa _{A}}+\frac{\eta _{a2}+\eta _{b}+2\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}}{2\kappa _{1}}+\frac{\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{2}}+\frac{\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{3}}+\frac{\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}}{\kappa _{5}}+\sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}\frac{\eta _{i}}{\kappa _{i}}$$\end{document}

First, we consider the case where maintenance energy is neglected, i.e., w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document}. In this case, the growth rate takes the following form:(S73)λ(κA,ι)={ϕmaxφ/εr(κA)+ψ(κA,ι)εr(κA)>εf(κA),ϕmaxφ/εf(κA)+ψ(κA,ι)εr(κA)<εf(κA),\begin{document}$$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)=\left \{\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\\[1pt] \displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

where λ(κA,0)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)$\end{document} and ψ(κA,0)\begin{document}$\psi \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)$\end{document} represent the terms unaffected by translation inhibition. Thus, λC(ι)≡λ(κA(C),ι)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)},\iota \right)$\end{document} and λmax(ι)≡λ(κAmax,ι)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}\left (\iota \right)\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max},\iota \right)$\end{document} become functions of ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document}:(S74){λC(ι)=λC(0)φ/εr/f(κA(C))+ψ(κA(C),0)φ/εr/f(κA(C))+ψ(κA(C),ι),λmax(ι)=λmax(0)φ/εf(κAmax)+ψ(κAmax,0)φ/εf(κAmax)+ψ(κAmax,ι).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)=\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)\frac{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)},0\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)},\iota \right)},\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \lambda _{\rm max}\left (\iota \right)=\lambda _{\rm max}\left (0\right)\frac{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max},0\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max},\iota \right)}.\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

In the homogeneous case, Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} and Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} follow:(S75){Jf(E)(κA,ι)=φ⋅λ(κA,ι)⋅θ(λ(κA,ι)−λC(ι)),Jr(E)(κA,ι)=φ⋅λ(κA,ι)⋅[1−θ(λ(κA,ι)−λC(ι))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)=\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)\cdot \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)\right),\\J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)=\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)\cdot \left[1- \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)\right)\right]\text{.}\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

To compare with experiments, we assume that extrinsic noise exists in kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} and κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} as specified in Appendix 3.3. Combining Equations S45 and S74, λC(ι)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} can be approximated by a Gaussian distribution:(S76)λC(ι)∼N(μλC(ι),σλC(ι)2),\begin{document}$$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)\sim {\cal N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right),\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)^{2}\right),$$\end{document}

where μλC(ι)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} and σλC(ι)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} represent the mean and standard deviation of λC(ι)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document}, with(S77){μλC(ι)=μλC(0)φ/εr/f(κA(C))+ψ(κA(C),0)φ/εr/f(κA(C))+ψ(κA(C),ι),σλC(ι)≈σλC(0)φ/εr/f(κA(C))+ψ(κA(C),0)φ/εr/f(κA(C))+ψ(κA(C),ι).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)=\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\frac{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)},0\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)},\iota \right)},\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)\approx \sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)\frac{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)},0\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)},\iota \right)}.\end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

Here, μλC(0)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} , σλC(0)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)$\end{document}, ψ(κA(C),0)\begin{document}$\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})},0\right)$\end{document}, λC(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} and λmax(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}\left (0\right)$\end{document} stand for the terms unaffected by translation inhibition. Essentially, there are distributions of values for εr/f(κA(C))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})}\right)$\end{document}, ψ(κA(C),0)\begin{document}$\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})},0\right)$\end{document} and ψ(κA(C),ι)\begin{document}$\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{(\text{C})},\iota \right)$\end{document}. For approximation, we use the deterministic values of these terms in Equation S77, and then the CV of λC(ι)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} can be approximated by λC(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)$\end{document}. Combining Equations S46, S75 and S76, we have:(S78){Jf(E)(λ(κA,ι),ι)=12φ⋅λ(κA,ι)⋅[erf(λ(κA,ι)−μλC(ι)2σλC(ι))+1],Jr(E)(λ(κA,ι),ι)=12φ⋅λ(κA,ι)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,ι)−μλC(ι)2σλC(ι))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right),\iota \right)=\frac{1}{2}\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)\cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)- \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)}\right)+1\right],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right),\iota \right)=\frac{1}{2}\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)\cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)- \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)}\right)\right]\text{.}\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

In the experiments, the inhibition coefficient ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} is controllable by adjusting the concentration of the translation inhibitor. For a given value of ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document}, λ(κA,ι)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)$\end{document} changes monotonically with κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}. Combining Equations S30 and S78, we have (here ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} is a parameter):(S79){Jf(N)(λ,ι)=φ⋅λβf(A)⋅[erf(λ−μλC(ι)2σλC(ι))+1],Jr(N)(λ,ι)=φ⋅λβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC(ι)2σλC(ι))],\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda ,\iota \right)=\frac{\varphi \cdot \lambda }{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)}\right)+1\right],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda ,\iota \right)=\frac{\varphi \cdot \lambda }{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)}\right)\right]\text{,}\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

where μλC(ι)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} and σλC(ι)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} follow Equation S77. The growth rate can also be perturbed by altering both κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} and ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} simultaneously. In this case, the relations among the energy fluxes, growth rate and ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} still follow Equation S79 (here ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} is a variable). The comparison between Equation S79 and experimental data (Basan et al., 2015) is shown in Appendix 1—figure 2D (3-D) and E(2-D). Overall, there is good consistency; however, there remains a noticeable discrepancy when ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} is large (i.e. at high concentration of the translation inhibitor). This led us to consider the maintenance energy through the coefficient w0\begin{document}$w_{0}$\end{document}, which is small but may account for this discrepancy. Then, λ(κA,ι)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)$\end{document} changes into:(S80)λ(κA,ι)={ϕmax−w0/εr(κA)φ/εr(κA)+ψ(κA,ι)εr(κA)>εf(κA),ϕmax−w0/εf(κA)φ/εf(κA)+ψ(κA,ι)εr(κA)<εf(κA),\begin{document}$$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)=\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}- w_{0} \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}- w_{0} \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

while λC(ι)≡λ(κA(C),ι)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)},\iota \right)$\end{document} and λmax(ι)≡λ(κAmax,ι)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}\left (\iota \right)\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max},\iota \right)$\end{document} still follow Equation S74, though the forms of λC(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} and λmax(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}\left (0\right)$\end{document} change to:(S81){λC(0)=ϕmax−w0/εr/f(κA(C))φ/εr/f(κA(C))+ψ(κA(C),0),λmax(0)=ϕmax−w0/εf(κAmax)φ/εf(κAmax)+ψ(κAmax,0).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)=\frac{\phi _{\rm max}- w_{0} \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)},0\right)},\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \lambda _{\rm max}\left (0\right)=\frac{\phi _{\rm max}- w_{0} \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max},0\right)}\text{.}\end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

In the homogeneous case, Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} and Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} follow:(S82){Jf(E)(κA,ι)=[φ⋅λ(κA,ι)+w0]⋅θ(λ(κA,ι)−λC(ι)),Jr(E)(κA,ι)=[φ⋅λ(κA,ι)+w0]⋅[1−θ(λ(κA,ι)−λC(ι))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)=\left[\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)+w_{0}\right]\cdot \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)\right),\\J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)=\left[\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)+w_{0}\right]\cdot \left[1- \theta \left (\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)- \lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)\right)\right]\text{.}\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

To compare with experiments, we assume that the extrinsic noise follows the specification in Appendix 3.3. Combining Equations S45, S74 and S81, λC(ι)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} approximately follows a Gaussian distribution:(S83)λC(ι)∼N(μλC(ι),σλC(ι)2)\begin{document}$$\lambda _{{C}}\left (\iota \right)\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{{C}}}\left (\iota \right),\sigma _{\lambda _{{C}}}\left (\iota \right)^{2}\right)$$\end{document}

Here μλC(ι)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} and σλC(ι)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} still follow Equation S77, while μλC(0)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} and σλC(0)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} change accordingly with λC(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)$\end{document} (see Equation S81). For approximation, we use the deterministic values of the relevant terms in Equation S77, and then the CV of λC(ι)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (\iota \right)$\end{document} is roughly the same as λC(0)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}\left (0\right)$\end{document}. Combining Equations S46, S82 and S83, we have:(S84){Jf(E)(λ(κA,ι),ι)=12(φ⋅λ(κA,ι)+w0)⋅[erf(λ(κA,ι)−μλC(ι)2σλC(ι))+1],Jr(E)(λ(κA,ι),ι)=12(φ⋅λ(κA,ι)+w0)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,ι)−μλC(ι)2σλC(ι))].\begin{document}$$\left\{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left(\text{E} \right)} \left(\lambda \left(\kappa_A, \iota \right), \iota \right) = \frac{1}{2} \left(\varphi \cdot \lambda \left(\kappa_A, \iota \right) + w_0 \right) \cdot \left[\text{erf} \left(\frac{\lambda \left(\kappa_A, \iota \right) - \mu_{\lambda_{\text{C}}} \left(\iota \right)}{\sqrt{2} \sigma_{\lambda_{\text{C}}} \left( \iota \right)} \right) + 1 \right], \\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left(\text{E} \right)} \left(\lambda \left(\kappa_A, \iota \right), \iota \right) = \frac{1}{2} \left(\varphi \cdot \lambda \left(\kappa_A, \iota \right) + w_0 \right) \cdot \left[ 1 - \text{erf} \left(\frac{\lambda \left(\kappa_A, \iota \right) - \mu_{\lambda_{\text{C}}} \left(\iota \right)}{\sqrt{2} \sigma_{\lambda_{\text{C}}} \left(\iota \right)} \right) \right]. \end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

Thus, for a given ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document}, λ(κA,ι)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\iota \right)$\end{document} changes monotonically with κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}. Combining Equations S30 and S84, we have (here ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} is a parameter):(S85){Jf(N)(λ,ι)=φ⋅λ+w0βf(A)⋅[erf(λ−μλC(ι)2σλC(ι))+1].Jr(N)(λ,ι)=φ⋅λ+w0βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC(ι)2σλC(ι))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left(\text{N}\right)}\left(\lambda ,\iota \right)=\frac{\varphi \cdot \lambda +w_{0}}{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left(\iota \right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left (\iota \right)}\right)+1\right].\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left(\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda ,\iota \right)=\frac{\varphi \cdot \lambda +w_{0}}{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left(\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left(\iota \right)}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}\left(\iota \right)}\right)\right]\text{.}\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

The growth rate and fluxes can also be perturbed by altering both κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} and ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} simultaneously. The relations among the energy fluxes, growth rate, and ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} would still follow Equation S85, except that ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} is now regarded as a variable. Assuming a small amount of maintenance energy by assigning w0=2.5 (h−1)\begin{document}$w_{0}=2.5\text{\ }\left (h^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}, we find that the experimental results (Basan et al., 2015) agree quantitatively well with the model predictions (Figure 3C and D).

sec.title: Overflow metabolism in substrates other than Group A carbon sources
sec.p: Due to the topology of the metabolic network, for cells using Group A carbon sources, the behavior of overflow metabolism follows Equation 5 (or Equation S47) upon κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} perturbation (i.e. varying the type or concentration of a Group A carbon source). This has been demonstrated clearly in the above analysis and agrees quantitatively with experiments. However, further analysis is required for cells using substrates other than Group A sources due to the topological differences in carbon utilization (Wang et al., 2019). In principle, substrates entering from glycolysis or the points before acetyl-CoA are potentially involved in overflow metabolism, while those joining from the TCA cycle are not relevant to this behavior. Still, mixed carbon sources are likely to induce a different profile of overflow metabolism, as long as there is a carbon source derived from glycolysis.

sec.title: 5.1 Pyruvate
sec.p: The coarse-grained model for pyruvate utilization is shown in Figure 3E. Here, nodes M1, M2, M3, M4, M5 follow the descriptions in Appendix 3.1. Each biochemical reaction follows Equation S5 with bi=1\begin{document}$b_{i}=1$\end{document} except that 2M2→M1 and M3+M5→M4. By applying flux balance to the stoichiometric fluxes, combining with Equation S8, we have:(S86){Φpy⋅ξpy=Φ7⋅ξ7+Φ8⋅ξ8,Φ7⋅ξ7=2Φ9⋅ξ9+Φ5⋅ξ5+Φa2⋅ξa2,Φ9⋅ξ9=Φa1⋅ξa1,Φ8⋅ξ8=Φ3⋅ξ3+Φ6⋅ξ6+Φb⋅ξb,Φ5⋅ξ5+Φ4⋅ξ4=Φ3⋅ξ3+Φd⋅ξd,Φ3⋅ξ3=Φ4⋅ξ4+Φc⋅ξc.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\Phi _{{\rm{py}}}} \cdot {\xi _{{\rm{py}}}} = {\Phi _7} \cdot {\xi _7} + {\Phi _8} \cdot {\xi _8},\\ {\Phi _7} \cdot {\xi _7} = 2{\Phi _9} \cdot {\xi _9} + {\Phi _5} \cdot {\xi _5} + {\Phi _{a2}} \cdot {\xi _{a2}},\\ {\Phi _9} \cdot {\xi _9} = {\Phi _{a1}} \cdot {\xi _{a1}},\\ {\Phi _8} \cdot {\xi _8} = {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} + {\Phi _6} \cdot {\xi _6} + {\Phi _b} \cdot {\xi _b},\\ {\Phi _5} \cdot {\xi _5} + {\Phi _4} \cdot {\xi _4} = {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} + {\Phi _d} \cdot {\xi _d},\\ {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} = {\Phi _4} \cdot {\xi _4} + {\Phi _c} \cdot {\xi _c}. \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

For energy biogenesis, we convert all the energy currencies into ATPs, and then,(S87)β8⋅Φ8⋅ξ8+β3⋅Φ3⋅ξ3+β4⋅Φ4⋅ξ4+β6⋅Φ6⋅ξ6+βa1⋅Φa1⋅ξa1−β7⋅Φ7⋅ξ7−β9⋅Φ9⋅ξ9=JE\begin{document}$${\beta _8} \cdot {\Phi _8} \cdot {\xi _8} + {\beta _3} \cdot {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} + {\beta _4} \cdot {\Phi _4} \cdot {\xi _4} + {\beta _6} \cdot {\Phi _6} \cdot {\xi _6} + {\beta _{a1}} \cdot {\Phi _{a1}} \cdot {\xi _{a1}} - {\beta _7} \cdot {\Phi _7} \cdot {\xi _7} - {\beta _9} \cdot {\Phi _9} \cdot {\xi _9} = {J_{\rm{E}}}$$\end{document}

where β7=1\begin{document}$\beta _{7}=1$\end{document}, β8=2\begin{document}$\beta _{8}=2$\end{document}, β3=2\begin{document}$\beta _{3}=2$\end{document}, β4=6\begin{document}$\beta _{4}=6$\end{document}, β6=1\begin{document}$\beta _{6}=1$\end{document}, β9=6\begin{document}$\beta _{9}=6$\end{document},βa1=4\begin{document}$\beta _{a1}=4$\end{document} for E. coli (Neidhardt et al., 1990; Sauer et al., 2004), and JE\begin{document}$J_{\text{E}}$\end{document} follows Equation S25. By applying the substitutions specified in Equations S9, S12, S14-S18, combined with Equations S4, S10, S22, S23, S25, S86-S87, and the constraint of proteome resource allocation, we have:(S88){ϕpy⋅κpy=ϕ7⋅κ7+ϕ8⋅κ8,ϕ7⋅κ7=2ϕ9⋅κ9+ϕ5⋅κ5+ϕa2⋅κa2,ϕ9⋅κ9=ϕa1⋅κa1ϕ8⋅κ8=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕ6⋅κ6+ϕb⋅κbϕ3⋅κ3=ϕ4⋅κ4+ϕc⋅κcϕ5⋅κ5+ϕ4⋅κ4=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕd⋅κdϕa1⋅κa1=ηa1⋅λ,ϕa2⋅κa2=ηa2⋅λ,ϕb⋅κb=ηb⋅λ,ϕc⋅κc=ηc⋅λ,ϕd⋅κd=ηd⋅λ,β8⋅ϕ8⋅κ8+β3⋅ϕ3⋅κ3+β4⋅ϕ4⋅κ4+β6⋅ϕ6⋅κ6+βa1⋅ϕa1⋅κa1−β7⋅ϕ7⋅κ7−β9⋅ϕ9⋅κ9=JE(N),JE(N)=ηE⋅λ,λ=ϕR⋅κt,Jr(N)=ϕ4⋅κ4,Jf(N)=ϕ6⋅κ6,ϕR+ϕpy+ϕ3+ϕ4+ϕ5+ϕ6+ϕ7+ϕ8+ϕ9+ϕa1+ϕa2+ϕb+ϕc+ϕd=ϕmax,\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\phi _{{\rm{py}}}} \cdot {\kappa _{{\rm{py}}}} = {\phi _7} \cdot {\kappa _7} + {\phi _8} \cdot {\kappa _8},\\ {\phi _7} \cdot {\kappa _7} = 2{\phi _9} \cdot {\kappa _9} + {\phi _5} \cdot {\kappa _5} + {\phi _{a2}} \cdot {\kappa _{a2}},\\ {\phi _9} \cdot {\kappa _9} = {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}}\\ {\phi _8} \cdot {\kappa _8} = {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6} + {\phi _b} \cdot {\kappa _b}\\ {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} = {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} + {\phi _c} \cdot {\kappa _c}\\ {\phi _5} \cdot {\kappa _5} + {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} = {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\phi _d} \cdot {\kappa _d}\\ {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}} = {\eta _{a1}} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _{a2}} \cdot {\kappa _{a2}} = {\eta _{a2}} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _b} \cdot {\kappa _b} = {\eta _b} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _c} \cdot {\kappa _c} = {\eta _c} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _d} \cdot {\kappa _d} = {\eta _d} \cdot \lambda ,\\ {\beta _8} \cdot {\phi _8} \cdot {\kappa _8} + {\beta _3} \cdot {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\beta _4} \cdot {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} + {\beta _6} \cdot {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6} + {\beta _{a1}} \cdot {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}} \\- {\beta _7} \cdot {\phi _7} \cdot {\kappa _7} - {\beta _9} \cdot {\phi _9} \cdot {\kappa _9} = J_{\rm{E}}^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)},\\ J_{\rm{E}}^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\eta _{\rm{E}}} \cdot \lambda ,\lambda = {\phi _R} \cdot {\kappa _{\rm t} },J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4},J_f^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6},\\ {\phi _{\rm{R}}} + {\phi _{{\rm{py}}}} + {\phi _3} + {\phi _4} + {\phi _5} + {\phi _6} + {\phi _7} + {\phi _8} + {\phi _9} + {\phi _{a1}} + {\phi _{a2}} + {\phi _b} + {\phi _c} + {\phi _d} = {\phi _{\max }}, \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

where ηE=rE⋅[∑iri/NEPicarbon]−1\begin{document}$\eta _{\text{E}}=r_{\text{E}}\cdot \left[\underset{i}{\sum }r_{i} \big/N_{\text{EP}_{i}}^{\text{carbon}}\right]^{- 1}$\end{document}. κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} is approximately a constant which follows Equation S20 for each of the intermediate node. The substrate quality of κpy\begin{document}$\kappa _{\text{py}}$\end{document} varies with the external concentration of pyruvate ([py]),(S89)κpy≡rproteinrcarbon⋅kpycatmEpy⋅[py][py]+Kpy⋅m0.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \kappa _{\text{py}}\equiv \frac{r_{\text{protein}}}{r_{\text{carbon}}}\cdot \frac{k_{\text{py}}^{\text{cat}}}{m_{E_{\text{py}}}}\cdot \frac{\left [\text{py}\right ]}{\left [\text{py}\right ]+K_{\text{py}}}\cdot m_{0}.$$\end{document}

From Equation S88, all ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} can be expressed by Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, and λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document}:(S90){ϕpy=[(2ηa1+ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)λ+Jr(N)+Jf(N)]/κpy,ϕ7=(2ηa1+ηa2+ηc+ηd)λ/κ7,ϕ9=ηa1⋅λ/κ9ϕ8=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(ηb+ηc)λ]/κ8ϕ3=(Jr(N)+ηc⋅λ)/κ3,ϕ4=Jr(N)/κ4,ϕ5=(ηc+ηd)λ/κ5,ϕ6=Jf(N)/κ6,ϕi=ηi⋅λ/κi(i=a1,a2,b,c,d).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \phi _{\text{py}}=\left[\left (2\eta _{a1}+\eta _{a2}+\eta _{b}+2\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}\right)\lambda +J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\right]\big/\kappa _{\text{py}},\\[1pt] & \displaystyle\phi _{7}=\left (2\eta _{a1}+\eta _{a2}+\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}\right)\lambda \big/\kappa _{7},\phi _{9}=\eta _{a1}\cdot \lambda \big/\kappa _{9}\\[1pt] & \displaystyle\phi _{8}=\left[J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+\left (\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}\right)\lambda \right]/\kappa _{8}\\[1pt] & \displaystyle\phi _{3}=\left (J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}+\eta _{c}\cdot \lambda \right) \big/\kappa _{3},\phi _{4}=J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} \big/\kappa _{4},\\[1pt] & \displaystyle\phi _{5}=\left (\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}\right)\lambda \big/\kappa _{5},\phi _{6}=J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\big/\kappa _{6},\\[1pt] & \displaystyle\phi _{i}=\eta _{i}\cdot \lambda /\kappa _{i}\qquad\left (i=a1,a2,b,c,d\right).\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

By substituting Equation S90 into Equation S88, we have:(S91){Jr(E,py)+Jf(E,py)=φpy⋅λ,Jr(E,py)εr(py)+Jf(E,py)εf(py)=ϕmax−ψpy⋅λ.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}+J_{f}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}=\varphi _{\text{py}}\cdot \lambda ,\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \frac{J_{r}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}}{\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}+\frac{J_{f}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}}{\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}=\phi _{\rm max}- \psi _{\text{py}}\cdot \lambda .\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

Here, Jr(E,py)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}$\end{document} and Jf(E,py)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}$\end{document} stand for the normalized energy fluxes of respiration and fermentation, respectively, with(S92){Jr(E,py)=βr(py)⋅Jr(N),Jf(E,py)=βf(py)⋅Jf(N).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}J_{r}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}=\beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\cdot J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)},\\J_{f}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}=\beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\cdot J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}.\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

where βr(py)=β3+β4+β8\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}=\beta _{3}+\beta _{4}+\beta _{8}$\end{document} and βf(py)=β6+β8\begin{document}$\beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}=\beta _{6}+\beta _{8}$\end{document}, with βr(py)=10\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}=10$\end{document} and βf(py)=3\begin{document}$\beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}=3$\end{document} for E. coli. The coefficients εr(py)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}$\end{document} and εf(py)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}$\end{document} represent the proteome efficiencies for energy biogenesis using pyruvate in respiration and fermentation pathways, respectively, with(S93){εr(py)=βr(py)1/κpy+1/κ8+1/κ3+1/κ4,εf(py)=βf(py)1/κpy+1/κ8+1/κ6.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} \varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)} &= \displaystyle \frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}{1\big/\kappa _{\text{py}}+1\big/\kappa _{8}+1\big/\kappa _{3}+1\big/\kappa _{4}},\\[1pt]\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)} &= \displaystyle \frac{\beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}{1\big/\kappa _{\text{py}}+1\big/\kappa _{8}+1\big/\kappa _{6}}.\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

ψpy−1\begin{document}$\psi _{\text{py}}^{- 1}$\end{document} is the proteome efficiency for biomass generation using pyruvate in the biomass synthesis pathway, with(S94)ψpy=1κt+1+ηa1+ηcκpy+1−ηb+ηa1κ7+ηb+ηcκ8+ηa1κ9+ηcκ3+ηc+ηdκ5+∑ia1,a2,b,c,dηiκi\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \psi _{\text{py}}=\frac{1}{\kappa _{\rm t}}+\frac{1+\eta _{a1}+\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{\text{py}}}+\frac{1- \eta _{b}+\eta _{a1}}{\kappa _{7}}+\frac{\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{8}}+\frac{\eta _{a1}}{\kappa _{9}}+\frac{\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{3}}+\frac{\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}}{\kappa _{5}}+\sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}\frac{\eta _{i}}{\kappa _{i}}$$\end{document}

φpy\begin{document}$\varphi _{\text{py}}$\end{document} is an energy demand coefficient (a constant), with(S95)φpy≡ηE+β7⋅(1−ηb+ηa1)+β9⋅ηa1−β8⋅(ηc+ηb)−β3⋅ηc−βa1⋅ηa1,\begin{document}$$\varphi _{\text{py}}\equiv \eta _{\text{E}}+\beta _{7}\cdot \left (1- \eta _{b}+\eta _{a1}\right)+\beta _{9}\cdot \eta _{a1}- \beta _{8}\cdot \left (\eta _{c}+\eta _{b}\right)- \beta _{3}\cdot \eta _{c}- \beta _{a1}\cdot \eta _{a1},$$\end{document}

Evidently, Equation S91 is identical in form with Equation S29. The growth rate changes into κpy\begin{document}$\kappa _{\text{py}}$\end{document} dependent:(S96)λ(κpy)={ϕmaxφpy/εr(py)(κpy)+ψpy(κpy)εr(py)(κpy)>εf(py)(κpy),ϕmaxφpy/εf(py)(κpy)+ψpy(κpy)εr(py)(κpy)<εf(py)(κpy).\begin{document}$$\lambda \left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right)=\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi _{\text{py}}\big/\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right)+\psi _{\text{py}}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right),\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi _{\text{py}}\big/\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right)+\psi _{\text{py}}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right).\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

When κpy\begin{document}$\kappa _{\text{py}}$\end{document} is very small, combined with Equation S93, then,(S97){εr(py)(κpy→0)≈βr(py)⋅κpy,εf(py)(κpy→0)≈βf(py)⋅κpy.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\rightarrow 0\right)\approx \beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\cdot \kappa _{\text{py}},\\\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\rightarrow 0\right)\approx \beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\cdot \kappa _{\text{py}}.\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

Obviously, βr(py)≫βf(py)\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\gg \beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}$\end{document}, and hence(S98)εr(py)(κpy→0)>εf(py)(κpy→0).\begin{document}$$\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\rightarrow 0\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\rightarrow 0\right).$$\end{document}

As long as(S99)βr(py)−βf(py)κpy(ST)<βf(py)(1κ8+1κ3+1κ4)−βr(py)⋅(1κ8+1κ6),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}- \beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}{\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}} \lt \beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\frac{1}{\kappa _{8}}+\frac{1}{\kappa _{3}}+\frac{1}{\kappa _{4}}\right)- \beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\cdot \left (\frac{1}{\kappa _{8}}+\frac{1}{\kappa _{6}}\right),$$\end{document}

where the superscript ‘(ST)’ stands for the saturated concentration, then,(S100)εr(py)(κpy(ST))<εf(py)(κpy(ST)),\begin{document}$$\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}\right),$$\end{document}

and there exists a critical value of κpy\begin{document}$\kappa _{\text{py}}$\end{document}, denoted as κpy(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}$\end{document}, with(S101){εr(py)(κpy(C))=εf(py)(κpy(C))=βr(py)−βf(py)1/κ3+1/κ4−1/κ6=β3+β4−β61/κ3+1/κ4−1/κ6,λC(py)≡λ(κpy(C))=ϕmaxφpy/εr/f(py)(κpy(C))+ψpy(κpy(C)).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=\frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}- \beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}{1\big/\kappa _{3}+1 \big/\kappa _{4}- 1/\kappa _{6}}=\frac{\beta _{3}+\beta _{4}- \beta _{6}}{1 \big/\kappa _{3}+1 \big/\kappa _{4}- 1 \big/\kappa _{6}}\text{,}\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=\frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi _{\text{py}} \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi _{\text{py}}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)}\text{.}\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

Here, λC(py)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}$\end{document} is the growth rate at the transition point, and εr/f(py)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r/f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}$\end{document} stands for either εr(py)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}$\end{document} or εf(py)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}$\end{document}. In Appendix 1—figure 2H, we show the dependencies of εr(py)(κpy)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right)$\end{document}, εf(py)(κpy)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right)$\end{document} and λ(κpy)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{\text{py}}\right)$\end{document} on κpy\begin{document}$\kappa _{\text{py}}$\end{document} in a 3-dimensional form. In the homogeneous case, Jf(E,py)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}$\end{document} and Jr(E,py)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}$\end{document} follow:(S102){Jf(E,py)=φpy⋅λ⋅θ(λ−λC(py)),Jr(E,py)=φpy⋅λ⋅[1−θ(λ−λC(py))].\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left( \text{E,py} \right)} = \varphi_{\text{py}} \cdot \lambda \cdot \theta \left( \lambda - \lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left( \text{py} \right)} \right), \\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left( \text{E,py} \right)} = \varphi_{\text{py}} \cdot \lambda \cdot \left[1 - \theta \left( \lambda - \lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left( \text{py} \right)} \right) \right]. \end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

Defining λmax(py)=λ(κpy(ST))\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}=\lambda \left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}\right)$\end{document}, and then, [0,λmax(py)]\begin{document}$\left[0,\lambda _{\rm max}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\right]$\end{document} is the relevant range of the x axis. To compare with experiments, we assume the same extent of extrinsic noise in kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} as specified in Appendix 3.3. Then, λC(py)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}$\end{document} approximately follows a Gaussian distribution:(S103)λC(py)∼N(μλC(py),σλC(py)2),\begin{document}$$\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}},\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}^{2}\right),$$\end{document}

where μλC(py)\begin{document}$\mu_{\lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}$\end{document} and σλC(py)\begin{document}$\sigma_{\lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}$\end{document} stand for the mean and standard deviation of λC(py)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}$\end{document}. Then, the relations between the normalized energy fluxes and growth rate are:(S104){Jf(E,py)(λ)=12φpy⋅λ⋅[erf(λ−μλC(py)2σλC(py))+1],Jr(E,py)(λ)=12φpy⋅λ⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC(py)2σλC(py))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{1}{2}\varphi_{\text{py}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}}\right)+1\right],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{E,py}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{1}{2}\varphi_{\text{py}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu_{\lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma_{\lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}}\right)\right].\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

Combined with Equation S92, we have:(S105){Jf(N)(λ)=φpy2βf(py)⋅λ⋅[erf(λ−μλC(py)2σλC(py))+1],Jr(N)(λ)=φpy2βr(py)⋅λ⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC(py)2σλC(py))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{\varphi _{\text{py}}}{2\beta _{f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}}\right)+1\right],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{\varphi _{\text{py}}}{2\beta _{r}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu_{\lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}}\right)\right].\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}
In Figure 3F, we show that the model predictions (Equation S105) align quantitatively with the experimental results (Holms, 1996).

sec.title: 5.2 Mixture of a Group A carbon source with extracellular amino acids
sec.p: In the case of a Group A carbon source mixed with amino acids, the coarse-grained model is shown in Appendix 1—figure 2A. This model can be used to analyze mixtures with one or multiple types of extracellular amino acids. Here, Equations S21, S22, S24 and S25 still apply, but Equation S23 changes to (the case of i=a1\begin{document}$i=a1$\end{document} remains the same as Equation S23):(S106)Φi⋅ξi⋅NEPicarbon+Φi′⋅ξi′⋅NPicarbon=ri⋅JBM(i=a2,b,c,d).\begin{document}$${\Phi _i} \cdot {\xi _i} \cdot N_{{\rm{E}}{{\rm{P}}_i}}^{{\rm{carbon}}} + \Phi _i^\prime \cdot \xi _i^\prime \cdot N_{{{\rm{P}}_i}}^{{\rm{carbon}}} = {r_i} \cdot {J_{{\rm{BM}}}}\,\,\,\,\,\, (i=a2,b,c,d).$$\end{document}

Here, NPicarbon\begin{document}$N_{\text{P}_{i}}^{\text{carbon}}$\end{document} represents the number of carbon atoms in a molecule of Pool i. For simplicity, we assume:(S107)NPicarbon≈NEPicarbon.\begin{document}$$N_{\text{P}_{i}}^{\text{carbon}}\approx N_{\text{EP}_{i}}^{\text{carbon}}.$$\end{document}

In the case where all 21 types of amino acids are present and each is at saturated concentration (denoted as ‘21AA’), we have:(S108){ϕA⋅κA=ϕ1⋅κ1+ϕa1⋅κa1,2ϕ1⋅κ1=ϕ2⋅κ2+ϕ5⋅κ5+ϕa2⋅κa2,ϕ2⋅κ2=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕ6⋅κ6+ϕb⋅κb,ϕ5⋅κ5+ϕ4⋅κ4=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕd⋅κd,ϕ3⋅κ3=ϕ4⋅κ4+ϕc⋅κc,ϕa1⋅κa1=ηa1⋅λ,ϕa2⋅κa2+ϕa2(21AA)⋅κa2(21AA)=ηa2⋅λ,ϕb⋅κb+ϕb(21AA)⋅κb(21AA)=ηb⋅λ,ϕc⋅κc+ϕc(21AA)⋅κc(21AA)=ηc⋅λ,ϕd⋅κd+ϕd(21AA)⋅κd(21AA)=ηd⋅λ,β1⋅ϕ1⋅κ1+β2⋅ϕ2⋅κ2+β3⋅ϕ3⋅κ3+β4⋅ϕ4⋅κ4+β6⋅ϕ6⋅κ6+βa1⋅ϕa1⋅κa1=JE(N),JE(N)=ηE⋅λ,λ=ϕR⋅κt,Jr(N)=ϕ4⋅κ4,Jf(N)=ϕ6⋅κ6,ϕR+ϕA+∑i6ϕi+∑ja1,a2,b,c,dϕj+ϕa2(21AA)+ϕb(21AA)+ϕc(21AA)+ϕd(21AA)=ϕmax,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\phi _A} \cdot {\kappa _A} = {\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1} + {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}},\\ 2{\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1} = {\phi _2} \cdot {\kappa _2} + {\phi _5} \cdot {\kappa _5} + {\phi _{a2}} \cdot {\kappa _{a2}},\\ {\phi _2} \cdot {\kappa _2} = {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6} + {\phi _b} \cdot {\kappa _b},\\ {\phi _5} \cdot {\kappa _5} + {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} = {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\phi _d} \cdot {\kappa _d},\\ {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} = {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} + {\phi _c} \cdot {\kappa _c},\\ {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}} = {\eta _{a1}} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _{a2}} \cdot {\kappa _{a2}} + \phi _{a2}^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} \cdot \kappa _{a2}^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} = {\eta _{a2}} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _b} \cdot {\kappa _b} + \phi _b^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} \cdot \kappa _b^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} = {\eta _b} \cdot \lambda ,\\ {\phi _c} \cdot {\kappa _c} + \phi _c^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} \cdot \kappa _c^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} = {\eta _c} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _d} \cdot {\kappa _d} + \phi _d^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} \cdot \kappa _d^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} = {\eta _d} \cdot \lambda ,\\ {\beta _1} \cdot {\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1} + {\beta _2} \cdot {\phi _2} \cdot {\kappa _2} + {\beta _3} \cdot {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\beta _4} \cdot {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} + {\beta _6} \cdot {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6} + {\beta _{a1}} \cdot {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}} = J_{\rm{E}}^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)},\\ J_{\rm{E}}^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\eta _{\rm{E}}} \cdot \lambda ,\lambda = {\phi _R} \cdot {\kappa _{\rm t}},J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4},J_f^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6},\\ {\phi _{\rm{R}}} + {\phi _A} + \sum\limits_i^6 {{\phi _i}} + \sum\limits_j^{a1,a2,b,c,d} {{\phi _j}} + \phi _{a2}^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} + \phi _b^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} + \phi _c^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} + \phi _d^{\left( {{\rm{21AA}}} \right)} = {\phi _{\max }}, \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

where ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} and κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} are defined following Equations S9 and S12. Since the cell growth rate significantly increases with the mixture of amino acids, we deduce that Pools a2-d are supplied by amino acids in growth optimization, with(S109)ϕi=0(i=a2,b,c,d)\begin{document}$$\phi _{i}=0 \,\, \,\, \,\,\left (i=a2,b,c,d\right)$$\end{document}

Amino acids should be more efficient in the supply of biomass synthesis than the Group A carbon source for Pools a2-d, i.e.,(S110){1/κa2(21AA)<1/κa2+1/(2κ1)+1/(2κA),1/κb(21AA)<1/κb+1/κ2+1/(2κ1)+1/(2κA),1/κc(21AA)<1/κc+1/κ5+1/κ3+1/κ2+1/κ1+1/κA,1/κd(21AA)<1/κd+1/κ5+1/(2κ1)+1/(2κA).\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}1 \big/\kappa _{a2}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)} \lt 1/\kappa _{a2}+1 \big/\left (2\kappa _{1}\right)+1 \big/\left (2\kappa _{A}\right),\\1 \big/\kappa _{b}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)} \lt 1 \big/\kappa _{b}+1/\kappa _{2}+1 \big/\left (2\kappa _{1}\right)+1 \big/\left (2\kappa _{A}\right),\\1 \big/\kappa _{c}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)} \lt 1 \big/\kappa _{c}+1 \big/\kappa _{5}+1 \big/\kappa _{3}+1 \big/\kappa _{2}+1 \big/\kappa _{1}+1 \big/\kappa _{A},\\1 \big/\kappa _{d}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)} \lt 1 \big/\kappa _{d}+1 \big/\kappa _{5}+1 \big/\left (2\kappa _{1}\right)+1 \big/\left (2\kappa _{A}\right).\end{array} \right.$$\end{document}

In practice, the requirement for proteome efficiency when using amino acids is even higher, since the biomass synthesis pathway is accompanied by energy biogenesis for Group A carbon sources, but not for amino acids. Combining Equations S108 and S109, we have:(S111){Jr(E)+Jf(E)=φ21AA⋅λ,Jr(E)εr+Jf(E)εf=ϕmax−ψ21AA⋅λ,\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}+J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}=\varphi _{\text{21AA}}\cdot \lambda ,\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \frac{J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}}{\varepsilon _{r}}+\frac{J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}}{\varepsilon _{f}}=\phi _{\rm max}- \psi _{\text{21AA}}\cdot \lambda ,\end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

where Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document}, Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} follow Equation S30, while εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document} follow Equation S31. ψ21AA−1\begin{document}${\psi}_{\text{21AA}}^{- 1}$\end{document} is the proteome efficiency for biomass generation in the biomass synthesis pathway under this nutrient condition, with(S112)ψ21AA=1κt+ηa1κA+ηa1κa1+ηa2κa2(21AA)+ηbκb(21AA)+ηcκc(21AA)+ηdκd(21AA)\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {\psi}_{\text{21AA}}=\frac{1}{\kappa _{t}}+\frac{\eta _{a1}}{\kappa _{A}}+\frac{\eta _{a1}}{\kappa _{a1}}+\frac{\eta _{a2}}{\kappa _{a2}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}}+\frac{\eta _{b}}{\kappa _{b}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}}+\frac{\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{c}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}}+\frac{\eta _{d}}{\kappa _{d}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}}$$\end{document}

φ21AA\begin{document}${\varphi}_{\text{21AA}}$\end{document} is an energy demand coefficient, with(S113)φ21AA≡ηE−βa1⋅ηa1\begin{document}$$\varphi _{\text{21AA}}\equiv \eta _{\text{E}}- \beta _{a1}\cdot \eta _{a1}$$\end{document}

Combining Equations S111 and S31, the formula for the growth rate is:(S114)λ(κA)={λr(21AA)=ϕmaxφ21AA/εr(κA)+ψ21AA(κA)εr(κA)>εf(κA),λf(21AA)=ϕmaxφ21AA/εf(κA)+ψ21AA(κA)εr(κA)<εf(κA).\begin{document}$$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A}\right)=\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \lambda _{r}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}= \frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi _{\text{21AA}} \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi _{\text{21AA}}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \lambda _{f}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}= \frac{\phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi _{\text{21AA}} \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi _{\text{21AA}}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right).\end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

In fact, Equations S37-S42 still apply. εr/f(κA(C))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)$\end{document} satisfies Equation S43, while λC(21AA)≡λ(κA(C))\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)$\end{document} and λmax(21AA)≡λ(κAmax)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\rm max}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)$\end{document} are:(S115){λC(21AA)=ϕmaxφ21AAεr/f(κA(C))+ψ21AA(κA(C)),λmax(21AA)=ϕmaxφ21AAεf(κAmax)+ψ21AA(κAmax).\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \lambda_{\text{C}}^{\left( \text{21AA} \right)} = \frac{\phi_{\text{max}}}{\frac{\varphi_{\text{21AA}}}{\varepsilon_{r/f} \left( \kappa_A^{\left( \text{C} \right)} \right)} + \psi_{\text{21AA}} \left( \kappa_A^{\left( \text{C} \right)} \right)}, \\[1pt] & \displaystyle \lambda_{\text{max}}^{\left( \text{21AA} \right)} = \frac{\phi_{\text{max}}}{\frac{\varphi_{\text{21AA}}}{\varepsilon_f \left( \kappa_A^{\text{max}} \right)} + \psi_{\text{21AA}} \left( \kappa_A^{\text{max}} \right)}. \end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

When extrinsic noise is taken into account, λC(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}$\end{document} approximately follows a Gaussian distribution:(S116)λC(21AA)∼N(μλC(21AA),σλC(21AA)2),\begin{document}$$\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}},\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}}^{2}\right),$$\end{document}

and the normalized fluxes Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} change to:(S117){Jf(N)(λ)=φ21AAβf(A)⋅λ⋅[erf(λ−μλC(21AA)2σλC(21AA))+1],Jr(N)(λ)=φ21AAβr(A)⋅λ⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC(21AA)2σλC(21AA))].\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{\varphi _{\text{21AA}}}{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}}}\right)+1\right],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{\varphi _{\text{21AA}}}{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}\cdot \lambda \cdot \left[1- \text{erf}\left (\frac{\lambda - \mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}}}{\sqrt{2}\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}}}\right)\right].\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

The above analysis can be extended to cases where a Group A carbon source is mixed with arbitrary combinations of amino acids. Equations S111, S114-S117 would remain in a similar form, while Equations S112-S113 would change depending on the combinations of amino acid. In Appendix 1—figure 2B and C, we compare model predictions (see also Appendix 8.2 and Equation S157) with experimental data (Basan et al., 2015; Wallden et al., 2016) from mixtures of 21 or 7 types of amino acids along with a Group A carbon source, demonstrating quantitative agreement. Additionally, the increase in the critical threshold of growth rate for the growth rate-dependent fermentation flux in mixtures with extracellular amino acids (i.e. λC(21AA),λC(7AA)>λC\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)},\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{7AA}\right)} \gt \lambda _{\text{C}}$\end{document}; see Appendix 1—figure 2C) has also been observed in other experimental findings (Peebo et al., 2015).

sec.title: 6.1 Carbon limitation within Group A carbon sources
sec.p: In Equation S28, we present the model predictions for the dependencies of enzyme proteomic mass fractions on growth rate and energy fluxes. To compare with experiments, we assume the same extent of extrinsic noise in kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} as specified in Appendix 3.3. Relative protein expression data for enzymes within glycolysis and the TCA cycle are available from existing studies and are comparable to the ϕ1-ϕ4\begin{document}$\phi _{1}\text{-}\phi _{4}$\end{document} enzymes of our model (Figure 1B). Upon κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} perturbation, κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} is a variable while w0\begin{document}$w_{0}$\end{document} is fixed (see Appendix 2.5). Combining Equations S28 and S47 (with w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document}), we obtain:(S118){ϕ1=λκ1{φ⋅(βr(A)−βf(A))2βr(A)⋅βf(A)⋅[erf(λ−μλC2σλC)+1]+φβr(A)+ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd2},ϕ2=λκ2{φ⋅(βr(A)−βf(A))βr(A)⋅βf(A)⋅[erf(λ−μλC2σλC)+1]+2φβr(A)+ηb+ηc},ϕ3=λκ3{φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC2σλC)]+ηc},ϕ4=λκ4⋅φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC2σλC)].\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} {\phi _1} &= \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _1}}}\left\{ {\frac{{\varphi \cdot \left( {\beta _r^{\left( A \right)} - \beta _f^{\left( A \right)}} \right)}}{{2\beta _r^{\left( A \right)} \cdot \beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right) + 1} \right] + \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} + \frac{{{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}}}{2}} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _2} &= \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _2}}}\left\{ {\frac{{\varphi \cdot \left( {\beta _r^{\left( A \right)} - \beta _f^{\left( A \right)}} \right)}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)} \cdot \beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right) + 1} \right] + \frac{{2\varphi }}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} + {\eta _b} + {\eta _c}} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _3} &= \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _3}}}\left\{ {\frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right)} \right] + {\eta _c}} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _4} &= \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _4}}} \cdot \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right)} \right]. \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

In Appendix 1—figure 3C and D, we show the comparisons between model predictions (Equation S118, w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document}) and experimental data (Hui et al., 2015), which are consistent overall. We then consider the influence of maintenance energy as specified in Appendix 4.2. Here, we continue to choose w0=2.5 (h−1)\begin{document}$w_{0}=2.5\text{\ }\left (h^{- 1}\right)$\end{document} as previously adopted in Appendix 4.3. Thus, Equation S28 still holds. Combined with Equation S85 under the condition that ι=0\begin{document}$\iota =0$\end{document}, we have:(S119){ϕ1=12⋅κ1{φ⋅λ+w0βf(A)⋅[erf(λ−μλC2σλC)+1]+φ⋅λ+w0βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC2σλC)]+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)λ},ϕ2=1κ2{φ⋅λ+w0βf(A)⋅[erf(λ−μλC2σλC)+1]+φ⋅λ+w0βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC2σλC)]+(ηb+ηc)λ},ϕ3=1κ3{φ⋅λ+w0βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC2σλC)]+ηc⋅λ},ϕ4=1κ4⋅φ⋅λ+w0βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC2σλC)].\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{lll} {\phi _1} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{2 \cdot {\kappa _1}}}\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + {w_0}}}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right) + 1} \right] + \frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + {w_0}}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right)} \right] \\+ \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right)\lambda \end{array} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _2} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\kappa _2}}}\left\{ {\frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + {w_0}}}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right) + 1} \right] + \frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + {w_0}}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right)} \right] + \left( {{\eta _b} + {\eta _c}} \right)\lambda } \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _3} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\kappa _3}}}\left\{ {\frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + {w_0}}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right)} \right] + {\eta _c} \cdot \lambda } \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _4} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\kappa _4}}} \cdot \frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + {w_0}}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}}}} \right)} \right]. \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

In Figure 4A–B, we show that the model predictions (Equation S119, w0=2.5(h−1)\begin{document}$w_{0}=2.5\, (h^{- 1})$\end{document}) generally agree with the experiments (Hui et al., 2015). However, there are different basal expressions of these enzymes, likely due to living demands other than cell proliferation, such as preparation for starvation (Mori et al., 2017) or changes in the type of the nutrient (Basan et al., 2020; Kussell and Leibler, 2005).

sec.title: 6.2 Overexpression of useless proteins
sec.p: In the case of ϕZ\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}$\end{document} perturbation under each nutrient condition with fixed κA\begin{document}$\kappa_{A}$\end{document} (see Appendix 4.1), we consider the same extent of extrinsic noise in kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} as specified in Appendix 3.3. The relation between enzyme allocation and growth rate can be obtained by combining Equations S28 and S58 (with w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document}):(S120){ϕ1=λ2⋅κ1{(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)+φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]+φβf(A)⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1]},ϕ2=λκ2{(ηb+ηc)+φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]+φβf(A)⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1]},ϕ3=λκ3{φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]+ηc},ϕ4=λκ4{φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]}.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} {\phi _1} &= \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{2 \cdot {\kappa _1}}}\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right) + \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right]\\ + \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right) + 1} \right] \end{array} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _2} &= \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _2}}}\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \left( {{\eta _b} + {\eta _c}} \right) + \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right]\\ + \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right) + 1} \right] \end{array} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _3} &= \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _3}}}\left\{ {\frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right] + {\eta _c}} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _4} &= \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _4}}}\left\{ {\frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right]} \right\}. \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

Here λ(κA,0)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)$\end{document} is the growth rate for ϕZ=0\begin{document}$\phi _{Z}=0$\end{document}, and thus it is a parameter rather than a variable. The growth rate is defined as λ(κA,ϕZ)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document}, which follows Equation S50. Thus, ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} is proportional to the growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document}. In Appendix 1—figure 3E and F, we observe that the model predictions (Equation S120) generally agree with the experiments (Basan et al., 2015). Next, we consider the influence of maintenance energy with w0=2.5 (h−1)\begin{document}$w_{0}=2.5\text{\ }\left (h^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}. Combining Equations S28, S58 and S85 (with ι=0\begin{document}$\iota =0$\end{document}), we get:(S121){ϕ1=w02κ1{1βf(A)⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1]+1βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]}+λ2κ1{φβf(A)⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1]+φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)},ϕ2=w0κ2{1βf(A)⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1]+1βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]}+λκ2{φβf(A)⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1]+φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]+(ηb+ηc)},ϕ3=λκ3{φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]+ηc}+w0κ3⋅1βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))],ϕ4=λκ4⋅φβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]+w0κ4⋅1βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))].\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} &{\phi _1} = \displaystyle \frac{{{w_0}}}{{2{\kappa _1}}}\left\{ {\frac{1}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right) + 1} \right] + \frac{1}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right]} \right\}\\[1pt] &+ \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{2{\kappa _1}}}\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right) + 1} \right] + \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right]\\ + \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right) \end{array} \right\},\\[1pt] &{\phi _2} = \displaystyle \frac{{{w_0}}}{{{\kappa _2}}}\left\{ {\frac{1}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right) + 1} \right] + \frac{1}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right]} \right\}\\[1pt] &+ \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _2}}}\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right) + 1} \right] + \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right]\\[1pt] &+ \displaystyle \left( {{\eta _b} + {\eta _c}} \right) \end{array} \right\},\\[1pt] & {\phi _3} = \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _3}}}\left\{ {\frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right] + {\eta _c}} \right\}\\[1pt] &+ \displaystyle \frac{{{w_0}}}{{{\kappa _3}}} \cdot \frac{1}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right],\\[1pt] & {\phi _4} = \displaystyle \frac{\lambda }{{{\kappa _4}}} \cdot \frac{\varphi }{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right] + \frac{{{w_0}}}{{{\kappa _4}}} \cdot \frac{1}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right]. \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

Here, the growth rate is defined as λ(κA,ϕZ)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},\phi _{\text{Z}}\right)$\end{document}, and λ(κA,0)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)$\end{document} is a parameter rather than a variable. Thus, ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} is a linear function of the growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document}, with a positive slope and a positive y-intercept. In Figure 4C–D and Appendix 1—figure 3I-J, we show that the model predictions (Equation S121) agree quantitively with the experimental data (Basan et al., 2015).

sec.title: 6.3 Energy dissipation
sec.p: In the case of energy dissipation under each nutrient condition, w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is perturbed while κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} is fixed. The relation between protein allocation and growth rate can be obtained by combining Equations S28 and S70. However, since w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is explicitly present in Equation S70, it is necessary to reduce this variable to obtain the growth rate dependence of enzyme allocation.
