From Equation S64, we have:(S122)λ(κA,w)=λ(κA,0){1−wϕmax⋅[1εr(κA)−θ(εf(κA)−εr(κA))⋅(1εr(κA)−1εf(κA))]}.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},w} \right) = \lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right)\left\{ {1 - \frac{w}{{{\phi _{\max }}}} \cdot \left[ {\frac{1}{{{\varepsilon _r}\left( {{\kappa _A}} \right)}} - \theta \left( {{\varepsilon _f}\left( {{\kappa _A}} \right) - {\varepsilon _r}\left( {{\kappa _A}} \right)} \right) \cdot \left( {\frac{1}{{{\varepsilon _r}\left( {{\kappa _A}} \right)}} - \frac{1}{{{\varepsilon _f}\left( {{\kappa _A}} \right)}}} \right)} \right]} \right\}.$$\end{document}

Here, λ(κA,0)≡λ(κA,w=0)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)\equiv \lambda \left (\kappa _{A},w=0\right)$\end{document} (satisfying Equation S64) is a parameter rather than a variable. ‘θ\begin{document}$\theta $\end{document}’ stands for the Heaviside step function. Thus, we have:(S123)w(λ)=ϕmax⋅[1−λ/λ(κA,0)][1/εr(κA)−θ(εf(κA)−εr(κA))⋅(1/εr(κA)−1/εf(κA))],\begin{document}$$\displaystyle w\left (\lambda \right)=\frac{\phi _{\rm max}\cdot \left[1- \lambda \big/\lambda \left (\kappa _{A},0\right)\right]}{\left[1 \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)- \theta \left (\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)- \varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)\right)\cdot \left (1 \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)- 1 \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)\right)\right]},$$\end{document}
where the energy dissipation coefficient w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is regarded as a function of the growth rate.

Combining Equations S28, S70 and S123, we get:(S124){ϕ1=12κ1{erf(λ−μλC(0)[1−w(λ)εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]2σλC(0)[1−w(λ)εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax])⋅[φ⋅λ+w(λ)βf(A)−φ⋅λ+w(λ)βr(A)]+[φ⋅λ+w(λ)](1βf(A)−1βr(A)+2βr(A))+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)⋅λ},ϕ2=1κ2{erf(λ−μλC(0)[1−w(λ)εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]2σλC(0)[1−w(λ)εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax])⋅[φ⋅λ+w(λ)βf(A)−φ⋅λ+w(λ)βr(A)]+[φ⋅λ+w(λ)](1βf(A)−1βr(A)+2βr(A))+(ηb+ηc)⋅λ},ϕ3=1κ3{[φ⋅λ+w(λ)]βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC(0)[1−w(λ)εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]2σλC(0)[1−w(λ)εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax])]+ηc⋅λ},ϕ4=1κ4⋅[φ⋅λ+w(λ)]βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ−μλC(0)[1−w(λ)εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax]2σλC(0)[1−w(λ)εr/f(κA(C))ϕmax])],\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} {\phi _1} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{2{\kappa _1}}}\left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)\left[ {1 - \frac{{w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right){\phi _{\max }}}}} \right]}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)\left[ {1 - \frac{{w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right){\phi _{\max }}}}} \right]}}} \right) \cdot \left[ {\frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} - \frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}}} \right]\\ + \left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right]\left( {\frac{1}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} - \frac{1}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} + \frac{2}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}}} \right) + \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right) \cdot \lambda \end{array} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _2} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\kappa _2}}}\left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)\left[ {1 - \frac{{w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right){\phi _{\max }}}}} \right]}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)\left[ {1 - \frac{{w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right){\phi _{\max }}}}} \right]}}} \right) \cdot \left[ {\frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} - \frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}}} \right]\\ + \left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right]\left( {\frac{1}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} - \frac{1}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} + \frac{2}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}}} \right) + \left( {{\eta _b} + {\eta _c}} \right) \cdot \lambda \end{array} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _3} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\kappa _3}}}\left\{ {\frac{{\left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right]}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)\left[ {1 - \frac{{w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right){\phi _{\max }}}}} \right]}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)\left[ {1 - \frac{{w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right){\phi _{\max }}}}} \right]}}} \right)} \right] + {\eta _c} \cdot \lambda } \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _4} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\kappa _4}}} \cdot \frac{{\left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right]}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)\left[ {1 - \frac{{w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right){\phi _{\max }}}}} \right]}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)\left[ {1 - \frac{{w\left( \lambda \right)}}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right){\phi _{\max }}}}} \right]}}} \right)} \right], \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

where w(λ)\begin{document}$w\left (\lambda \right)$\end{document} follows Equation S123. When κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} lies in the vicinity of κA(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}$\end{document} or w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is small so that(S125)(1−wεr/f(κA)⋅ϕmax)/(1−wεr/f(κA)⋅ϕmax)(1−wεr/f(κA(C))⋅ϕmax)(1−wεr/f(κA(C))⋅ϕmax)≈1\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {{\left( {1 - \frac{w}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {{\kappa _A}} \right) \cdot {\phi _{\max }}}}} \right)} \mathord{\left/ {\vphantom {{\left( {1 - \frac{w}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {{\kappa _A}} \right) \cdot {\phi _{\max }}}}} \right)} {\left( {1 - \frac{w}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right) \cdot {\phi _{\max }}}}} \right)}}} \right. } {\left( {1 - \frac{w}{{{\varepsilon _{r/f}}\left( {\kappa _A^{\left( {\rm{C}} \right)}} \right) \cdot {\phi _{\max }}}}} \right)}} \approx 1 $$\end{document}

then we have:(S126){Jf(N)(λ,w)=φ⋅λ+wβf(A)⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1],Jr(N)(λ,w)=φ⋅λ+wβr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))],\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_{f}^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)}\left( {\lambda ,w} \right) = \frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + w}}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right) + 1} \right],\\[1pt] & \displaystyle J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)}\left( {\lambda ,w} \right) = \frac{{\varphi \cdot \lambda + w}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right]{\rm{, }} \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

and thus:(s127){ϕ1=12κ1{[φ⋅λ+w(λ)](1βf(A)−1βr(A))⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1]+2βr(A)[φ⋅λ+w(λ)]+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)⋅λ},ϕ2=1κ2{[φ⋅λ+w(λ)](1βf(A)−1βr(A))⋅[erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))+1]+2βr(A)[φ⋅λ+w(λ)]+(ηb+ηc)⋅λ},ϕ3=1κ3{[φ⋅λ+w(λ)]βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))]+ηc⋅λ},ϕ4=1κ4⋅[φ⋅λ+w(λ)]βr(A)⋅[1−erf(λ(κA,0)−μλC(0)2σλC(0))],\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} {\phi _1} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{2{\kappa _1}}}\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right]\left( {\frac{1}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} - \frac{1}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}}} \right) \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right) + 1} \right]\\ + \frac{2}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}}\left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right] + \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right) \cdot \lambda \end{array} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _2} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\kappa _2}}}\left\{ \begin{array}{l} \left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right]\left( {\frac{1}{{\beta _f^{\left( A \right)}}} - \frac{1}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}}} \right) \cdot \left[ {{\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right) + 1} \right]\\ + \frac{2}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}}\left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right] + \left( {{\eta _b} + {\eta _c}} \right) \cdot \lambda \end{array} \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _3} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\kappa _3}}}\left\{ {\frac{{\left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right]}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right] + {\eta _c} \cdot \lambda } \right\},\\[1pt] {\phi _4} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\kappa _4}}} \cdot \frac{{\left[ {\varphi \cdot \lambda + w\left( \lambda \right)} \right]}}{{\beta _r^{\left( A \right)}}} \cdot \left[ {1 - {\rm{erf}}\left( {\frac{{\lambda \left( {{\kappa _A},0} \right) - {\mu _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}{{\sqrt 2 {\sigma _{{\lambda _{\rm{C}}}}}\left( 0 \right)}}} \right)} \right], \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

Note that in Equation S123, w\begin{document}$w$\end{document} is a linear function of λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} with a negative slope. Thus ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} exhibits a linear relation with λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} when Equation S125 is satisfied (see Equation S127). In fact, the slope of ϕ4\begin{document}$\phi _{4}$\end{document} is certainly negative (combining Equations S64, S123 and S127), while the sign of the slope for other ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} depends on parameters. For a given nutrient, the enzymes corresponding to the same ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} should exhibit the same slope sign. Another restriction is that if the slope sign of ϕ1\begin{document}$\phi _{1}$\end{document} is negative, then the slope sign of ϕ2\begin{document}$\phi _{2}$\end{document} is surely negative. In Appendix 1—figure 3K-N, we show that our model results agree well with the experimental data (Basan et al., 2015; Equation S127).

sec.title: 7.1 A coarse-grained model with more details
sec.p: To compare with experiments, we consider a coarse-grained model with more details, as shown in Appendix 1—figure 2F. Here, nodes M6, M7 represent GA3P and DHAP, respectively. Other nodes follow the descriptions specified in Appendix 3.1. Each biochemical reaction follows Equation S5 with bi=1\begin{document}$b_{i}=1$\end{document} except that M1→M6+M7 and M3+M5→M4. By applying flux balance to the stoichiometric fluxes, combined with Equation S8, we obtain:(S128){ΦA⋅ξA=Φ1⋅ξ1+Φa1⋅ξa1,Φ11⋅ξ11=Φ10⋅ξ10+Φ1⋅ξ1,Φ10⋅ξ10=Φ1⋅ξ1,Φ11⋅ξ11=Φ2⋅ξ2+Φ5⋅ξ5+Φa2⋅ξa2,Φ2⋅ξ2=Φ3⋅ξ3+Φ6⋅ξ6+Φb⋅ξb,Φ5⋅ξ5+Φ4⋅ξ4=Φ3⋅ξ3+Φd⋅ξd,Φ3⋅ξ3=Φ4⋅ξ4+Φc⋅ξc.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\Phi _A} \cdot {\xi _A} = {\Phi _1} \cdot {\xi _1} + {\Phi _{a1}} \cdot {\xi _{a1}},\\ {\Phi _{11}} \cdot {\xi _{11}} = {\Phi _{10}} \cdot {\xi _{10}} + {\Phi _1} \cdot {\xi _1},{\Phi _{10}} \cdot {\xi _{10}} = {\Phi _1} \cdot {\xi _1},\\ {\Phi _{11}} \cdot {\xi _{11}} = {\Phi _2} \cdot {\xi _2} + {\Phi _5} \cdot {\xi _5} + {\Phi _{a2}} \cdot {\xi _{a2}},\\ {\Phi _2} \cdot {\xi _2} = {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} + {\Phi _6} \cdot {\xi _6} + {\Phi _b} \cdot {\xi _b},\\ {\Phi _5} \cdot {\xi _5} + {\Phi _4} \cdot {\xi _4} = {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} + {\Phi _d} \cdot {\xi _d},\\ {\Phi _3} \cdot {\xi _3} = {\Phi _4} \cdot {\xi _4} + {\Phi _c} \cdot {\xi _c}. \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

While Equations S22-S25 still hold. By applying the substitutions specified in Equations S9, S12, S14-S18, combined with Equations S4, S10, S22-S25, S128, and the constraint of proteome resource allocation, we get:(S129){ϕA⋅κA=ϕ1⋅κ1+ϕa1⋅κa1,ϕ11⋅κ11=ϕ10⋅κ10+ϕ1⋅κ1,ϕ10⋅κ10=ϕ1⋅κ1,ϕ11⋅κ11=ϕ2⋅κ2+ϕ5⋅κ5+ϕa2⋅κa2,ϕ2⋅κ2=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕ6⋅κ6+ϕb⋅κb,ϕ5⋅κ5+ϕ4⋅κ4=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕd⋅κd,ϕ3⋅κ3=ϕ4⋅κ4+ϕc⋅κc,ϕa1⋅κa1=ηa1⋅λ,ϕa2⋅κa2=ηa2⋅λ,ϕb⋅κb=ηb⋅λ,ϕc⋅κc=ηc⋅λ,ϕd⋅κd=ηd⋅λ,β1⋅ϕ1⋅κ1+β2⋅ϕ2⋅κ2+β3⋅ϕ3⋅κ3+β4⋅ϕ4⋅κ4+β6⋅ϕ6⋅κ6+βa1⋅ϕa1⋅κa1=JE(N),JE(N)=ηE⋅λ,λ=ϕR⋅κt,Jr(N)=ϕ4⋅κ4,Jf(N)=ϕ6⋅κ6,ϕR+ϕA+ϕ1+ϕ2+ϕ3+ϕ4+ϕ5+ϕ6+ϕ7+ϕ8+ϕa1+ϕa2+ϕb+ϕc+ϕd=ϕmax.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\phi _A} \cdot {\kappa _A} = {\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1} + {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}},\\ {\phi _{11}} \cdot {\kappa _{11}} = {\phi _{10}} \cdot {\kappa _{10}} + {\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1},{\phi _{10}} \cdot {\kappa _{10}} = {\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1},\\ {\phi _{11}} \cdot {\kappa _{11}} = {\phi _2} \cdot {\kappa _2} + {\phi _5} \cdot {\kappa _5} + {\phi _{a2}} \cdot {\kappa _{a2}},\\ {\phi _2} \cdot {\kappa _2} = {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6} + {\phi _b} \cdot {\kappa _b},\\ {\phi _5} \cdot {\kappa _5} + {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} = {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\phi _d} \cdot {\kappa _d},\\ {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} = {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} + {\phi _c} \cdot {\kappa _c},\\ {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}} = {\eta _{a1}} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _{a2}} \cdot {\kappa _{a2}} = {\eta _{a2}} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _b} \cdot {\kappa _b} = {\eta _b} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _c} \cdot {\kappa _c} = {\eta _c} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _d} \cdot {\kappa _d} = {\eta _d} \cdot \lambda ,\\ {\beta _1} \cdot {\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1} + {\beta _2} \cdot {\phi _2} \cdot {\kappa _2} + {\beta _3} \cdot {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\beta _4} \cdot {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} + {\beta _6} \cdot {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6} + {\beta _{a1}} \cdot {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}} = J_{\rm{E}}^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)},\\ J_{\rm{E}}^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\eta _{\rm{E}}} \cdot \lambda ,\lambda = {\phi _R} \cdot {\kappa _{\rm t}},J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4},J_f^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6},\\ {\phi _{\rm{R}}} + {\phi _A} + {\phi _1} + {\phi _2} + {\phi _3} + {\phi _4} + {\phi _5} + {\phi _6} + {\phi _7} + {\phi _8} + {\phi _{a1}} + {\phi _{a2}} + {\phi _b} + {\phi _c} + {\phi _d} = {\phi _{\max }}. \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

Then, Equation S28 still holds, while ϕ10\begin{document}$\phi _{10}$\end{document} and ϕ11\begin{document}$\phi _{11}$\end{document} are:(S130){ϕ10=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)λ]/2⋅κ10(2⋅κ10),ϕ11=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)λ]/κ11.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} {\phi _{10}} &= {{\left[ {J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} + J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} + \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right)\lambda } \right]} \big/ 2 \cdot {\kappa _{10}} {\left( {2 \cdot {\kappa _{10}}} \right)}},\\[1pt] {\phi _{11}} &= {{\left[ {J_{r}^{\left( {\text{N}} \right)} + J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} + \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right)\lambda } \right]} \big/ \kappa _{11}}. \end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

By substituting Equations S28 and S130 into Equation S129, we get:(S131){Jr(E)+Jf(E)=φ⋅λ,Jr(E)εr(dt)+Jf(E)εf(dt)=ϕmax−ψdt⋅λ,\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_r^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)} + J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)} = \varphi \cdot \lambda ,\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \frac{{J_r^{\left( {\rm{E}} \right)}}}{{\varepsilon _r^{\left( {{\rm{dt}}} \right)}}} + \frac{{J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}}}{{\varepsilon _f^{\left( {{\rm{dt}}} \right)}}} = {\phi _{\max }} - {\psi _{{\rm{dt}}}} \cdot \lambda , \end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

where ‘dt’ stands for details. Equations S30 and S33 still hold. εr(dt)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{dt}\right)}$\end{document} and εf(dt)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{dt}\right)}$\end{document} represent the proteome efficiencies for energy biogenesis in the respiration and fermentation pathways, respectively, with(S132){εr(dt)=βr(A)1/κA+1/κ1+1/κ10+2/κ11+2/κ2+2/κ3+2/κ4,εf(dt)=βf(A)1/κA+1/κ1+1/κ10+2/κ11+2/κ2+2/κ6.\begin{document}$$\left\{\begin{aligned} \varepsilon _{r}^{\left (\text{dt}\right)} &= \displaystyle \frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}{1 \big/\kappa _{A}+1 \big/\kappa _{1}+1 \big/\kappa _{10}+2 \big/\kappa _{11}+2 \big/\kappa _{2}+2 \big/\kappa _{3}+2 \big/\kappa _{4}},\\[1pt]\varepsilon _{f}^{\left (\text{dt}\right)} &= \displaystyle \frac{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}{1/\kappa _{A}+1 \big/\kappa _{1}+1 \big/\kappa _{10}+2 \big/\kappa _{11}+2 \big/\kappa _{2}+2 \big/\kappa _{6}}.\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

ψdt−1\begin{document}${\psi}_{\text{dt}}^{- 1}$\end{document} is the proteome efficiency for biomass generation in the biomass synthesis pathway, with(S133)ψdt=1κt+1+ηa1+ηc2κA+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)(12κ1+12κ10+1κ11)+ηb+ηcκ2+ηcκ3+ηc+ηdκ5+∑ia1,a2,b,c,dηiκi.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \psi _{\text{dt}}=\frac{1}{\kappa _{\rm t}}+\frac{1+\eta _{a1}+\eta _{c}}{2\kappa _{A}}+\left (\eta _{a2}+\eta _{b}+2\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}\right)\left (\frac{1}{2\kappa _{1}}+\frac{1}{2\kappa _{10}}+\frac{1}{\kappa _{11}}\right) \\[1pt] & \displaystyle +\frac{\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{2}}+\frac{\eta _{c}}{\kappa _{3}}+\frac{\eta _{c}+\eta _{d}}{\kappa _{5}}+\sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}\frac{\eta _{i}}{\kappa _{i}}. \end{aligned}$$\end{document}

sec.title: 7.2 Estimation of the in vivo enzyme catalytic rates
sec.p: We use the method introduced by Davidi et al., 2016, combined with proteome experimental data (Basan et al., 2015; Appendix 1—table 2), to estimate the in vivo enzyme catalytic rates. Combining Equations S28 and S130, we have:(S134){κ1=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)λ]/(2⋅ϕ1),κ2=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(ηb+ηc)λ]/ϕ2,κ3=(Jr(N)+ηc⋅λ)/ϕ3,κ4=Jr(N)/ϕ4,κ5=(ηc+ηd)λ/ϕ5,κ6=Jf(N)/ϕ6κ10=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)λ]/(2⋅ϕ10),κ11=[Jr(N)+Jf(N)+(ηa2+ηb+2ηc+ηd)λ]/ϕ11.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} {\kappa _1} &= {{\left[ {J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} + J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} + \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right)\lambda } \right]} \big/ \left( {2 \cdot {\phi _1}} \right)},\\[1pt] {\kappa _2} &= {{\left[ {J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} + J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} + \left( {{\eta _b} + {\eta _c}} \right)\lambda } \right]} \big/ \phi _2},\\[1pt] {\kappa _3} &= {{\left( {J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} + {\eta _c} \cdot \lambda } \right)} \big/\phi _3}, {\kappa _4} = {{J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)}} \big/\phi _4},\\[1pt] {\kappa _5} &= {{\left( {{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right)\lambda } \big/\phi _5}, {\kappa _6} = {{J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}} \big/\phi _6} \\[1pt] {\kappa _{10}} &= {{\left[ {J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} + J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} + \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right)\lambda } \right]} \big/ \left( {2 \cdot {\phi _{10}}} \right)},\\[1pt] {\kappa _{11}} &= {{\left[ {J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} + J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} + \left( {{\eta _{a2}} + {\eta _b} + 2{\eta _c} + {\eta _d}} \right)\lambda } \right]} \big/\phi _{11}}. \end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

Here, Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} and ϕi\begin{document}$\phi _{i}$\end{document} (i=1-6,10-11\begin{document}$i=1\text{-6,10-11}$\end{document}) are measurable from experiments (see Appendix 9.1 and Appendix 1—table 2). Thus, we can obtain the in vivo values of κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} from Equation S134. Combined with Equations S17 and S20, we have(S135)kicat=rcarbonrprotein⋅mEimcarbon⋅κi⋅[∑iri/NEPicarbon]\begin{document}$$\displaystyle k_i^{{\rm{cat}}} = \frac{{{r_{{\rm{carbon}}}}}}{{{r_{{\rm{protein}}}}}} \cdot \frac{{{m_{{E_i}}}}}{{{m_{{\rm{carbon}}}}}} \cdot {\kappa _i} \cdot \left[ {\sum\limits_i {{{{r_i}} \big/ {N_{{\rm{E}}{{\rm{P}}_i}}^{{\rm{carbon}}}}}} } \right]$$\end{document}

Equation S135 is the in vivo result for the enzyme catalytic rate. In Appendix 1—figure 2G, we show a comparison between in vivo and in vitro results for kcat\begin{document}$k_{\text{cat}}$\end{document} values of enzymes within glycolysis and the TCA cycle, which are roughly consistent. In the applications, we prioritized the use of in vivo results for enzyme catalytic rates, and use in vitro data as a substitute when there were gaps.

sec.title: 7.3 Comparison with existing models that illustrate experimental results
sec.p: For the coarse-grained model described in Appendix 3, the normalized stoichiometric influx of a Group A carbon source is given by:(S136)Jin(N)≡JA(N)=ϕA⋅κA.\begin{document}$$J_{\rm in}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}\equiv J_{A}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}=\phi _{A}\cdot \kappa _{A}.$$\end{document}

Combined with the first equation in Equation S28 and Equation S30, we obtain:(S137)Jin(N)−ϑ⋅λ=Jr(E)βr(A)+Jf(E)βf(A),\begin{document}$$\displaystyle J_{\rm in}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}- \vartheta \cdot \lambda =\frac{J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}}{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}+\frac{J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}}{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}},$$\end{document}

where ϑ=ηa1+ηc+(ηa2+ηb+ηd)/2\begin{document}$\vartheta =\eta _{a1}+\eta _{c}+\left (\eta _{a2}+\eta _{b}+\eta _{d}\right){\big /}2$\end{document}. Evidently, βr(A)\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}$\end{document}, βf(A)\begin{document}$\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}$\end{document} and ϑ\begin{document}$\vartheta $\end{document} are constant parameters. In this subsection, we highlight the major differences between our model presented in Appendix 3 and existing models that illustrate the growth rate dependence of fermentation flux in the standard picture of overflow metabolism (Basan et al., 2015; Holms, 1996; Meyer et al., 1984; Nanchen et al., 2006).

Based on the modeling principles rather than the detailed mechanisms, there are two major classes of existing models that can illustrate experimental results. Both classes of models regard the proteome efficiencies εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document} as constants, with εf>εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f} \gt \varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} if used, or follow functionally equivalent propositions. However, in our model, εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document} are both functions of κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}, which vary significantly upon nutrient perturbation, with εr(κA→0)>εf(κA→0)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right)$\end{document} and εr(κAmax)<εf(κAmax)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)$\end{document} (see Equations S38, S40-S41). Furthermore, there are significant differences in the modeling and optimization principles, as listed below.

The first class of models (Chen and Nielsen, 2019; Majewski and Domach, 1990; Shlomi et al., 2011; Varma and Palsson, 1994; Vazquez et al., 2010; Vazquez and Oltvai, 2016; Zhuang et al., 2011) optimize the ratio of biomass outflow to carbon influx λ/Jin(N)\begin{document}$\lambda \big/J_{\rm in}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, either to optimize the growth rate for a given carbon influx or to minimize the carbon influx for a given growth rate. Since respiration is far more efficient than fermentation in terms of energy biogenesis per unit carbon, to optimize the ratio λ/Jin(N)\begin{document}$\lambda \big/J_{\rm in}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}, cells would preferentially use respiration when the carbon influx is small. As carbon influx increases above a certain threshold, factors such as proteome allocation direct cells toward fermentation in a threshold-linear response, since they consider εf>εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f} \gt \varepsilon _{r}$\end{document}. Our model is significantly different from this class of models in the optimization principle, as we purely optimize the cell growth rate for a given nutrient condition, without imposing a special constraint on the carbon influx.

The second class of models, represented by Basan et al., 2015, also adopt the optimization of λ/Jin(N)\begin{document}$\lambda \big/J_{\rm in}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} in the interpretation of their model results. However, the growth rate dependence of fermentation flux was derived prior to the application of growth rate optimization (although it can be derived by optimizing λ/Jin(N)\begin{document}$\lambda \big/J_{\rm in}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}). In fact, Equations S29 and S137 in our model are very similar in form to those in Basan et al., 2015, yet there are critical differences, which we list below. In Equation S29, by regarding Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} and Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} as the two variables in a system of linear equations, we obtain the following expressions:(S138){Jr(E)=ϕmax−(ψ+φεf)⋅λ1εr−1εf,Jf(E)=(ψ+φεr)⋅λ−ϕmax1εr−1εf.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{ll} J_{r}^{\left( \text{E} \right)} &= \displaystyle \frac{\phi_{\text{max}} - \left( \psi + \frac{\varphi}{\varepsilon_f} \right) \cdot \lambda}{\frac{1}{\varepsilon_r} - \frac{1}{\varepsilon_f}}, \\[1pt] J_{f}^{\left( \text{E} \right)} &= \displaystyle \frac{\left( \psi + \frac{\varphi}{\varepsilon_r} \right) \cdot \lambda - \phi_{\text{max}}}{\frac{1}{\varepsilon_r} - \frac{1}{\varepsilon_f}}. \end{array} \right.$$\end{document}

In Basan et al., 2015, Equation S138 is considered to be the relation between Jr/f(E)\begin{document}$J_{r/f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} and λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} upon nutrient (and thus Jin(N)\begin{document}$J_{\rm in}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document}) perturbation, while εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} and εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document} are regarded as constants throughout the perturbation. By contrast, in our model, Equation S138 serves as a constraint under a given nutrient condition with fixed κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}, and is not relevant to nutrient perturbation. For wild-type strains, if εr(κA)>εf(κA)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document} (or vice versa), then the solution for optimal growth is Jr(E)(κA)=φ⋅λ(κA)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)=\varphi \cdot \lambda \left (\kappa _{A}\right)$\end{document} and Jf(E)(κA)=0\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)=0$\end{document}, with λ(κA)=εr(κA)⋅ϕmaxφ+εr(κA)⋅ψ(κA)\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A}\right)=\frac{\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)\cdot \phi _{\rm max}}{\varphi +\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)\cdot \psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)}$\end{document}. This solution, which satisfies Equation S138, corresponds to a point rather than a line in the relation between growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} and normalized energy flux Jr/f(E)\begin{document}$J_{r/f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} upon κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} perturbation.

sec.title: Probability density functions of variables and parameters
8.1 Probability density function of κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document}
sec.p: Enzyme catalysis is crucial for the survival of living organisms, as it significantly accelerates biochemical reactions by reducing the energy barrier between the substrate and product (Nelson and Cox, 2008). However, the maximal turnover rate of enzymes, kcat\begin{document}$k_{\text{cat}}$\end{document}, varies notably between in vivo and in vitro measurements (Davidi et al., 2016). Recent studies suggest that differences in the aquatic medium are the primary cause of this variation (Davidi et al., 2016; García-Contreras et al., 2012). In particular, potassium and phosphate concentrations have a significant influence on kcat\begin{document}$k_{\text{cat}}$\end{document} (García-Contreras et al., 2012), and these concentrations exhibit some degree of variation among cell populations under intracellular conditions (García-Contreras et al., 2012). For simplicity, we assume that the turnover rate of each enzyme Ei\begin{document}$E_{i}$\end{document}, kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document}, follows a Gaussian distribution N(μkicat,σkicat2)\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}},\sigma _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{2}\right)$\end{document} with kicat>0\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}} \gt 0$\end{document} among cells (representing extrinsic noise [Elowitz et al., 2002], denoted as χext\begin{document}$\chi _{\text{ext}}$\end{document}). The probability density function of kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} is then given by:(S139)kicat∼N′(x;μkicat,σkicat2)={l1σkicat2πe−12(x−μkicatσkicat)2,x≥0.0,x<0.\begin{document}$${k}_i^{{\rm{cat}}}\sim\mathcal{N}'\left( {x;{\mu _{k_i^{{\rm{cat}}}}},\sigma _{k_i^{{\rm{cat}}}}^2} \right) = \left\{ \begin{aligned}{l} & \displaystyle \frac{1}{{{\sigma _{k_i^{{\rm{cat}}}}}\sqrt {2\pi } }}{{\rm e}^{ - \frac{1}{2}{{\left( {\frac{{x - {\mu _{k_i^{{\rm{cat}}}}}}}{{{\sigma _{k_i^{{\rm{cat}}}}}}}} \right)}^2}}}, &x \ge 0.\\ &0, &x < 0. \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

When the CV of the kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} distribution (i.e. σkicat/μkicat\begin{document}$\sigma _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}\big/\mu _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}$\end{document}) is less than 1/3\begin{document}$1/3$\end{document} , N′(x;μkicat,σkicat2)\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}'\left (x;\mu _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}},\sigma _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{2}\right)$\end{document} is almost identical to N(μkicat,σkicat2)\begin{document}$\mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}},\sigma _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{2}\right)$\end{document}. In this case, 1/kicat\begin{document}$1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} follows the positive inverse of Gaussian (IOG) distribution, and the probability density function is:(S140)IOG(x;μ1/kicat,ζ1/kicat)={ζ1/kicat2πx4exp(−12ζ1/kicat(x−μ1/kicat)2x2μ1/kicat2),x≥0,0,x<0,\begin{document}$$\text{IOG}\left (x;\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}},\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}\right)=\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \sqrt{\frac{\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}}{2\pi x^{4}}}{\rm exp}\left (- \frac{1}{2}\frac{\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}\left (x- \mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}\right)^{2}}{x^{2}\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{2}}\right), &x\geq 0,\\ &0, & x \lt 0,\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

where ζ1/kicat=1/σkicat2\begin{document}$\zeta _{1{/}k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}=1{\big /}\sigma _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{2}$\end{document} is the shape parameter, and μ1/kicat=1/μkicat\begin{document}$\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}=1{\big /}\mu _{k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}$\end{document} is the mean.

Meanwhile, due to the stochastic nature of biochemical reactions, we apply Gillespie’s chemical Langevin equation (Gillespie, 2000) to account for intrinsic noise (Elowitz et al., 2002) (denoted as χint\begin{document}$\chi _{\text{int}}$\end{document}). For cell size regulation of E. coli within a cell cycle, the cell mass at the initiation of DNA replication per chromosome origin remains constant (Donachie, 1968). Thus, the time required for enzyme Ei\begin{document}$E_{i}$\end{document} to complete a catalytic job (with a timescale of 1/kicat\begin{document}$1{\big /}k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document}) can be approximated as the first passage time of a stochastic process, with(S141){Xi(t=0)=0,dXi/dt=αi+αiΓi(t),TΘ=inf{t>0|Xi(t)=Θ}.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}X_{i}\left (t=0\right)=0,\\dX_{i} \big/dt=\alpha _{i}+\sqrt{\alpha _{i}}\Gamma _{i}\left (t\right),\\T_{\Theta }={\rm inf}\left \{t \gt 0|X_{i}\left (t\right)=\Theta \right \}.\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

Here αi≡kicat⋅Θ\begin{document}$\alpha _{i}\equiv k_{i}^{\text{cat}}\cdot \Theta $\end{document}, where Θ\begin{document}$\Theta $\end{document} is proportional to the cell volume, and Γi(t)\begin{document}$\Gamma _{i}\left (t\right)$\end{document} represents independent, temporally uncorrelated Gaussian white noise. Then, for a given value of kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document}, the first passage time TΘ\begin{document}$T_{\Theta }$\end{document} follows an Inverse Gaussian (IG) distribution (Folks and Chhikara, 1978):(S142)IG(x;μ1/kicat′,ζ1/kicat′)={ζ1/kicat′2πx3exp(−12ζ1/kicat′(x−μ1/kicat′)2xμ1/kicat′2),x≥0,0,x<0,\begin{document}$$\text{IG}\left (x;\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime },\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime }\right)=\left \{\begin{aligned} & \displaystyle \sqrt{\frac{\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime }}{2\pi x^{3}}}{\rm exp}\left (- \frac{1}{2}\frac{\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime }\left (x- \mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime }\right)^{2}}{x\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime 2}}\right), &x\geq 0,\\ &0, &x \lt 0,\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

where ζ1/kicat′=Θ/kicat\begin{document}$\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime }=\Theta {\big /}k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} is the shape parameter, and μ1/kicat′=1/kicat\begin{document}$\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime }=1{\big /}k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} represents the mean. The variance of this distribution is σ1/kicat′2≡μ1/kicat′3/ζ1/kicat′=1/[Θ⋅(kicat)2]\begin{document}$\sigma _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime 2}\equiv \mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime 3} \big/\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime }=1 \big/\left[\Theta \cdot \left (k_{i}^{\text{cat}}\right)^{2}\right]$\end{document}. Thus, we can obtain the CV:(S143)σ1/kicat′/μ1/kicat′=Θ−12,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle {\sigma _{1/k_i^{{\rm{cat}}}}^\prime } \big/ \mu _{1/k_i^{{\rm{cat}}}}^\prime = {\Theta ^{ - \frac{1}{2}}} , $$\end{document}

which is inversely proportional to the square root of cell volume. Evidently, the intrinsic and extrinsic noise make orthogonal contributions to the total noise (Elowitz et al., 2002) (denoted as χtot\begin{document}$\chi _{\text{tot}}$\end{document}):(S144)χtot2=χint2+χext2.\begin{document}$$\chi _{\text{tot}}^{2}=\chi _{\text{int}}^{2}+\chi _{\text{ext}}^{2}.$$\end{document}

In fact, when the CV is small (i.e. CV <<1), both the IOG and IG distributions converge into Gaussian distributions (Appendix 1—figure 4). In the back-of-the-envelope calculations, we approximate x in all denominator terms of IOG(x;μ,ζ)\begin{document}$\text{IOG}\left (x;\mu ,\zeta \right)$\end{document} and IG(x;μ,ζ)\begin{document}$\text{IG}\left (x;\mu ,\zeta \right)$\end{document} as μ (since CV <<1). Then, both the IOG and IG distributions can be approximated as follows:(S145)IOG(x;μ1/kicat,ζ1/kicat)→CV≪1N(μ1/kicat,σ1/kicat2),\begin{document}$$\text{IOG}\left (x;\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}},\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}\right)\xrightarrow{\text{CV}\ll \text{1}}\mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}},\sigma _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{2}\right),$$\end{document}

with a variance of σ1/kicat2=μ1/kicat4/ζ1/kicat\begin{document}$\sigma _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{2}=\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{4}{\big /}\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}$\end{document}, and(S146)IG(x;μ1/kicat′,ζ1/kicat′)→CV≪1N(μ1/kicat′,σ1/kicat′2),\begin{document}$$\text{IG}\left (x;\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime },\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime }\right) \xrightarrow{\text{CV}\ll \text{1}}\mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime },\sigma _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime ^{2}}\right),$$\end{document}

with a variance of σ1/kicat′2=μ1/kicat′3/ζ1/kicat′\begin{document}$\sigma _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime ^{2}}=\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime ^{3}}{\big /}\zeta _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{\prime }$\end{document}. Rigorously, we show below that IG(x;μ,ζ)\begin{document}$\text{IG}\left (x;\mu ,\zeta \right)$\end{document} shrinks to be N(μ,μ3/ζ)\begin{document}${\cal N}\left (\mu ,\mu ^{3}{\big /}\zeta \right)$\end{document} when the CV is small. For the IG distribution, the characteristic function of the variable x is given by Folks and Chhikara, 1978; Kampen, 1992:(S147)G(k)=∫−∞∞eikx⋅IG(x;μ,ζ)dx=exp{ζμ[1−1−2iμ2kζ]},\begin{document}$$\displaystyle G\left (k\right)=\int \limits_{- \infty }^{\infty }e^{\text{i}kx}\cdot \text{IG}\left (x;\mu ,\zeta \right)dx={\rm exp}\left \{\frac{\zeta }{\mu }\left[1- \sqrt{1- \frac{2\text{i}\mu ^{2}k}{\zeta }}\right]\right \},$$\end{document}

and therefore,(S148)IG(x;μ,ζ)=12π∫−∞∞e−ikx⋅G(k)dk.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \text{IG}\left (x;\mu ,\zeta \right)=\frac{1}{2\pi }\int \limits_{- \infty }^{\infty }{\rm e}^{- \text{i}kx}\cdot G\left (k\right)dk.$$\end{document}

When the variance σ2≡μ3/ζ\begin{document}$\sigma ^{2}\equiv \mu ^{3}\big/\zeta $\end{document} is very small, we essentially require 2μ2k/ζ=2σ2k/μ≪1\begin{document}$2\mu ^{2}k\big/\zeta =2\sigma ^{2}k\big/\mu \ll 1$\end{document}, and then 1−2iμ2kζ≈1−μ2ζki+μ42ζ2k2\begin{document}$\sqrt{1- \frac{2\text{i}\mu ^{2}k}{\zeta }}\approx 1- \frac{\mu ^{2}}{\zeta }k\text{i}+\frac{\mu ^{4}}{2\zeta ^{2}}k^{2}$\end{document}. Thus,(S149){G(k)≈exp⁡(μki−μ32ζk2),IG(x;μ,ζ)≈ζ2πμ3exp⁡(−ζ(x−μ)22μ3)=N(μ,μ3ζ).\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} & \displaystyle G(k) \approx \exp\left( \mu k {\rm i} - \frac{\mu^3}{2\zeta} k^2 \right), \\[1pt] & \displaystyle \text{IG}(x; \mu, \zeta) \approx \sqrt{\frac{\zeta}{2\pi \mu^3}} \exp\left( -\frac{\zeta (x - \mu)^2}{2\mu^3} \right) = \mathcal{N}\left( \mu, \frac{\mu^3}{\zeta} \right). \end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

This leads to:(S150)limσ→0IG(x;μ,ζ)=N(μ,μ3/ζ).\begin{document}$$\underset{\sigma \rightarrow 0}{\rm lim}\text{IG}\left (x;\mu ,\zeta \right)=\mathcal{N}\left (\mu ,\mu ^{3}/\zeta \right).$$\end{document}

In fact, intrinsic noise does affect the short-term measurement of enzyme catalytic rate and growth rate at the single-cell level. However, its contribution in the long term is averaged out and thus becomes negligible. For simplicity, we approximate χtot≈χext\begin{document}$\chi _{\text{tot}}\approx \chi _{\text{ext}}$\end{document}. Combined with Equations S145-S146, it is straightforward to verify that 1/kicat\begin{document}$1{\big /}k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} shares roughly the same CV as kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document}:(S151)σ1/kicat/μ1/kicat=σkicat/μkicat.\begin{document}$$\sigma _{1/k_i^{\rm{cat}}} \big /\mu _{1/k_i^{\rm{cat}}} = \sigma _{k_i^{\rm{cat}}} \big/ \mu _{k_i^{\rm{cat}}} .$$\end{document}

For convenience, in the model analysis, we approximate both IOG and IG distributions as Gaussian distributions. Then, all 1/kicat\begin{document}$1{\big /}k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} are independent, normally distributed random variables following Gaussian distributions:(S152)1/kicat∼N(μ1/kicat,σ1/kicat2).\begin{document}$$1\big/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}},\sigma _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}^{2}\right).$$\end{document}

Using the properties of Gaussian distributions, for a series of constant real numbers γi\begin{document}$\gamma _{i}$\end{document}, the summation of γi/kicat\begin{document}$\gamma _{i}\big/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document}, which we define as Ξ≡∑i=1nγi/kicat\begin{document}$\Xi \equiv \sum \limits_{i=1}^{n}\gamma _{i}\big/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} , follows a Gaussian distribution (Kampen, 1992):(S153)Ξ∼N(μΞ,σΞ2),\begin{document}$$\Xi \sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\Xi },\sigma _{\Xi }^{2}\right),$$\end{document}

with μΞ=∑i=1nγiμ1/kicat\begin{document}$\mu _{\Xi }=\sum \limits_{i=1}^{n}\gamma _{i}\mu _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}$\end{document} and σΞ2=∑i=1n(γiσ1/kicat)2\begin{document}$\sigma _{\Xi }^{2}=\sum \limits_{i=1}^{n}\left (\gamma _{i}\sigma _{1/k_{i}^{\text{cat}}}\right)^{2}$\end{document}. The relation between κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} and kicat\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}$\end{document} is shown in Equation S12. To optimize cell growth rate, each κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} of the intermediate nodes satisfies Equation S20, while κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} satisfies Equation S27. Thus, for a given nutrient condition ([A] is fixed), all the ratios kicat/κi\begin{document}$k_{i}^{\text{cat}}{\big /}\kappa _{i}$\end{document} are constants. Combined with Equations S139, S145-S146, and S152, the distributions of all κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} and 1/κi\begin{document}$1\big/\kappa _{i}$\end{document} can be approximated as Gaussian distributions:(S154){κi∼N(μκi,σκi2),1κi∼N(μ1/κi,σ1/κi2),\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} \kappa_i &\sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mu_{\kappa_i}, \sigma_{\kappa_i}^2\right), \\[1pt] \displaystyle \frac{1}{\kappa_i} &\sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mu_{1/\kappa_i}, \sigma_{1/\kappa_i}^2\right), \end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

where μκi\begin{document}$\mu _{\kappa _{i}}$\end{document} and μ1/κi\begin{document}$\mu _{1/\kappa _{i}}$\end{document} are the means of κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} and 1/κi\begin{document}$1{\big /}\kappa _{i}$\end{document}, and σκi\begin{document}$\sigma _{\kappa _{i}}$\end{document} and σ1/κi\begin{document}$\sigma _{1/\kappa _{i}}$\end{document} are their standard deviations. Using the properties of Gaussian distributions, combined with Equation S31, S32, S36, S42-S43, S145-S146 and S153, εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document}, εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, ψ\begin{document}$\psi $\end{document}, λr\begin{document}$\lambda _{r}$\end{document}, λf\begin{document}$\lambda _{f}$\end{document}, κA(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}$\end{document} and λC\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}$\end{document} also roughly follow Gaussian distributions.

sec.title: 8.2 Probability density function of the growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document}
sec.p: From Appendix 8.1, we note that λr\begin{document}$\lambda _{r}$\end{document} and λf\begin{document}$\lambda _{f}$\end{document} (see Equation S36) roughly follow Gaussian distributions, with(S155){λr∼N(μλr,σλr2),λf∼N(μλf,σλf2),\begin{document}$$\left\{\begin{array}{l}\lambda _{r}\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{r}},\sigma _{\lambda _{r}}^{2}\right),\\\lambda _{f}\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{f}},\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}^{2}\right),\end{array}\right. $$\end{document}

where μλr/f\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{r/f}}$\end{document} and σλr/f\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{r/f}}$\end{document} represent the mean and standard deviation, respectively. We further assume that the correlation between λr\begin{document}$\lambda _{r}$\end{document} and λf\begin{document}$\lambda _{f}$\end{document} is ρrf\begin{document}$\rho _{rf}$\end{document}. From Equation S36, we see that the growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} takes the maximum of λr\begin{document}$\lambda _{r}$\end{document} and λf\begin{document}$\lambda _{f}$\end{document}, i.e.,(S156)λ=max(λr,λf).\begin{document}$$\lambda ={\rm max}\left (\lambda _{r},\lambda _{f}\right).$$\end{document}

Then, the cumulative distribution function of λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} is P(λ≤x)=∫−∞x∫−∞xf(x1,x2)dx1dx2\begin{document}$P\left (\lambda \leq x\right)=\int \limits_{- \infty }^{x}\int \limits_{- \infty }^{x}f\left (x_{1},x_{2}\right)dx_{1}dx_{2}$\end{document}, wheref(x1,x2)=(1−ρrf2)−122πσλrσλfexp(−12(1−ρrf2)[(x1−μλrσλr)2−2ρrf(x1−μλrσλr)(x2−μλfσλf)+(x2−μλfσλf)2]).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned}f\left (x_{1},x_{2}\right)= & \displaystyle \frac{\left (1- {\rho}_{rf}^{2}\right)^{- \frac{1}{2}}}{2\pi \sigma _{\lambda _{r}}\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}}{\exp}\bigg(- \frac{1}{2\left (1- {\rho}_{rf}^{2}\right)}\bigg[\left (\frac{x_{1}- \mu _{\lambda _{r}}}{\sigma _{\lambda _{r}}}\right)^{2} \\[1pt] & \displaystyle - 2\rho _{rf}\left (\frac{x_{1}- \mu _{\lambda _{r}}}{\sigma _{\lambda _{r}}}\right)\left (\frac{x_{2}- \mu _{\lambda _{f}}}{\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}}\right)+\left (\frac{x_{2}- \mu _{\lambda _{f}}}{\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}}\right)^{2}\bigg]\bigg).\end{aligned}$$\end{document}

Thus, the probability density function of the growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} is given by:(S157)fλ(x)=122πσλre−12(x−μλrσλr)2[erf((x−μλf)σλr−ρrfσλf(x−μλr)σλrσλf2(1−ρrf2))+1]+122πσλfe−12(x−μλfσλf)2[erf((x−μλr)σλf−ρrfσλr(x−μλf)σλrσλf2(1−ρrf2))+1].\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} f_{\lambda }\left (x\right)= & \displaystyle \frac{1}{2\sqrt{2\pi }\sigma _{\lambda _{r}}}{\rm e}^{- \frac{1}{2}\left (\frac{x- \mu _{\lambda _{r}}}{{\sigma}_{{\lambda}_{r}}}\right)^{2}}\left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\left (x- \mu _{\lambda _{f}}\right)\sigma _{\lambda _{r}}- \rho _{rf}\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}\left (x- \mu _{\lambda _{r}}\right)}{\sigma _{\lambda _{r}}\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}\sqrt{2\left (1- {\rho}_{rf}^{2}\right)}}\right)+ 1\right] \\[1pt] & \displaystyle+\frac{1}{2\sqrt{2\pi }\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}}{\rm e}^{- \frac{1}{2}\left (\frac{x- \mu _{\lambda _{f}}}{\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}}\right)^{2}}\left[\text{erf}\left (\frac{\left (x- \mu _{\lambda _{r}}\right)\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}- \rho _{rf}\sigma _{\lambda _{r}}\left (x- \mu _{\lambda _{f}}\right)}{\sigma _{\lambda _{r}}\sigma _{\lambda _{f}}\sqrt{2\left (1- \rho _{rf}^{2}\right)}}\right)+1\right].\end{aligned}$$\end{document}
In Appendix 1—figure 2B, we show that Equation S157 quantitatively matches the experimental data for E. coli under the relevant conditions.

sec.title: Model comparison with experiments on E. coli
9.1 Flux comparison with experiments on E. coli
sec.p: In Appendix 7.2, we see that the values of Jf(N)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} and Jr(N)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}$\end{document} are required to calculate the in vivo enzyme catalytic rates of the intermediate nodes. Here, we use Jacetate\begin{document}$J_{\text{acetate}}$\end{document} and JCO2,r\begin{document}$J_{\text{CO}_{\text{2}},r}$\end{document} to represent the stoichiometric fluxes of acetate from the fermentation pathway and CO2 from the respiration pathway, respectively. Combined with the stoichiometric coefficients of both pathways, we have:(S158){Jacetate=Jf,JCO2,r=3⋅Jr.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{l}J_{\text{acetate}}=J_{f},\\J_{\text{CO}_{\text{2}},r}=3\cdot J_{r}.\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}

By further combining with Equations S16-S17, we get:(S159){Jf(N)=Jacetate⋅mcarbonMcarbon⋅[∑iri/NEPicarbon]−1,Jr(N)=13⋅JCO2,r⋅mcarbonMcarbon⋅[∑iri/NEPicarbon]−1.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \left\{ \begin{aligned} J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} &= \displaystyle {J_{{\rm{acetate}}}} \cdot \frac{{{m_{{\rm{carbon}}}}}}{{{M_{{\rm{carbon}}}}}} \cdot {\left[ {\sum\limits_i {{{{r_i}} \big/ N_{{\rm{E}}{{\rm{P}}_i}}^{{\rm{carbon}}}}} } \right]^{ - 1}},\\[1pt] \displaystyle J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} &= \displaystyle \frac{1}{3} \cdot {J_{{\rm{C}}{{\rm{O}}_2},r}} \cdot \frac{{{m_{{\rm{carbon}}}}}}{{{M_{{\rm{carbon}}}}}} \cdot {\left[ {\sum\limits_i {{{{r_i}} \big/N_{{\rm{E}}{{\rm{P}}_i}}^{{\rm{carbon}}}}} } \right]^{ - 1}}. \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

In fact, the values of Jacetate\begin{document}$J_{\text{acetate}}$\end{document} and JCO2,r\begin{document}$J_{\text{CO}_{\text{2}},r}$\end{document} scale with the mass of the ‘big cell,’ which increases over time. In experiments, the measurable fluxes are typically expressed in the unit of mM/OD600/h (Basan et al., 2015). Thus, we define Jacetate(M)\begin{document}$J_{\text{acetate}}^{\left (\text{M}\right)}$\end{document} and JCO2,r(M)\begin{document}$J_{\text{CO}_{\text{2}},r}^{\left (\text{M}\right)}$\end{document} as the fluxes of Jacetate\begin{document}$J_{\text{acetate}}$\end{document} and JCO2,r\begin{document}$J_{\text{CO}_{\text{2}},r}$\end{document} (per biomass) in the unit of mM/OD600/h, respectively. The superscript ‘(M)’ represents the measurable flux in this unit. For E. coli, we use the following biochemical data collected from published literature: 1 OD600 roughly corresponds to 6×108 cells/mL (Stevenson et al., 2016), the average mass of a cell is 1 pg (Milo and Phillips, 2015), the biomass percentage of the cell weight is 30% (Neidhardt et al., 1990), the molar mass of carbon is 12 g (Nelson and Cox, 2008), rcarbon=0.48\begin{document}$r_{\text{carbon}}=0.48$\end{document} (Neidhardt et al., 1990) and rprotein=0.55\begin{document}$r_{\text{protein}}=0.55$\end{document} (Neidhardt et al., 1990). Combined with the values of ri\begin{document}$r_{i}$\end{document} (see Appendix 2.2) and NEPicarbon\begin{document}$N_{\text{EP}_{i}}^{\text{carbon}}$\end{document}, where NEPa1carbon=6\begin{document}$N_{\text{EP}_{a1}}^{\text{carbon}}=6$\end{document}, NEPa2carbon=3\begin{document}$N_{\text{EP}_{a2}}^{\text{carbon}}=3$\end{document}, NEPbcarbon=3\begin{document}$N_{\text{EP}_{b}}^{\text{carbon}}=3$\end{document}, NEPccarbon=5\begin{document}$N_{\text{EP}_{c}}^{\text{carbon}}=5$\end{document}, and NEPdcarbon=4\begin{document}$N_{\text{EP}_{d}}^{\text{carbon}}=4$\end{document} (Nelson and Cox, 2008), we have:(S160){Jf(N)≈Jacetate(M)/2,Jr(N)≈JCO2,r(M)/6.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} \approx {J_{{\rm{acetate}}}^{\left( {\rm{M}} \right)}} \big/ 2,\\ J_r^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} \approx {J_{{\rm{C}}{{\rm{O}}_{\rm{2}}},r}^{\left( {\rm{M}} \right)}} \big/ 6. \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

From Equation S18, we obtain the values of ηi\begin{document}$\eta _{i}$\end{document} for each precursor pool: ηa1=0.15\begin{document}$\eta _{a1}=0.15$\end{document}, ηa2=0.30\begin{document}$\eta _{a2}=0.30$\end{document},ηb=0.35\begin{document}$\eta _{b}=0.35$\end{document}, ηc=0.09\begin{document}$\eta _{c}=0.09$\end{document}, and ηd=0.11\begin{document}$\eta _{d}=0.11$\end{document}. Still, the value of ηE\begin{document}$\eta _{\text{E}}$\end{document} is required to compare the growth rate dependence of fermentation/respiration fluxes between model results and experiments, which we will specify in Appendix 9.2.

sec.title: 9.2 Model parameter settings using experimental data of E. coli
sec.p: We have collected biochemical data for E. coli, as shown in Appendix 1—table 1 and Appendix 1—table 2, to set the model parameters. This includes the molecular weight (MW) and in vitro kcat values of the catalytic enzymes, as well as the proteome and flux data used to calculate the in vivo turnover numbers. To reduce measurement noise, we take the average rather than the maximum value of in vivo kcat from calculations using data from four cultures (see Appendix 1—table 2). Here, we prioritize the use of in vivo kcat wherever applicable unless there is a gap in the in vivo data (see Appendix 1—table 1).

Note that our models are coarse grained. For example, the flux J3\begin{document}$J_{3}$\end{document} shown in Figure 1B actually corresponds to three different reactions in the metabolic network (see Figure 1A and Appendix 1—table 1), which we label as J3(i)\begin{document}$J_{3}^{\left (i\right)}$\end{document} (i=1, 2, 3). For each J3(i)\begin{document}$J_{3}^{\left (i\right)}$\end{document}, there are corresponding variables/parameters of Φ3(i)\begin{document}$\Phi _{3}^{\left (i\right)}$\end{document} , ξ3(i)\begin{document}$\xi _{3}^{\left (i\right)}$\end{document}, ϕ3(i)\begin{document}$\phi _{3}^{\left (i\right)}$\end{document}, κ3(i)\begin{document}$\kappa _{3}^{\left (i\right)}$\end{document} satisfying Equations S8, S9 and S12, Evidently, J3(i)=J3\begin{document}$J_{3}^{\left (i\right)}=J_{3}$\end{document} (i=1, 2, 3), and it is straightforward to derive the following relation between κ3(i)\begin{document}$\kappa _{3}^{\left (i\right)}$\end{document} and κ3\begin{document}$\kappa _{3}$\end{document}:(S161)1/κ3=∑i=131/κ3(i).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle 1 \big/\kappa _{3}=\sum \limits_{i=1}^{3}1\big/\kappa _{3}^{\left (i\right)}.$$\end{document}

In fact, Equation S161 can be generalized to determine the values of other κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} in the coarse-grained models combined with the biochemical data. For the coarse-grained model of Group A carbon source utilization shown in Figure 1B, we have the values for parameters κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} (i=1, …, 6), and then εr/f(κA(C))=122(h−1)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=122\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}. Evidently, εr(κglucose(ST))<εf(κglucose(ST))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{\text{glucose}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{\text{glucose}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}\right)$\end{document}, εr(κlactose(ST))<εf(κlactose(ST))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{\text{lactose}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{\text{lactose}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}\right)$\end{document}, and thus εr(κAmax)<εf(κAmax)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)$\end{document}. For pyruvate, we have εr/f(py)(κpy(C))=εr/f(κA(C))=122(h−1)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r/f}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=122\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document} (see Equations S43 and S101), and it is easy to check that εr(κpy(ST))<εf(κpy(ST))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{\text{py}}^{\left (\text{ST}\right)}\right)$\end{document}.

For the remaining model parameters, note that we have classified the inactive ribosomal-affiliated proteins into the Q-class, and then ϕmax=48%\begin{document}$\phi _{\rm max}=48\% $\end{document} (Scott et al., 2010). The value of κt\begin{document}$\kappa _{\rm t}$\end{document} is obtainable from experiments: the translation speed is 20.1aa/s (Scott et al., 2010), with 7336 amino acids per ribosome (Neidhardt, 1996) and ς≈1.67\begin{document}$\varsigma \approx 1.67$\end{document} (Neidhardt, 1996; Scott et al., 2010) (see Appendix 2.1), hence κt=1/610(s−1)\begin{document}$\kappa _{\rm t}=1/610\left (\text{s}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}. However, there are insufficient data to determine the values of κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} (i=a1, a2, b, c, d) for the metabolites between the entry point metabolites shown in Figure 1A to the precursor pools. These processes involves many steps, so these values are expected to be quite large. Here, we combine the contributions of κt\begin{document}$\kappa _{\rm t}$\end{document} and κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document} (i=a1, a2, b, c, d) by defining a composite parameter:(S162)Ω≡1/κt+∑ia1,a2,b,c,dηi/κi.\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \Omega \equiv 1\big/\kappa _{\rm t}+\sum \limits_{i}^{a1,a2,b,c,d}\eta _{i}\big/\kappa _{i}.$$\end{document}

We proceed to estimate the values of Ω\begin{document}$\Omega $\end{document} and φ\begin{document}$\varphi $\end{document} using experimental data (Basan et al., 2015) for wild-type strains on the Jacetate(M)-λ\begin{document}$J_{\text{acetate}}^{\left (\text{M}\right)}\text{-}\lambda $\end{document} relation (Figure 1C), and then all the remaining model parameters are set accordingly.

For the case of w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document}, where all kcat values follow a Gaussian distribution with an extrinsic noise of 25% CV (which is the general setting we use unless otherwise specified), we have φ=10.8\begin{document}$\varphi =10.8$\end{document} and Ω=1345 (s)\begin{document}$\Omega =1345\text{\ }\left (\text{s}\right)$\end{document}. Accordingly, we obtain ηE=14.78\begin{document}$\eta _{\text{E}}=14.78$\end{document}, μλC=0.92 (h−1)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}=0.92\text{\ }\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}, and σλC=0.12μλC\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}=0.12\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}$\end{document}, where the CV of the extrinsic noise for Ω\begin{document}$\Omega $\end{document} is estimated using the averaged CV of other κi\begin{document}$\kappa _{i}$\end{document}. For the translation inhibition effect of Cm, we estimate the values for ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} as ιw0=0(2μm Cm)=1.15\begin{document}$\iota _{w_{0}=0}^{\left (2\mu \text{m Cm}\right)}=1.15$\end{document}, ιw0=0(4μm Cm)=2.33\begin{document}$\iota _{w_{0}=0}^{\left (4\mu \text{m Cm}\right)}=2.33$\end{document}, and ιw0=0(8μm Cm)=6.25\begin{document}$\iota _{w_{0}=0}^{\left (8\mu \text{m Cm}\right)}=6.25$\end{document}, where the superscript stands for the concentration of Cm, and the subscript represents the choice of w0\begin{document}$w_{0}$\end{document}.

For pyruvate, with the value of ηE\begin{document}$\eta _{\text{E}}$\end{document}, we get φpy=14.82\begin{document}$\varphi _{\text{py}}=14.82$\end{document}. However, there is still a lack of proteome data to determine the value of κ9\begin{document}$\kappa _{9}$\end{document}, which involves many steps in the metabolic network and thus can be considerably large. Here we define another composite parameter, Ω′Gg≡(ηb+ηc)/κ8+ηa1/κ9\begin{document}$\Omega ^{\prime }_{\text{Gg}}\equiv \left (\eta _{b}+\eta _{c}\right)/\kappa _{8}+\eta _{a1}/\kappa _{9}$\end{document}, and estimate its value as Ω′Gg=690 (s)\begin{document}$\Omega ^{\prime }_{\text{Gg}}=690\text{\ }\left (\text{s}\right)$\end{document} from growth rate data for E. coli measured under the relevant nutrient conditions (Basan et al., 2015), where the subscript ‘Gg’ stands for glucogenesis. Then, μλC(py)=0.67 (h−1)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}=0.67\text{\ }\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}, and σλC(py)=0.10μλC(py)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}=0.10\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{py}\right)}}$\end{document}, where the same CV of extrinsic noise for Ω\begin{document}$\Omega $\end{document} applies to Ω′Gg\begin{document}$\Omega ^{\prime }_{\text{Gg}}$\end{document}.

For the case of a Group A carbon source mixed with 21 amino acids (21AA, with saturated concentrations), we have φ21AA=14.2\begin{document}$\varphi _{\text{21AA}}=14.2$\end{document}. Comparing Equation S32 with Equation S112, the parameter Ω\begin{document}$\Omega $\end{document} should change to Ω21AA≡1/κt+ηa1/κa1+∑ia2,b,c,dηi/κi(21AA)\begin{document}$\Omega _{\text{21AA}}\equiv 1\big/\kappa _{t}+\eta _{a1}\big/\kappa _{a1}+\sum \limits_{i}^{a2,b,c,d}\eta _{i}\big/\kappa _{i}^{\left (\text{21AA}\right)}$\end{document}. Obviously, 1/κt<Ω21AA<Ω\begin{document}$1/\kappa _{t} \lt \Omega _{\text{21AA}} \lt \Omega $\end{document}, and we estimate Ω21AA=1000 (s)\begin{document}$\Omega _{\text{21AA}}=1000\text{\ }\left (\text{s}\right)$\end{document} from the growth rate data for E. coli measured under the relevant nutrient conditions (Wallden et al., 2016). Then, we have μλC(21AA)=1.13 (h−1)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}=1.13\text{\ }\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}, and σλC(21AA)=0.12μλC(21AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}=0.12\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}$\end{document}.

For the case of a Group A carbon source mixed with 7 amino acids (7AA: His, Iso, Leu, Lys, Met, Phe, and Val), similar to the roles of φ21AA\begin{document}$\varphi _{\text{21AA}}$\end{document} and Ω21AA\begin{document}$\Omega _{\text{21AA}}$\end{document}, we define φ7AA\begin{document}$\varphi _{\text{7AA}}$\end{document} and Ω7AA\begin{document}$\Omega _{\text{7AA}}$\end{document}. Using the mass fraction of the 7AA combined with Equation S18, we have φ7AA=11.6\begin{document}$\varphi _{\text{7AA}}=11.6$\end{document}. For the value of Ω7AA\begin{document}$\Omega _{\text{7AA}}$\end{document}, evidently, Ω21AA<Ω7AA<Ω\begin{document}$\Omega _{\text{21AA}} \lt \Omega _{\text{7AA}} \lt \Omega $\end{document}, and we estimate Ω7AA=1215 (s)\begin{document}$\Omega _{\text{7AA}}=1215\text{\ }\left (\text{s}\right)$\end{document} from growth rate data for E. coli measured under the relevant culture media (Basan et al., 2015). Then, μλC(7AA)=0.98 (h−1)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (\text{7AA}\right)}}=0.98\text{\ }\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}, and σλC(7AA)=0.12μλC(7AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (7\text{AA}\right)}}=0.12\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}^{\left (7\text{AA}\right)}}$\end{document}.

For the case of w0=2.5 (h−1)\begin{document}$w_{0}=2.5\text{\ }\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}, we have φ=8.3\begin{document}$\varphi =8.3$\end{document}, and thus ηE=12.28\begin{document}$\eta _{\text{E}}=12.28$\end{document}, while other parameters such as Ω\begin{document}$\Omega $\end{document}, μλC\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}$\end{document} and σλC\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{C}}}$\end{document} remain the same as for w0=0\begin{document}$w_{0}=0$\end{document}. Nevertheless, the values for ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} under translation inhibition by Cm are influenced by the choice of w0\begin{document}$w_{0}$\end{document}, where the values of ι\begin{document}$\iota $\end{document} change to ιw0=2.5(2μm Cm)=1.05\begin{document}$\iota _{w_{0}=2.5}^{\left (2\mu \text{m Cm}\right)}=1.05$\end{document}, ιw0=2.5(4μm Cm)=2.00\begin{document}$\iota _{w_{0}=2.5}^{\left (4\mu \text{m Cm}\right)}=2.00$\end{document}, and ιw0=2.5(8μm Cm)=5.40\begin{document}$\iota _{w_{0}=2.5}^{\left (8\mu \text{m Cm}\right)}=5.40$\end{document}.

From Appendix 8.1–8.2, combined with Equation S114, the distributions of λr(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{r}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}$\end{document} and λf(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{f}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}$\end{document} can be approximated by Gaussian distributions:(S163){λr(21AA)∼N(μλr(21AA),σλr(21AA)2),λf(21AA)∼N(μλf(21AA),σλf(21AA)2),\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} \lambda_r^{(21\text{AA})} &\sim \mathcal{N}\left( \mu_{\lambda_r^{(21\text{AA})}}, \, \sigma_{\lambda_r^{(21\text{AA})}}^2 \right), \\ \lambda_f^{(21\text{AA})} &\sim \mathcal{N}\left( \mu_{\lambda_f^{(21\text{AA})}}, \, \sigma_{\lambda_f^{(21\text{AA})}}^2 \right), \end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

where μλr(21AA)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{r}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}$\end{document} and μλf(21AA)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{f}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}$\end{document} stand for the mean values, while σλr(21AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{r}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}$\end{document} and σλf(21AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{f}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}$\end{document} represent the standard deviations. For the case of glucose mixed with 21AA (labeled as ‘Glucose + 21AA’), the distribution of the growth rate λglucose(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{glucose}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}$\end{document} follows Equation S157. With Ω21AA=1000 (s)\begin{document}$\Omega _{\text{21AA}}=1000\text{\ }\left (\text{s}\right)$\end{document}, we have μλglucose, r(21AA)=1.34 (h−1)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{glucose,}r}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}=1.34\text{\ }\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document} , μλglucose,f(21AA)=1.46(h−1)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{glucose,}f}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}=1.46\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document} (both definitions follow Equation S163), and ρrf≈1.0\begin{document}$\rho _{rf}\approx 1.0$\end{document} (obtained from numerical results).

For the case of succinate mixed with 21AA (labeled as ‘Succinate +21AA’), the respiration pathway is always more efficient since succinate lies within the TCA cycle. Thus, the cell growth rate (defined as λsuccinate(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{succinate}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}$\end{document}) would take the value of the respiration one and follows a Gaussian distribution:(S164)λsuccinate(21AA)∼N(μλsuccinate(21AA),σλsuccinate(21AA)2).\begin{document}$$\lambda _{\text{succinate}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{\text{succinate}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}},\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{succinate}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}^{2}\right).$$\end{document}

For the case where acetate is the sole carbon source, the cells exclusively use the respiration pathway, and the growth rate (defined as λacetate\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{acetate}}$\end{document}) follows a Gaussian distribution:(S165)λacetate∼N(μλacetate,σλacetate2).\begin{document}$$\lambda _{\text{acetate}}\sim \mathcal{N}\left (\mu _{\lambda _{\text{acetate}}},\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{acetate}}}^{2}\right).$$\end{document}

Using the measured growth rate data (Wallden et al., 2016), we estimate μλsuccinate(21AA)=0.67(h−1)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{succinate}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}=0.67\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document} and μλacetate=0.253(h−1)\begin{document}$\mu _{\lambda _{\text{acetate}}}=0.253\left (\text{h}^{- 1}\right)$\end{document}. To illustrate the distribution of growth rates λglucose(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{glucose}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}$\end{document}, λsuccinate(21AA)\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{succinate}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}$\end{document} and λacetate\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{acetate}}$\end{document} shown in Appendix 1—figure 2B, if no other source of noise existed, extrinsic noise with a CV of 40% would be required for each kcat value. Then, σλglucose, r(21AA)≈0.21μλglucose, r(21AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{glucose,}r}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}\approx 0.21\mu _{\lambda _{\text{glucose,}r}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}$\end{document}, σλglucose, f(21AA)≈0.23μλglucose, f(21AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{glucose,}f}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}\approx 0.23\mu _{\lambda _{\text{glucose,}f}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}$\end{document}, σλsuccinate(21AA)=0.22μλsuccinate(21AA)\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{succinate}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}=0.22\mu _{\lambda _{\text{succinate}}^{\left (21\text{AA}\right)}}$\end{document}, and σλacetate=0.22μλacetate\begin{document}$\sigma _{\lambda _{\text{acetate}}}=0.22\mu _{\lambda _{\text{acetate}}}$\end{document}. Allowing for the possibility that intrinsic noise may also play a non-negligible role in the observed single-cell growth rate (which is not a long-term average), we still use extrinsic noise with a CV of 25% for the model results of E. coli, except for those shown in Appendix 1—figure 2B.

sec.title: Explanation of the Crabtree effect in yeast and the Warburg effect in tumors
sec.p: Our model, along with the analysis presented in Appendix 3, can be extended with modifications to explain the Crabtree effect in yeast and the Warburg effect in tumors. In both cases, the optimization objective remains maximizing the cell growth rate. Consequently, yeast and tumor cells use the most efficient pathway for ATP production at the single-cell level.

For model applications in yeast or tumor cell metabolism, the fermentation flux shifts from acetate secretion to ethanol and lactate secretion, respectively (see Appendix 1—figure 5A and B). The respiration and biomass generation pathways remain largely similar to those of E. coli, except that the biochemical reactions within the TCA cycle and respiratory chain occur in the mitochondria (see Appendix 1—figure 5C and D). This leads to an increased enzyme cost for the respiration pathway due to energy currency exchanges between NADH or FADH2 and ATP in the mitochondria. The coarse-grained models for Group A carbon source utilization in yeast and mammalian cells are shown in Appendix 1—figure 5E and F, where M3 represents pyruvate. In yeast and mammalian cells, the stoichiometric coefficients for ATP production (i.e. βi\begin{document}$\beta _{i}$\end{document}) are identical to each other but differ from those of E. coli (see Figure 1B and Appendix 1—figure 5C and D), with β1=5\begin{document}$\beta _{1}=5$\end{document}, β2=1\begin{document}$\beta _{2}=1$\end{document}, β3=5\begin{document}$\beta _{3}=5$\end{document}, β4=7.5\begin{document}$\beta _{4}=7.5$\end{document}, β6=−2.5\begin{document}$\beta _{6}=- 2.5$\end{document}, and βa1=5\begin{document}$\beta _{a1}=5$\end{document} (Nelson and Cox, 2008). Hence, the stoichiometric coefficients of ATP production per glucose in each pathway are βr(A)=32\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}=32$\end{document} and βf(A)=2\begin{document}$\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}=2$\end{document}, respectively, where βr(A)=β1+2(β2+β3+β4)\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}=\beta _{1}+2\left (\beta _{2}+\beta _{3}+\beta _{4}\right)$\end{document} and βf(A)=β1+2(β2+β6)\begin{document}$\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}=\beta _{1}+2\left (\beta _{2}+\beta _{6}\right)$\end{document}.

The impact of maintenance energy in yeast and tumor cells is significantly higher than that in E. coli (Locasale and Cantley, 2010). Therefore, Equation S25 changes to (see Equation S59):(S166)JE=rE⋅JBM+w0⋅Mcarbonm0,\begin{document}$$\displaystyle J_{\text{E}}=r_{\text{E}}\cdot J_{\text{BM}}+w_{0}\cdot \frac{M_{\text{carbon}}}{m_{0}},$$\end{document}

where w0\begin{document}$w_{0}$\end{document} is the aforementioned maintenance energy coefficient. Thus, we have (see Equation S60):(S167)JE(N)=ηE⋅λ+w0.\begin{document}$$J_{\text{E}}^{\left (\text{N}\right)}=\eta _{\text{E}}\cdot \lambda +w_{0}.$$\end{document}

To account for the protein cost of energy currency exchanges in the mitochondria, we introduce ϕMT\begin{document}$\phi _{\text{MT}}$\end{document} and κMT\begin{document}$\kappa _{\text{MT}}$\end{document} to represent the proteomic mass fraction of the enzymes and the effective substrate quality of related metabolites in the mitochondria, respectively. Note that the energy currency exchanges between NADH or FADH2 and ATP only occur during respiration, as there is no net NADH or FADH2 generation during fermentation (see Appendix 1—figure 5C and D). Combined with Equation S167, Equation S25 changes to:(S168){ϕA⋅κA=ϕ1⋅κ1+ϕa1⋅κa1,2ϕ1⋅κ1=ϕ2⋅κ2+ϕ5⋅κ5+ϕa2⋅κa2,ϕ2⋅κ2=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕ6⋅κ6+ϕb⋅κb,ϕ5⋅κ5+ϕ4⋅κ4=ϕ3⋅κ3+ϕd⋅κd,ϕ3⋅κ3=ϕ4⋅κ4+ϕc⋅κc,ϕa1⋅κa1=ηa1⋅λ,ϕa2⋅κa2=ηa2⋅λ,ϕb⋅κb=ηb⋅λ,ϕc⋅κc=ηc⋅λ,ϕd⋅κd=ηd⋅λ,β1⋅ϕ1⋅κ1+β2⋅ϕ2⋅κ2+β3⋅ϕ3⋅κ3+β4⋅ϕ4⋅κ4+β6⋅ϕ6⋅κ6+βa1⋅ϕa1⋅κa1=JE(N),JE(N)=ηE⋅λ+w0,λ=ϕR⋅κt,Jr(N)=ϕ4⋅κ4=ϕMT⋅κMT,Jf(N)=ϕ6⋅κ6,ϕR+ϕA+ϕ1+ϕ2+ϕ3+ϕ4+ϕ5+ϕ6+ϕMT+ϕa1+ϕa2+ϕb+ϕc+ϕd=ϕmax.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\phi _A} \cdot {\kappa _A} = {\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1} + {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}},\\ 2{\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1} = {\phi _2} \cdot {\kappa _2} + {\phi _5} \cdot {\kappa _5} + {\phi _{a2}} \cdot {\kappa _{a2}},\\ {\phi _2} \cdot {\kappa _2} = {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6} + {\phi _b} \cdot {\kappa _b},\\ {\phi _5} \cdot {\kappa _5} + {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} = {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\phi _d} \cdot {\kappa _d},\\ {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} = {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} + {\phi _c} \cdot {\kappa _c},\\ {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}} = {\eta _{a1}} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _{a2}} \cdot {\kappa _{a2}} = {\eta _{a2}} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _b} \cdot {\kappa _b} = {\eta _b} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _c} \cdot {\kappa _c} = {\eta _c} \cdot \lambda ,{\phi _d} \cdot {\kappa _d} = {\eta _d} \cdot \lambda ,\\ {\beta _1} \cdot {\phi _1} \cdot {\kappa _1} + {\beta _2} \cdot {\phi _2} \cdot {\kappa _2} + {\beta _3} \cdot {\phi _3} \cdot {\kappa _3} + {\beta _4} \cdot {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} + {\beta _6} \cdot {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6} + {\beta _{a1}} \cdot {\phi _{a1}} \cdot {\kappa _{a1}} = J_{\rm{E}}^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)},\\ J_{\rm{E}}^{\left( {\rm{N}} \right)} = {\eta _{\rm{E}}} \cdot \lambda + {w_0},\lambda = {\phi _R} \cdot {\kappa _{\rm t}},J_{r}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} = {\phi _4} \cdot {\kappa _4} = {\phi _{{\rm{MT}}}} \cdot {\kappa _{{\rm{MT}}}},J_{f}^{\left (\text{N}\right)} = {\phi _6} \cdot {\kappa _6},\\ {\phi _{\rm{R}}} + {\phi _A} + {\phi _1} + {\phi _2} + {\phi _3} + {\phi _4} + {\phi _5} + {\phi _6} + {\phi _{{\rm{MT}}}} + {\phi _{a1}} + {\phi _{a2}} + {\phi _b} + {\phi _c} + {\phi _d} = {\phi _{\max }}. \end{array} \right. $$\end{document}

Here, Equation S28 still holds, and we have:(S169){Jr(E)+Jf(E)=φ⋅λ+w0,Jr(E)εr+Jf(E)εf=ϕmax−ψ⋅λ,\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{aligned} & \displaystyle J_r^{\left( {\text{E}} \right)} + J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)} = \varphi \cdot \lambda + {w_0},\\[1pt] & \displaystyle \frac{{J_r^{\left( {\text{E}} \right)}}}{{{\varepsilon _r}}} + \frac{{J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}}}{{{\varepsilon _f}}} = {\phi _{\max }} - \psi \cdot \lambda , \end{aligned} \right. $$\end{document}

where Jr(E)\begin{document}$J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} and Jf(E)\begin{document}$J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)}$\end{document} follow Equation S30, and ψ\begin{document}$\psi $\end{document} and φ\begin{document}$\varphi $\end{document} satisfy Equation S32 and S33, respectively. The expression for εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}$\end{document} follows Equation S31. However, the expression for εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}$\end{document} differs from that in Equation S31. For yeast and mammalian cells, we have:(S170){εr=βr(A)1/κA+1/κ1+2/κ2+2/κ3+2/κ4+2/κMT,εf=βf(A)1/κA+1/κ1+2/κ2+2/κ6.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} \varepsilon _{r} &= \displaystyle \frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}}{1\big/\kappa _{A}+1\big/\kappa _{1}+2\big/\kappa _{2}+2\big/\kappa _{3}+2\big/\kappa _{4}+2\big/\kappa _{\text{MT}}},\\[1pt] \varepsilon _{f} &= \displaystyle \frac{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}{1\big/\kappa _{A}+1\big/\kappa _{1}+2\big/\kappa _{2}+2\big/\kappa _{6}}.\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

At the single-cell level, from Equation S169, and similar to Equation S61-S63, if εr>εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r} \gt \varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}, the optimal growth strategy is:(S171){Jf(E)=0,Jr(E)=φ⋅λ+w0,εr>εf,\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)} = 0,\\ J_{r}^{\left( {\text{E}} \right)} = \varphi \cdot \lambda + {w_0}, \end{array} \right.\,\,\,\,\,\,{\varepsilon _r} > {\varepsilon _f}, $$\end{document}

while if εf>εr\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f} \gt \varepsilon _{r}$\end{document}, the optimal growth strategy is:(S172){Jf(E)=φ⋅λ+w0,Jr(E)=0.εr<εf.\begin{document}$$\left\{ \begin{array}{l} J_{f}^{\left (\text{E}\right)} = \varphi \cdot \lambda + {w_0},\\ J_{r}^{\left (\text{E}\right)} = 0. \end{array} \right.\,\,\,\,\,\,{\varepsilon _r} < {\varepsilon _f}. $$\end{document}

In both cases, the growth rate λ\begin{document}$\lambda $\end{document} reaches its maximum value for a given nutrient condition with fixed κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document}:(S173)λ(κA)={ϕmax−w0/εr(κA)φ/εr(κA)+ψ(κA)εr(κA)>εf(κA),ϕmax−w0/εf(κA)φ/εf(κA)+ψ(κA)εr(κA)<εf(κA).\begin{document}$$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A}\right)=\left \{\begin{aligned} &\displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}- w_{0}\big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right),\\[1pt] &\displaystyle \frac{\phi _{\rm max}- w_{0}\big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}\right)}\qquad\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\right).\end{aligned} \right.$$\end{document}

From Equation S170, when κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} is very small such that κA→0\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0$\end{document}, it is evident that for yeast and mammalian cells, we still have:(S174){εr(κA→0)≈βr(A)⋅κA,εf(κA→0)≈βf(A)⋅κA.\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{array}{c}\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right)\approx \beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}\cdot \kappa _{A},\\\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right)\approx \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}\cdot \kappa _{A}.\end{array}\right.$$\end{document}
Thus,(S175)εr(κA→0)>εf(κA→0),\begin{document}$$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right) \gt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}\rightarrow 0\right),$$\end{document}

since βr(A)≫βf(A)\begin{document}$\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}\gg \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}$\end{document} still holds. Then, as long as εr(κAmax)<εf(κAmax)\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right) \lt \varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\rm max}\right)$\end{document}, there exists a critical switching point for κA\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}$\end{document} (denoted as κA(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}$\end{document}; see Equation S41), below which respiration is more efficient, while above κA(C)\begin{document}$\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}$\end{document}, fermentation becomes more efficient in ATP production per proteome. Combined with Equation S170, we have:(S176)κA(C)=βr(A)−βf(A)βf(A)(1/κ1+2/κ2+2/κ3+2/κ4+2/κMT)−βr(A)(1/κ1+2/κ2+2/κ6).\begin{document}$$\displaystyle \kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}=\frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}- \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}{\beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}\left (1\big/\kappa _{1}+2\big/\kappa _{2}+2\big/\kappa _{3}+2\big/\kappa _{4}+2\big/\kappa _{\text{MT}}\right)- \beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}\left (1\big/\kappa _{1}+2\big/\kappa _{2}+2/\kappa _{6}\right)}.$$\end{document}

Accordingly, we obtain the expressions for εr(κA(C))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)$\end{document}, εf(κA(C))\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)$\end{document} and λC\begin{document}$\lambda _{\text{C}}$\end{document} (i.e. λ(κA(C))\begin{document}$\lambda \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)$\end{document}):(S177){εr(κA(C))=εf(κA(C))=βr(A)−βf(A)2(1/κ3+1/κ4+1/κMT−1/κ6),λC=ϕmax−w0/εr/f(κA(C))φ/εr/f(κA(C))+ψ(κA(C)),\begin{document}$$\left \{\begin{aligned} &\displaystyle \varepsilon _{r}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=\varepsilon _{f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)=\frac{\beta _{r}^{\left (A\right)}- \beta _{f}^{\left (A\right)}}{2\left (1\big/\kappa _{3}+1\big/\kappa _{4}+1\big/\kappa _{\text{MT}}- 1\big/\kappa _{6}\right)}\text{,}\\[1pt] &\displaystyle \lambda _{\text{C}}=\frac{\phi _{\rm max}- w_{0}\big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)}{\varphi \big/\varepsilon _{r/f}\left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)+\psi \left (\kappa _{A}^{\left (\text{C}\right)}\right)}\text{,}\end{aligned}\right.$$\end{document}

Consequently, yeast and tumor cells would preferentially use respiration under starvation conditions (where εr>εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r} \gt \varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}), yet switch to aerobic glycolysis when nutrients are abundant (where εr<εf\begin{document}$\varepsilon _{r} \lt \varepsilon _{f}$\end{document}) for optimal cell growth.
